X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Good news sometimes comes in funny packages

Meteorite hits New Jersey home.=0A=0AI know, I know, having a meteorite str=
ike your house doesn't sound like very good news, until you start thinking =
about it that is. First of all, assuming it didn't kill you, you are really=
 lucky!  Second, a meterorite that hit a house is worth serious bank!  Only=
 six meteorites have been verified to have struck a building in the past 40=
0 years as I understand it.=0A=0Ahttp://www.ecanadanow.com/curiosity/2007/0=
1/06/meteorite-falls-through-roof-of-house-in-new-jersey/=0Ahttp://www.nyda=
ilynews.com/front/story/486216p-409309c.html=0A=0AIt is interesting to star=
t thinking about the odds of something like this happening.  =0A=0ABack in =
1991, right before my first son was born, I was driving up Highway 9 to my =
house in the Santa Cruz mountains when a fellow driving the other direction=
 lost control of his van and struck me.  I suffered a broken rib, some nast=
y cuts, and some back injuries that still haunt me until this day.  My car =
was almost pushed over the cliff with one rear wheel fully over the side.  =
The van driver was scared shitless but was uninjured.=0A=0ABut what were th=
e chances? Both cars were traveling 35-40 miles per hour making our relativ=
e velocity in excess of 70 miles per hour.  My car, a Mazda 323, was less t=
han 20 feet long.  At that speed, a variation in timing of only a fraction =
of a second  (check the math yourself) would have meant my car wasn't there=
 when he lost control and his van would have plunged over the side .  He pr=
obably would have ended up rolling down several hundred feet of the steep m=
ountain side, where there were several broken remains of cars that had prev=
iously taken that tumble.  My car being precisely where it was when it was,=
 very likely saved this man's life.  I hope he's been making good use of th=
at second chance.=0A=0AThis incident also triggered a number of life changi=
ng circumstances for me.  And then there was the mysterious "mountain man" =
that stopped and gave me a Mustang Ranch t-shirt to stop the bleeding on my=
 arm.  The fireman that came from the station at the summit said they didn'=
t see the old blue Ford stepside pick up and there weren't any houses aroun=
d there either.  But I digress.=0A=0ANext time you encounter a life changin=
g event, whether its a meteorite, a car accident, or something else, consid=
er the odds.  And consider the ramifications to everyone involved in the ev=
ent.  I think you'll find that many of these seminal events in your life ar=
e also surprisingly unlikely.  =0A=0APeace,=0A=0APeter=0A=0A=0A=0A=0A=0A=0A=
=0A

 Jersey home.=0A=0AI know, I know, having a meteorite strike your house doe=
sn't sound like very good news, until you start thinking about it that is. =
First of all, assuming it didn't kill you, you are really lucky!  Second, a=
 meterorite that hit a house is worth serious bank!  Only six meteorites ha=
ve been verified to have struck a building in the past 400 years as I under=
stand it.=0A=0Ahttp://www.ecanadanow.com/curiosity/2007/01/06/meteorite-fal=
ls-through-roof-of-house-in-new-jersey/=0Ahttp://www.nydailynews.com/front/=
story/486216p-409309c.html=0A=0AIt is interesting to start thinking about t=
he odds of something like this happening.  =0A=0ABack in 1991, right before=
 my first son was born, I was driving up Highway 9 to my house in the Santa=
 Cruz mountains when a fellow driving the other direction lost control of h=
is van and struck me.  I suffered a broken rib, some nasty cuts, and some b=
ack injuries that still haunt me until this day.  My car was almost pushed =
over the cliff with one rear wheel fully over the side.  The van driver was=
 scared shitless but was uninjured.=0A=0ABut what were the chances? Both ca=
rs were traveling 35-40 miles per hour making our relative velocity in exce=
ss of 70 miles per hour.  My car, a Mazda 323, was less than 20 feet long. =
 At that speed, a variation in timing of only a fraction of a second  (chec=
k the math yourself) would have meant my car wasn't there when he lost cont=
rol and his van would have plunged over the side .  He probably would have =
ended up rolling down several hundred feet of the steep mountain side, wher=
e there were several broken remains of cars that had previously taken that =
tumble.  My car being precisely where it was when it was, very likely saved=
 this man's life.  I hope he's been making good use of that second chance.=
=0A=0AThis incident also triggered a number of life changing circumstances =
for me.  And then there was the mysterious "mountain man" that stopped and =
gave me a Mustang Ranch t-shirt to stop the bleeding on my arm.  The firema=
n that came from the station at the summit said they didn't see the old blu=
e Ford stepside pick up and there weren't any houses around there either.  =
=0A=0ANext time you encounter a life changing event, whether its a meteorit=
e, a car accident, or something else, consider the odds.  And consider the =
ramifications to everyone involved in the event.  I think you'll find that =
many of these seminal events in your life are also surprisingly unlikely.  =
Food for thought and IMO good news as well.=0A=0APeace,=0A=0APeter=0A=0A=0A=

Got a couple things going on.  For starters, most people thing the federal 
Reserve is actually owned by the government.  Second, most activists care 
more about about the activism than they do the cause.  They don't care what 
they're protesting as long as they get to protest.  The hypocracy astounds 
me as I can't imagine anyone beinga  more negative bitter person than that 
while at the same time self suffocating themselves on their smug self 
rightiousness.

"What do we want?  CHANGE!"
"What are we protesting?  WHO CARES!"

Cue circus music....

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Mon)

Ok, I have a question and would appreciate some good intelligent answers:

I was listening to conservative radio this morning on my way to work
(not Rush) and their point is that we should escalate the war and
fight it correctly in order to win. Their point is, we have to
increase troop strength, lower Iraqi freedoms, and stop playing the
good guy political correct army. Especially since we haven't won a war
since we stopped being brutal.

The other point is that if we leave:

1. Iraq collapses into a terrorist state (which would be a threat to the US)
2. Iran can overrun Iraq (Which is already somewhat happening since
Iran has been sending and funding terrorists in Iraq)
3. Iran can gain nuclear ability easier
4. The massive oil supply (money) of Iraq will be in the hands of terrorists.

so what is the best way to negate these arguments?

Also, another question, how is it that we were able to conquer Japan
and Germany in less time then Iraq and defeat the uprising (which
there was a lot of after the war) in those countries so easily?

Thanks for any thoughtful repies.

Steve:

IMHO, The best way to negate the points you illustrated below:

1) Let's call a spade a spade. Iraq is on the brink of a civil war, and half of the ING are spies/underground separatists aka Terrorists to those that oppose them (and get blown up by them). For all intents & purposes, it already is more of a terrorist state than it was before we entered. Not to say Saddam wasn't a brutal Tyrant, just telling it how it is. I sincerely subscribe to the notion that there will only be a political solution to this mess.

2) Iraq was the other "Super-Power" in that region before we invaded. Because vast resources were used on both sides of each nation while they were at war (and Cold War), this kept the president of Iran in check. Now that Saddam's out, this guy is now the shot-caller whether we like it or not. Even Iraq's president is co-conspiring with him now about what to do when we leave. Will Iran run amok all over North Iraq when we pull out? Doubt it, they've got bigger fish to fry. Like Europe & Sunni-based Saudi Arabia. 

3) No offense, but what a joke. We're talking about a country that already has these capabilities. Note Israel is technically still undeclared, as I bet Iran will remain for a long time unless they feel threatened. I think N. Korea will declare first if they have not already. 

4) What can I say? That point is well-taken. Let's leave before they do take control! Political solutions! Political solutions! Us being there is only attracting enrollment. As a matter of fact, I believe AQ is bigger now than ever.

To your second question: "Easily?" Don't think so buddy. You know better than to post a comment like that! Also, you need to read the 'Greatest Generation or watch Private Ryan. Don't play the easily won because we nuked 'em card; we had plenty of casualties esp. in Europe. There was nothing easy about it. 

peace

Chuck

Steve Osteen <sosteen@gmail.com> wrote: Ok, I have a question and would appreciate some good intelligent answers:

I was listening to conservative radio this morning on my way to work
(not Rush) and their point is that we should escalate the war and
fight it correctly in order to win. Their point is, we have to
increase troop strength, lower Iraqi freedoms, and stop playing the
good guy political correct army. Especially since we haven't won a war
since we stopped being brutal.

The other point is that if we leave:

1. Iraq collapses into a terrorist state (which would be a threat to the US)
2. Iran can overrun Iraq (Which is already somewhat happening since
Iran has been sending and funding terrorists in Iraq)
3. Iran can gain nuclear ability easier
4. The massive oil supply (money) of Iraq will be in the hands of terrorists.

so what is the best way to negate these arguments?

Also, another question, how is it that we were able to conquer Japan
and Germany in less time then Iraq and defeat the uprising (which
there was a lot of after the war) in those countries so easily?

Thanks for any thoughtful repies.

Hi Steve~

 From my perspective--having been a kid during WW II with relatives  
in both the European and Pacific Theatres of  War--there is NO simple  
answer except that we were still seen in Europe as liberators from  
Hitler's Nazi German empire and not as occupiers, and in Japan we had  
just dropped two A-bombs so they were in awe of our superiority. Thus  
we were overwhelmingly welcome in both Europe and Japan. Beyond that,  
of course, there's a lot more, but that IMO is a reasonable overview  
of  the main differences then and now.

Thanks for the good questions! I hope  you DO  get some thoughtful  
answers to  them!

Will

Hi Steve~
> As for the the whole Japan/Germany issue, I wasn't referring to the
> wars themselves (I'm well aware over 50 million people died in it, and
> I can also name every aircraft that fought in it) I was referring to
> how easily we transformed the countries after the war.

But there IS an important connection between the two: just as the  
situation in the Pacific Theatre of War was different from that in  
the European Theatre. The transformations were different as well:   
American occup[ation of a subservient people in Japan and in Europe  
the Marshall Plan to prevent the Soviets from taking over more  
countries there.

Will

job?  McCain is calling for a much larger commitment.  Why is he wrong?=0A=

k at this point spending more money and lives requires a detailed justifica=
tion, and as far as I am concerned Bush and Co. have no credibility whatsoe=
ver.  They need to prove their argument, because otherwise its less than cl=
ear that you aren't simply throwing away more money and more lives for noth=
ing.=0A=0AI do think you raise some good points about what might be require=
d to really "win" a war.  At some level, war is a contest of wills.  And th=
at's the difference you observe between WWII and more recent conflicts at s=
ome level.  If the enemy's will to fight isn't broken you can't really say =
you've won the war.  But then "Mission Accomplished" depends on how you def=
ine the mission.   =0A=0APersonally, I'd argue that fighting unecessary war=
s which in the end we can't (or simply won't) win isn't a very sound nation=
al strategy.  And it seems to some of us that this is exactly the situation=
  in Iraq.  Realism and planning are required to get us out of this mess; d=
elusional idealism and hoping for the best aren't likely to produce the out=
come, a safer, prosperous, and free America, at peace, which I think we all=
 want.=0A =0APeace,=0A =0APeter=0A=0AP.S. If I was a conspiracy theorist, I=
 might suppose that part of the original plan for invading Iraq was to mire=
 the U.S. in exactly the dilemma you've outlined.  Ask yourself who benefit=
s from that situation and follow the money.=0A=0A=0A----- Original Message =

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Mon)


I can handle that one...

1. We had Nukes.  They didn't.
2.  Remember my statement about the overtaking of an educated nation vs non 
educated?  Cases in point.

ANyone willing to listen to reason is somebody that can be 
converted/brainwashed to your way of thinking.  Unreasonable people are the 
hardest to convert.  20 years of the Russian Afghan war taught us 
nothing.  Uneducated doesn't mean stupid.  What I mean are people who are 
not pre-occupied with thoughts about teh higher philisophiclal points of 
life, and have time to debate about this (all mailing lists online case in 
point).  They have to go work.  They work for food.  They farm, they 
irrigate, tend to flocks, etc.  Discussions are in the realm of did you eat 
today, was it good, how many sheep do you have.

These are the types of people that when you see a deadly snake, you kill 
it.  You don't worry about it's feelings, why it's there, what it's doing, 
what is it's food supply, what global climate changes could have caused it 
to leave it's normal enviorment, can it be reasoned with, maybe its' hungry 
and if i feed it it will go away.

Do you see where I'm going with this?  Kill the snake.

Thats' the mind set we're dealing with.  That's the problem I have when 
people say that "politics" will solve everything.  Remember that Politics 
is the science of being polite, and making everyone happy, saying things 
they want to hear.

If you want people to listen, you have to use a bigger hammer than the one 
they carry.  We have nothig that actually scares any of these people.  If 
we really want a political solution that would work we have two choices:

Army Corp of Enginners:  Rebuild the region with the iraqi people.  Teach 
them everything we can and make them self sufficient (What we did in 
Japan).  People are less likely to blow up something they build and put a 
lot of sweat into.  Doesn't mean it won't happen though.

Nuclear Threat:  Army corp builds some large tombs all over bagdad and we 
drop in some 100 megaton warheads into each one and seal them in.  All 
attacks are to cease or we level the region.  You have 24 hours to comply, 
then the talks can begin.  No compliance, we turn the entire place into a 
sheet of glass, and the remaining military that moved to a safe distance 
will take over all the oil fields and drain them dry. (Post WWII Germany 
Model).  Yes, this is extreme.  The world would not look favorably on us 
for this, but I doubt anyone would want to fuck with us either.

Since we're doing quotes...

"Just before World War I, there were a number of terrorist attacks on the 
United States forces in the Philippines by Islamic extremists. So General 
Pershing captured 50 terrorists, and had them tied to posts for execution. 
He then had his men bring in two pigs and slaughter them in front of the, 
now horrified, terrorists. Muslims detest pork, because they believe pigs 
are filthy animals. Some of them simply refuse to eat it, while others 
won't even touch pigs at all, nor any of their by-products. To them, eating 
or touching a pig, its meat, its blood, etc., is to be instantly barred 
from Paradise (and those virgins), and doomed to hell. The soldiers then 
soaked their bullets in the pigs' blood, and proceeded to execute 49 of the 
terrorists by firing squad. The soldiers then dug a big hole, dumped in the 
terrorist's bodies, and covered them in pig blood, entrails, etc. They let 
the 50th man go. And for the next 42 years, there was not a single Muslim 
extremist attack anywhere in the world. Maybe it is time for this segment 
of history to repeat itself, maybe in Iraq? The question is, where do we 
find another Black Jack Pershing?"

And the famous...

"Of course the people don't want war. But after all, it's the leaders of 
the country who determine the policy, and it's always a simple matter to 
drag the people along whether it's a democracy, a fascist dictatorship, or 
a parliament, or a communist dictatorship. Voice or no voice, the people 
can always be brought to the bidding of the leaders. That is easy. All you 
have to do is tell them they are being attacked, and denounce the pacifists 
for lack of patriotism, and exposing the country to greater danger."

-- Herman Goering at the Nuremberg trials

PBS's news program Frontline had a great episode on
recently titled "The Dark Side" which documents the
hows and whys of the deception that created and
reinforced the al quaeda/WMD story that was used to
wrest war powers from Congree so the US military could
invide Iraq.

You can watch the program for free on the Frontline
website:

http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/darkside/

The thing of all this stuff is that there's no grey
area to it.  All of this has been done out in the open
and right under everyone's nose.  The problem is that
no one has the cajones to call the administration on
it.  The American people (that's you and me, folks)
are A-O-K with this kind of thing going on in our
name, so it doesn't get challenged.

Now that Saddam's out, this guy is now the shot-caller whether we like it or not. Even Iraq's president is co-conspiring with him now about what to do when we leave. > Since we're doing quotes...
>
> "Just before World War I, there were a number of terrorist attacks on the 
> United States forces in the Philippines by Islamic extremists. So General 
> Pershing captured 50 terrorists, and had them tied to posts for execution. He 
> then had his men bring in two pigs and slaughter them in front of the, now 
> horrified, terrorists. Muslims detest pork, because they believe pigs are 
> filthy animals. Some of them simply refuse to eat it, while others won't even 
> touch pigs at all, nor any of their by-products. To them, eating or touching 
> a pig, its meat, its blood, etc., is to be instantly barred from Paradise 
> (and those virgins), and doomed to hell. The soldiers then soaked their 
> bullets in the pigs' blood, and proceeded to execute 49 of the terrorists by 
> firing squad. The soldiers then dug a big hole, dumped in the terrorist's 
> bodies, and covered them in pig blood, entrails, etc. They let the 50th man 
> go. And for the next 42 years, there was not a single Muslim extremist attack 
> anywhere in the world. Maybe it is time for this segment of history to repeat 
> itself, maybe in Iraq? The question is, where do we find another Black Jack 
> Pershing?"

sounds of it):
http://www.snopes.com/rumors/pershing.htm

> always be brought to the bidding of the leaders. That is easy. All you have

> lack of patriotism, and exposing the country to greater danger."

"No sage or savior has ever endorsed greed and gluttony as a path  
toward social justice or personal fulfillment.  These sane and  
enlightened people come to us from all cultures and all eras,  
sometimes knowing of each other but more often not.  Socrates and  
Jesus, Lao Tzu and Tolstoi, Gandhi and Martin Buber -- no one can  
find in their lives and words a jot of support for a political and  
economic regime that encourages the acquisition of wealth far beyond  
what is needed for the necessaries -- or even the restorative  
pleasures -- of life while consigning the masses to live and work in  
squalor."
-Stephen J. Fortunato, Associate Justice, Rhode Island Supreme Court.

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of  
the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will  
gradually become visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

I've never said otherwise, however I'm not out in public making an ass of 
myself trying to disrupt the lives of everyone around me.  It would be one 
thing of the california congress directly voted against the peoples general 
wishes, but they don't, for the most part.  Our polititions are just as 
whiney and liberal as the statistical majority.

Case in point:  San Francisco stages a protest against something that the 
highly liberal city and state are already opposed to, with voteing records 
to back this up.

Bravo.  That's like throwing an anti-abortion rally at the RNC.  Way to 
open up the eyes and minds of the masses.

Try going somewhere where your feelings are agree'd upon by the 
public.  How about an anti-gun and war protest in Texas, or 
Georgia.  Anywhere in the deep south.  Go where there's a lot of voters and 
convince them.  No, that would be hard.

That's part of my point.  Its sorta en vogue to protest everything a round 
these parts.

From: Deepfog <sfgroove@deepfog.com>

To: "The Twilight Laser Outpost (West)" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Mon)

hey all -

i was out all day, here's what i did, i saw a lot of responses, i  
read them all, and i basically made one big reply, i didn't edit  
anything, and i tried to flag stuff that i haven't researched.  i'm  
trying to get some home organizing going on here, so wish me luck and  
i hope my comments add to the discussion but don't overwhelm people.   
have a good one.

--

I personally encourage getting information from whatever source you  
want, even Rush Limbaugh.  The problem many of us have is we don't  
get our information from *enough* sources.  I believe these studies  
that used to come out that suggested most Americans get their  
information from television news.  I remember I used to joke around  
years ago on this very list that I got all my news and information  
from ABC-7 news, which is owned by ABC, which is owned by Disney.

But when you think about it, how smart is it for anyone to get their  
news and information from an entertainment company?  That's like  
going to a used car dealer and asking them what they paid for the  
car.  Obviously they're going to do whatever they can to make sure  
they get the highest price at the highest interest rate from you, the  
consumer.  So it's up to you, the consumer, to make sure you're  
informed about the scams car dealers pull, just like it's your  
responsibility as a citizen to make sure you get your information  
from varying sources and use the brain that was given to you to  
figure out what you think is good and what you think is BS.

This war was not made to be won or lost, in my opinion, from what  
I've read, just like Vietnam wasn't.  It was made to keep perpetual  
war going on and on, for as long as they can, to keep the no-bid  
contracts going, to keep the oil in Iraq from flowing.  Right now,  
I'm reading Greg Palast's Armed Madhouse, where he outlines that the  
Bush Administration did not have 1 plan to invade Iraq before 9/11.   
In fact, he had 2 plans.  For those of you who don't know who he is,  
he is a BBC reporter that sometimes works for ABC News.  He was  
arrested a few months ago for filming a FEMA camp outside New Orleans  
that was next to an oil refinery.  He was charged under the PATRIOT  
ACT as a terrorist, but the government dropped the charges due to  
public outcry.

How many of you have heard that British soldiers were caught running  
around Iraq dressed up like Arabs with bombs and weapons in the back  
of whatever they were driving?  If this is true, what more would  
anyone need to come to the conclusion that perpetual war is the true  
goal?

By the way, did you know the United States has a ship called the USS  
Haliburton?  Welcome to the new America, where we do, indeed, pay  
constant homage to the corporation.

Now, back to these neocon talk show hosts.  Look, most of what is out  
there on the radio is just parroting the globalist agenda, in my  
opinion, but no matter what you're listening to, I would write down  
(or type in) supposed facts anyone spews out and verify it with your  
own research.  The problem, I think, in this country is most people  
don't read enough!  Read books!

Love that Herman Goering quote, by the way.  So true.

 From what I hear, we're being set up by people like Rupert Murdoch,  
who owns Fox News here and Sky TV in the UK, by demonizing the evil  
Americans invading a sovereign nation, and then here in America,  
telling us how great the war in Iraq is.  End result?  Everyone hates  
us, and we didn't even ask for this war.  At least I didn't  
personally call the White House and ask for us to invade Iraq and  
spend my money to do it.  Anyway, what does anyone think about this  
conspiracy theory?

By the way, where is Starchild?  I used to always hear people  
complain about getting their ear talked off about the Libertarian  
party.  A lot of these issues about bigger government and the  
encroaching police state, though, are I think Libertarian in nature,  
in my opinion.

Responding to Shatter's comment about military leaders being the  
types that wouldn't hesitate to shoot a soldier on the battlefield  
for cowardice.  One has to wonder what a definition of cowardice  
might be on today's battlefield, with the story of Jessica Lynch  
supposedly later coming out as staged, and the soldiers that didn't  
go along with the official version wind up dead, or the supposed  
controversy regarding Pat Tillmon's death.  What really happened  
there?  Apparently Kevin Tillmon, his brother, might be ready to talk  
about what he's learned.  Now I heard all this on the Alex Jones  
show, and I didn't research any of it, so go on the internet and  
research it before you go saying this as fact, or, conversely,  
calling me a nut.  What if it's true?

--

There we go, I've been waiting for Deepfog to chime in all day (I love
his posts). Now my day is complete and I can go home and play legos
with my kid. Seriously.

Ok, so you think more along the conspiracy lines.... I personally
think that the conspiracy argument is probably about 30% true. For
instance: I'm sure Bush wanted to invade Iraq and I'm sure that
coorporations and oil helped his decision, but still there were some
decent reasons...

I always believed that Iraq was a major threat to the US and felt that
they were an immediate danger and thus attacking them was in our best
interest. Now, looking back I remember getting pissed off because all
Bush would say for reasons to go to war was " we are going to liberate
the people of Iraq from a repressive regime". For me, that is not a
reason to go to war, self defense is the only time violence is
acceptable.

Oh well...

Yeah, I also miss the libertarian posts.

Later,
Steve

On 1/8/07, Deepfog <sfgroove@deepfog.com> wrote:
> hey all -
>
> i was out all day, here's what i did, i saw a lot of responses, i
> read them all, and i basically made one big reply, i didn't edit
> anything, and i tried to flag stuff that i haven't researched.  i'm
> trying to get some home organizing going on here, so wish me luck and
> i hope my comments add to the discussion but don't overwhelm people.
> have a good one.
>
> --
>
> I personally encourage getting information from whatever source you
> want, even Rush Limbaugh.  The problem many of us have is we don't
> get our information from *enough* sources.  I believe these studies
> that used to come out that suggested most Americans get their
> information from television news.  I remember I used to joke around
> years ago on this very list that I got all my news and information
> from ABC-7 news, which is owned by ABC, which is owned by Disney.
>
> But when you think about it, how smart is it for anyone to get their
> news and information from an entertainment company?  That's like
> going to a used car dealer and asking them what they paid for the
> car.  Obviously they're going to do whatever they can to make sure
> they get the highest price at the highest interest rate from you, the
> consumer.  So it's up to you, the consumer, to make sure you're
> informed about the scams car dealers pull, just like it's your
> responsibility as a citizen to make sure you get your information
> from varying sources and use the brain that was given to you to
> figure out what you think is good and what you think is BS.
>
> This war was not made to be won or lost, in my opinion, from what
> I've read, just like Vietnam wasn't.  It was made to keep perpetual
> war going on and on, for as long as they can, to keep the no-bid
> contracts going, to keep the oil in Iraq from flowing.  Right now,
> I'm reading Greg Palast's Armed Madhouse, where he outlines that the
> Bush Administration did not have 1 plan to invade Iraq before 9/11.
> In fact, he had 2 plans.  For those of you who don't know who he is,
> he is a BBC reporter that sometimes works for ABC News.  He was
> arrested a few months ago for filming a FEMA camp outside New Orleans
> that was next to an oil refinery.  He was charged under the PATRIOT
> ACT as a terrorist, but the government dropped the charges due to
> public outcry.
>
> How many of you have heard that British soldiers were caught running
> around Iraq dressed up like Arabs with bombs and weapons in the back
> of whatever they were driving?  If this is true, what more would
> anyone need to come to the conclusion that perpetual war is the true
> goal?
>
> By the way, did you know the United States has a ship called the USS
> Haliburton?  Welcome to the new America, where we do, indeed, pay
> constant homage to the corporation.
>
> Now, back to these neocon talk show hosts.  Look, most of what is out
> there on the radio is just parroting the globalist agenda, in my
> opinion, but no matter what you're listening to, I would write down
> (or type in) supposed facts anyone spews out and verify it with your
> own research.  The problem, I think, in this country is most people
> don't read enough!  Read books!
>
> Love that Herman Goering quote, by the way.  So true.
>
>  From what I hear, we're being set up by people like Rupert Murdoch,
> who owns Fox News here and Sky TV in the UK, by demonizing the evil
> Americans invading a sovereign nation, and then here in America,
> telling us how great the war in Iraq is.  End result?  Everyone hates
> us, and we didn't even ask for this war.  At least I didn't
> personally call the White House and ask for us to invade Iraq and
> spend my money to do it.  Anyway, what does anyone think about this
> conspiracy theory?
>
> By the way, where is Starchild?  I used to always hear people
> complain about getting their ear talked off about the Libertarian
> party.  A lot of these issues about bigger government and the
> encroaching police state, though, are I think Libertarian in nature,
> in my opinion.
>
> Responding to Shatter's comment about military leaders being the
> types that wouldn't hesitate to shoot a soldier on the battlefield
> for cowardice.  One has to wonder what a definition of cowardice
> might be on today's battlefield, with the story of Jessica Lynch
> supposedly later coming out as staged, and the soldiers that didn't
> go along with the official version wind up dead, or the supposed
> controversy regarding Pat Tillmon's death.  What really happened
> there?  Apparently Kevin Tillmon, his brother, might be ready to talk
> about what he's learned.  Now I heard all this on the Alex Jones
> show, and I didn't research any of it, so go on the internet and
> research it before you go saying this as fact, or, conversely,
> calling me a nut.  What if it's true?
>

other countries in protest of their running water.

Because I'm not much of a protester.  The only times I've bother, was to 
piss off the majority.  During the first gulf war there were lots of 
anti-war protests, I joined the war support ones.  Did I believe in 
it?  No, but I certainly didn't want to be seen with those assholes on the 
other side of the street.  ;)

My political views are weird.  I still think Iraq was a huge mistake and 
was opposed to us going in.  OTOH now that we're there, we have to finish 
it correctly, with some sort of end game strategy.  Of course we got into 
Iraq without finishing Afghanistan.  Funny how nobody mentions the war 
there anymore, even though it ages on.  Six years and counting.

I like guns.  I think we should all have them.

I'm mostly anti-abortion and pro capital punishment.  How could I be 
anti-abortion???  It's simple.  There's a lot of fucking BC on the 
market.  People will give it to you for FREE.  Condoms are everywhere.  For 
fucks sake, how in the hell can any get knocked up these days?  Abortion is 
not proper birth control.  Are there times when it's needed?  Yes, I just 
think it's too readily available.  Not that I'm saying no, but if they're 
going to make me wait 15 days to buy a gun, then they should make women 
wait 15 days to kill fetus.  My buying a gun doesn't mean something is 
guarentee'd to die, but an abortion certainly does guarentee it.  Also, 
second trimester abortions...  wrong...  performing them on 6mo 
pregnancies...  wrong.   So wrong...

I also think piss tests for Gov't assistance should be manditory.  People 
have to get a piss test for a job, it's only fair that those on the dole 
should have to get off their ass and meet them half way.

So...   am I still preaching to the choir?

> everywhere.  For
> fucks sake, how in the hell can any get knocked up these days?  Abortion
> is
> not proper birth control.  Are there times when it's needed?  Yes, I just
> think it's too readily available.  Not that I'm saying no, but if they're
> going to make me wait 15 days to buy a gun, then they should make women
> wait 15 days to kill fetus.  My buying a gun doesn't mean something is
> guarentee'd to die, but an abortion certainly does guarentee it.  Also,
> second trimester abortions...  wrong...  performing them on 6mo

I think the problem with guys like Chomsky is that commentators and 
editorialists are treated as credible news sources.  They'll editorialize 
on some subject, and people will treat it as a news article, instead of 
what it really is, an opinion.

It was a super small show too, there was like maybe 50 people in the
audience, and so they pretty much let us all up on stage, and my friend
almost stomped on Alec Empires face cause he dropped to the floor screaming
during one of the songs and with everyone moshing up on stage my buddy got
pushed back and noticed just in time to move his foot out of the way, and
helped Alec back up.  My ears rang for days after that concert...hehehehe.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR: What are the best *shows you've seen?

Too many to really list...

The ones I really remember was a string of about 5 tour stops I followed 
Primus around during Pork Soda tour,
Mr Bungle. Every time I see them. The 1999/2000 show at the Galleria 
with Melvins and Fantomas. At midnight, when the whole place thought Y2K 
was gonna destroy life as we knew it, at the drop of the balloons and 
confetti they mr bungle comes out on stage and started their set to 
"what the world needs now.... is love, sweet love". And goes immediately 
from that song to some super heavy shit. Cathartic.
Strapping Young Lad
Pigface when they'd have like 25 people on stage at once.
Idiot Flesh and now Sleepytime Gorilla Museum...
Roni Size at the Maritime.
Frontline Assembly at the Maritime.
Einsturzende Neubauten.
Tool, San Jose.
Babyland whenever they'd play, sometimes in the desert. Thirteen years 
have gone by and I still catch them when they come up to the Gilman.
I never got really into seeing electronic acts live mostly because you'd 
see this fantastic group on stage but in a concert environment and you'd 
really want to dance your ass off but everyone else would be too dumb to 
get into it. It just never felt the same as the way I'd imagine it in my 
head.

And what I am really certain of is that I'm going to go to Lamb of God, 
Machine Head, and Gojira for my birthday in Santa Cruz in Feb. Hell yeah.

-t

Subject: [sfraves] SRR?:  John Law Sues His Former Burning Man Partners

--=====================_4167078==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"



<http://laughingsquid.com/john-law-sues-his-former-burning-man-partners/>John Law Sues His Former Burning Man Partners

posted by <http://laughingsquid.com/scott-beale/>Scott Beale on January 9th, 2007 

<http://johnlawspeaks.wordpress.com>John Law, one of the original three owners of the <http://burningman.com/>Burning Man event, contacted me to let me know that he is just filed suit against his two Burning Man partners <http://www.burningman.com/whatisburningman/people/1_harvey_bio.html>Larry Harvey and Michael Mikel, after Michael initiated his own legal proceedings and demand for arbitration. In 1997 Paper Man LLC was formed between the three original owners in order to own and control the name and service mark “Burning Man”, which is at the center of this dispute.

Here’s a <http://johnlawspeaks.wordpress.com/2007/01/09/does-burning-man-belong-to-everyone/>statement from John Law regarding this lawsuit from his blog, which he recently launched in order to have a public voice regarding this issue.

Here’s a <http://laughingsquid.com/other/john_law_burning_man_complaint.pdf>PDF of John Law’s complaint that was filed in San Francisco on January 9th, 2007.

Full Disclosure: John Law is one of Laughing Squid’s business partners and a close personal friend, but that relationship is independent of his legal involvement in Burning Man. I met John in 1995 through the <http://cacophony.org/>San Francisco Cacophony Society and in 1999 he was involved in the formation of Laughing Squid LLC (Laughing Squid’s current business structure) along our third partner David Klass. I am a big supporter of the Burning Man event, which I attended for 8 straight years (1995-2002) and I plan on returning again in the future. The bottom line is that I am staying neutral on this issue. I’m good friends with the three people involved and hope they find a amicable resolution to this situation.

CONTINUED:  http://laughingsquid.com/john-law-sues-his-former-burning-man-partners/






<http://www.asambleapopulardeoaxaca.com/>http://www.asambleapopulardeoaxaca.com/ 

MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo 

Tribenet:   <http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k>http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k

"An adult is one who has lost the grace, the freshness, the innocence of the child, who is no longer capable of feeling pure joy, who makes everything complicated, who spreads suffering everywhere, who is afraid of being happy, and who, because it is easier to bear, has gone back to sleep.  The wise man is a happy child."
-Arnaud Desjardins

"Music rots when it gets too far from the dance.  Poetry atrophies when it gets too far from the music."
-Ezra Pound

I am a huge Melvins fan so I have been to several shows. I think my favorite show with them (one of many) was when the opened for GWAR. 

The Jesus Lizard was always an amazing live show.

DEVO was also extremely memorable.

Pink Floyd was the show I had been waiting for my entire life and they did not disappoint.

Goldfrapp was a recent show I saw and that was awesome.

And last but far from least and probably my favorite band only second to the Melvins is Jucifer. They are constantly on tour and their live shows are an experience. A guitarist and drummer and a wall of speakers behind them. The sound can only be described as huge.

What a great subject. I've been going to shows for 30 years so there are a  
lot to choose from. 
 
The best ones, in no particular order: 
 
The Cure, Shoreline, Mountain View 1989
Dead Kennedys, Barrington Hall cafeteria, Berkeley 1979
Bruce Springsteen, Oakland Coliseum 1980
Santana, Old Waldorf nightclub, San Francisco 1977
The Nuns, Mabuhay Gardens, San Francisco 1977
U2, Civic Auditorium (Bill Graham), San Francisco 1983
The Clash, Civic Auditorium, San Francisco, 1982
Love and Rockets, Berkeley Community Theater  around 1989
Pink Floyd, Oakland Coliseum 1994
Ronnie Lane All-Stars Multiple Sclerosis benefit concert 1982   featuring 
Beck, Clapton, Page, many others
Nirvana: Bosnian Rape Victims Benefit, Cow Palace SF, 1993
the first Lollapalooza
and my best New Year's Eve ever: 
    opening act: Pearl Jam (brand new band) 
    then: Nirvana (the big new thing)
    headliner: Red Hot Chili Peppers (at their peak,  but Nirvana and Pearl 
Jam stole the show)
 
Those were some good times, for sure. 
 
The long version of the list includes .... (pulled off an old website I  made 
in 1999) 
...  
Nirvana, Pink Floyd, Love & Rockets, REM, Rolling Stones,  The Who, U2, 
Sisters of Mercy, Peter Murphy, Siouxsie and the Banshees, The  Cure, The 
Creatures, Cocteau Twins, Hot Tuna, Jefferson Airplane, Grateful Dead,  Spin Doctors, 
Spinal Tap, Bruce Springsteen, Nine Inch Nails, Stephen Bishop,  Cracker, Gin 
Blossoms, Jane's Addiction, Santana, Green Day, DBS, Pansy  Division, MDC, 
Beatnigs, Ubzub, Danzig, White Zombie, Ronnie Lane All-Stars,  Jackson Browne, 
Peter Frampton, the Eagles, Lynyrd Skynyrd, Greg Kihn, Tom  Petty, George 
Thorogood, Julian Lennon, Mick Taylor, Keith Richard, the Kinks,  James Brown, Red 
Hot Chili Peppers, L7, Breeders, Elastica, Duran Duran,  Smashing Pumpkins, 
Pearl Jam, Guns 'n Roses, the New Barbarians, FFI, Pete  Shelley, Chris Isaak, Art 
of Noise, Jeff Beck, Turbulence, Bad Religion,  Ramones, The Tubes, The Nuns, 
Blondie, Rockpile, Elvis Costello, The Church,  Marty Willson-Piper, Elton 
John, EMF, Eurythmics, Smithereens, Groovie Ghoulies,  Black Fork, Loudmouths, 
SVT, 311, Silverchair, Dash Rip Rock, Erasure, Howard  Jones, Jonathan Richman, 
Dinosaurs, Dinosaur Jr, ELO, and  more

-------------------------------1168416668--

Message-ID: <1685.67.160.220.219.1168432814.squirrel@secure.saturn5.com>
Date: Wed, 10 Jan 2007 04:40:14 -0800 (PST)
From: "Osby Oi Oi Jamz" <osby@viberation.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Reply-To: osby@viberation.com
User-Agent: SquirrelMail/1.4.8
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain;charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit
X-Priority: 3 (Normal)
Importance: Normal
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] HAIGHT STREET FAIR NEEDS YOUR HELP

So a lil' background info on HSF & the current situation we're dealing
with... Haight Street Fair has been going on now for the past 29 years...
Pablo Heising started this fair as a cummunity celebration in SF... as
time went on & years passed, the HSF has shaped up to be an event which
people, Globally, have attended & participate in every year! For a City
known for it's diversity, HSF has also been a landmark for the Culture &
celebration SF is known for!

I've been really lucky to be part of such a Dope organization! After being
part of San Fancisco Late Night Coalition for 4-5 years, I was so totally
honored when i became part of the Haight Street Fair organization. I've
been assistant stage manager now for the Groundscore/ Masonic Stage for
the past 2 years & Loving it! A few weeks ago, we had a meeting in the
Haight to discuss what was happening w/ the HSF & City Hall. Apparently,
there have been complaints from other organizations to City Hall & now
City Hall has the impression that all Hell breaks loose the day of HSF.

Now in SF, there are currently 5 HUGE annual day time events that happen:
Folsum Street Fair, How Weird Fair, Castro Street Fair, Love Fest
(formerly known as Love Parade), & Haight Street Fair. So compared to
those other day parties, those other community organizations are calling
us out & saying that our day party is out of control! LoL  !!! OK... so
let's see... there's two major gay/ alternative lifestyle fairs, 1 of them
focused on leather, which are known Globally and thousands of people
attend them year after year. Then there's another fair that involves
between 10-20 floats with DJs performing in a parade down Market Street
ending in Civic Center where 5000 people plus gather & dance all day. So
compared to all these events, City Hall & those other organizations
decided that HSF was too crazy for The City.

Unfortunately, Pablo passed away recently. One of the last things he said
during that last meeting was he wanted to be the ringleader for one more
fair, on a good round number, 30, before he officially singed off as the
head executive coordinator for HSF and passed down the golden keys. It's
really sad that he won't be able to do that. But Pablo had this dream. He
dreamed that we would be able to pass down this SF tradition so that
future generations will be able to enjoy the fair. I swear man, if you
heard the passion in his voice when he emphasized passing down the HSF to
future generations, you probably would of been as touched as i was! But
all hope is lost and we do have faith!! With a good team of HSF Board Of
Director & a community of support, it will happen!

Now here's where you come in. Because of this recent fight with City hall
& those other organizations, we need to prove that Haight Street Fair is
more than just another day party. There's strength in numbers &
signitures! Over the past few weeks, I know I've spoken to many of you
about this & Thank you for your support, but now I'm asking everyone to
PLEASE take some time to download, sign this petition, & mail it in! You
can find it here:

http://haightstreetfair.org/index.php

There's a huge meeting coming up in a few weeks at City Hall where the
future of HSF will be discussed. The organizations opposing HSF will be
present as well as a handfull of us who are fighting to keep it alive. By
you signing this petition & mailing it in shows that your pressence will
be at that meeting also. If you've ever been to the Haight Street Fair,
then you know how special it is. I mean, if SF can repesent various
countercultures in their own day celebrations, then we should be able to
have our celebration too! I mean serioulsy, like Haight Street is historic
for the artists, music, literary authors, and just the rich Culture SF is
known for! HSF is a reflection of that History. PLease help keep Pablo's
memory & the Haight Street Fair Alive!!!

Thank You!
_________________

-- 
Take Care <3
Peace=->Jus' Me =-> O§bY {8O)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR: What are the best *shows you've seen?


Jane's Addiction, May '91 pre-lollipalooza, in Sacto, outdoor arena (AMAZING)
Cure, '92, Rose Bowl
MDC & Victims Family @ Cotati Caberet '87 (two lines of stage diving, and 
only time I saw an entire venue used as a most pit, not standing tables and 
nowhere to hide - it ruled)
All FRONT 242 SHOWS
Lords of Acid, '97, Trocadero

Alan Ginsberg's last reading, Green Christmas ball '96 (died shortly after)

Lords of Acid & TKK @ Sextasy Ball, Warfield, '95
KMFDM @ Warfield Oct '95 and the going to Cyberfest 2 in Oakland right after
The 1st & 2nd Industi-raves by 21st Circuitry Records at the Trocadero.

For the Metalheads....

Death Angel, Blind Illusion, Skitzo, January 1987 @ The Omni - Death Angels 
release party for Ultraviolence
and...
Death Angel @ DNA '03 - getting to hear Ultra Violence live once again, 
every note, every inflection, sounding BETTER than ever.
Slick Idiot @ The Pound July '02 and hearing mark Durante playing the solo 
in Drug Against War, thinking i would NEVER get to hear that again after 
the band breakup of original KMFDM.
Judas Priest @ Oakland Colliseum '89 - Painkiller tour, with Megadeth and 
Testament.  \m/ \m/

There's more...  so many more

looking for my car keys and wallet.  But I couldn't find them.  Too many fr=
ee cocktails I guess.  At least I didn't have any shrapnel in my leg.=0A=0A=
Peace,=0A=0APeter=0A=0AMan's wallet returned after 62 yearsMEXICO, Mo. - Ra=
y Heilwagen has his wallet back, 62 years after he lost=0Ait in France duri=
ng World War II. Late last year, Heilwagen received a=0Acall from Stephen B=
reitenstein of Palatine, Ill.=0A=0A"He said, 'Did you lose a billfold?' and=
 I remembered I did,"=0AHeilwagen told the Hannibal Courier-Post. "Then he =
said, 'I found it=0Aand will send it to you.'=0A=0A"I could hardly believe =
it."=0A=0A=0A=0ABreitenstein's father, who also served in France during Wor=
ld War=0AII, recently died. Digging through his father's possessions =97=0A=
ironically on Veteran's Day =97 Stephen Breitenstein found the old=0Awallet=
. He figured his dad found it during the war and brought it home,=0Ahoping =
to find the owner. Not knowing how to do so, he left it in a=0Adrawer for m=
ore than six decades.=0A=0A=0A=0AUsing the Internet, Breitenstein tracked d=
own Heilwagen. After their phone conversation, he mailed the wallet to him.=
=0A=0A=0A=0A"He sent it to me, and I received it in very good order," Heilw=
agen=0Asaid. "It had everything in it =97 (French) francs and pictures and =
my=0Aoriginal =0A=0A=0A=0A=0A=0A=0A=0A=0A=0ASocial Security card and some r=
eceipts."=0A=0AThe wallet also included an article from the Courier-Post (H=
eilwagen=0Agrew up in Hannibal) that his parents had mailed to him during t=
he war.=0A=0A=0A=0AHeilwagen served with the Army's 79th Infantry Division =
of the U.S.=0AArmy, which was in combat in France from their arrival in Jul=
y 1944=0Auntil he was injured and hospitalized that November with a leg inj=
ury.=0AHe received a Purple Heart and a Bronze Star.=0A=0A=0A=0A"We were in=
 combat continuously, every day almost," he recalled. "We=0Awere in a battl=
e and received small arms fire, then a German mortar=0Acame in and exploded=
. It blew me into the river, and I had about five=0Apieces of shrapnel in m=
y right leg."=0A=0A=0A=0AAs medics helped him in the field, Heilwagen recal=
led pulling out=0Ahis billfold to look at pictures. The next day, he was ta=
ken to a=0AFrench hospital, where the shrapnel was removed.=0A=0A"They were=
 getting ready to ship me out to another hospital, and I=0Alooked for my bi=
llfold, and it was gone," said Heilwagen, who was later=0Adischarged and re=
turned to Missouri. He retired after a 39-year career=0Awith Southwestern B=
ell Telephone.=0A=0A=0A=0AAs for Breitenstein, "I was impressed that a stra=
nger would go to=0Asuch trouble to locate me and return my wallet," Heilwag=
en said.=0A=0A___=0A=0AInformation from the Hannibal Courier-Post http://ww=
w.hannibal.net/=0A=0A=0A=0Ahttp://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20070109/ap_on_fe_st/=
wallet_returned_2=0A=0A=0A=0A

OK, this list of shows will tell you just how damn old I really am.  Not re=
ally in any order:=0A=0A1. Bob Marley at Santa Cruz Civic during his last U=
S tour.  My girlfriend dumped me that week and the girl I took to the conce=
rt wasn't really into the whole smoke giant spliffs and dance till you can'=
t feel your legs thing.  But Marley's spiritual presence, ecstatic dancing,=
 and the herb carried the day.  I think this is the best single concert or =
musical event of any sort I have ever been to.=0A=0A2. Lynyrd Skynyrd at Da=
y on the Green.  The last tour before their plane crashed.  And we were up =
in front with a fifth of Jack.  Peter Frampton closed this show and he suck=
ed ass.=0A=0A3. Led Zeppelin at Day on the Green.  Their last US tour.  OK,=
 everyone says this concert sort of sucked but I was so excited to see them=
 and in truth I don't remember anything about the concert at all.  So it mu=
st have been good!=0A=0A4. Robin Trower and Grateful Dead at Winterland.  T=
hese were three different concerts, but back in the day almost any concert =
at Winterland was great.  What a great venue.  My favorite part was steppin=
g over the passed out people and junkies on the way to the bathroom.  Sweet=
!=0A=0A5. Oingo Boingo at the College V Cafeteria 1979.  This was the famou=
s College V/Porter Halloween bash.  I was dressed as a droog from Clockwork=
 Orange if I recall correctly.  =0A=0A6.  The Tubes at Bimbo's 365 and late=
r at the Berkeley Community Theater, The Bimbo's cncert was the very first =
concert I ever went to and they had their complete stage show.  Their prese=
ntation of the song "Don't Touch Me There" rocked my world.  The later Comm=
unity Theater concert defined my high school years.  =0A=0A7. Buddy Guy and=
 Junior Wells at some bar in Orange County. I drove almost two hours in the=
 pouring rain  from North Hollywood to see these guys and it was totally wo=
rth it.  Check out the record "Drinking TNT and Smoking Dynamite" where Cha=
rlie Watts and that other guy from the Stones back them up.  This is exactl=
y what they sounded like that night.  So friggin tight!=0A=0A8. The Marsali=
s brothers with Art Blakey at the Kumbwaa Jazz Center in SC.  They totally =
blew this tiny venue apart.  Wow.=0A=0A9. King Crimson at the Greek.  Twice=
.  Robert Fripp and Adrian Belew making strange guitar noises. My brain mak=
ing strange connections and correlations.=0A=0A10. Derrick May and Kevin Sa=
underson on 4 decks at "Red" during the Winter Music Conference.  Saunderso=
n came out and danced with the crowd between mixes.  Crazy funky techno.  I=
 discover the virtues of Red Bull and Vodka.=0A=0A=0A=0A=0A=0A

Yeah a few years back i saw them at DNA lounge, and there were only like 3
of them on stage, Groovy, Buzz and some dude with dreds on drums.  It looks
like groovy was using the mic stand to hold himself up and you know i think
it did look like he was lip synching.  Very disappointing.  Saw them a
couple years later open for Ministry.  Much better that time, not as great
as before but at least they had Levi and others on stage and he was actually
rocking out on stage and not just standing there.

Oh man i totally forgot to add GWAR to my list, that show kicked ass.  I was
stained blue for a week after that show, had to go into a job interview a
couple days later and my hair and finger nails were still a slight shade of
blue.

Saw Roger Waters at Shoreline too about 5 or 6 years ago.  That was an
awesome show, no pink floyd, but about as close as you can get these days.

On 1/9/07, Amber Leahey <princess_leahey@yahoo.com> wrote:
>
> I am a huge Melvins fan so I have been to several shows. I think my
> favorite show with them (one of many) was when the opened for GWAR.
>
> The Jesus Lizard was always an amazing live show.
>
> DEVO was also extremely memorable.
>
> Pink Floyd was the show I had been waiting for my entire life and they did
> not disappoint.
>
> Goldfrapp was a recent show I saw and that was awesome.
>
> And last but far from least and probably my favorite band only second to
> the Melvins is Jucifer. They are constantly on tour and their live shows are
> an experience. A guitarist and drummer and a wall of speakers behind them.
> The sound can only be described as huge.
>
>
>
> __________________________________________________

> http://mail.yahoo.com

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=UTF-8; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

as much shit as people give lynyrd skynyrd, they were a damn good band.

On 1/10/07, dangrsmind@yahoo.com <dangrsmind@yahoo.com> wrote:
>
> OK, this list of shows will tell you just how damn old I really am.  Not
> really in any order:
>
> 1. Bob Marley at Santa Cruz Civic during his last US tour.  My girlfriend
> dumped me that week and the girl I took to the concert wasn't really into
> the whole smoke giant spliffs and dance till you can't feel your legs
> thing.  But Marley's spiritual presence, ecstatic dancing, and the herb
> carried the day.  I think this is the best single concert or musical event
> of any sort I have ever been to.
>
> 2. Lynyrd Skynyrd at Day on the Green.  The last tour before their plane
> crashed.  And we were up in front with a fifth of Jack.  Peter Frampton
> closed this show and he sucked ass.
>
> 3. Led Zeppelin at Day on the Green.  Their last US tour.  OK, everyone
> says this concert sort of sucked but I was so excited to see them and in
> truth I don't remember anything about the concert at all.  So it must have
> been good!
>
> 4. Robin Trower and Grateful Dead at Winterland.  These were three
> different concerts, but back in the day almost any concert at Winterland was
> great.  What a great venue.  My favorite part was stepping over the passed
> out people and junkies on the way to the bathroom.  Sweet!
>
> 5. Oingo Boingo at the College V Cafeteria 1979.  This was the famous
> College V/Porter Halloween bash.  I was dressed as a droog from Clockwork
> Orange if I recall correctly.
>
> 6.  The Tubes at Bimbo's 365 and later at the Berkeley Community Theater,
> The Bimbo's cncert was the very first concert I ever went to and they had
> their complete stage show.  Their presentation of the song "Don't Touch Me
> There" rocked my world.  The later Community Theater concert defined my high
> school years.
>
> 7. Buddy Guy and Junior Wells at some bar in Orange County. I drove almost
> two hours in the pouring rain  from North Hollywood to see these guys and it
> was totally worth it.  Check out the record "Drinking TNT and Smoking
> Dynamite" where Charlie Watts and that other guy from the Stones back them
> up.  This is exactly what they sounded like that night.  So friggin tight!
>
> 8. The Marsalis brothers with Art Blakey at the Kumbwaa Jazz Center in
> SC.  They totally blew this tiny venue apart.  Wow.
>
> 9. King Crimson at the Greek.  Twice.  Robert Fripp and Adrian Belew
> making strange guitar noises. My brain making strange connections and
> correlations.
>
> 10. Derrick May and Kevin Saunderson on 4 decks at "Red" during the Winter
> Music Conference.  Saunderson came out and danced with the crowd between
> mixes.  Crazy funky techno.  I discover the virtues of Red Bull and Vodka.
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
> ---------------------------------------------------------------------
> To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
>
>


-- 
As they stirred Heaven and Earth, they combined to one,
and everything was everyone and each one was all.
As they stirred I heard a trumpet call,
and everything was everyone and each one was all.

i saw gwar, once, when i was 17...i still kick myself for not having seen
them since.

oh, also, clutch, at ziggys in winston salem, NC...was a 3 hour show, the
bar stayed open past last call and it was more a house party than a club
show. Best time i think i ever had in the late 90's.

--=====================_4441578==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"



Portrait of Dr. Albert Hofmann


Swiss Albert Hofmann is reputed to be one of the most important chemists of our times. He is the discoverer of LSD, which he considers, up to this very day, as both a "wonder drug" and a "problem child". In addition he did pioneering work as a researcher of other psychoactive substances as well as active agents of important medicinal plants and mushrooms. Under the spell of the mind-expanding potential of LSD the scientist turned increasingly into a philosopher of nature and a visionary critical of contemporary culture.

    On 11 January 1906 Albert Hofmann was born in the quiet small town of Baden, Switzerland, as the eldest one of four children. His father is a toolmaker in a factory where he meets Albert’s mother-to-be; when he falls seriously ill, Albert has to support the family. That’s why he makes a commercial apprenticeship. At the same time he swots up on Latin and other languages, since he wants to take his A-levels, which he succeeds in at a private school (paid for by a godfather).

CONTINUED:  http://www.lsd.info/symposium/ah-en



http://www.asambleapopulardeoaxaca.com/ 

MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo 

Tribenet:   <http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k>http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k 
                
House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"An adult is one who has lost the grace, the freshness, the innocence of the child, who is no longer capable of feeling pure joy, who makes everything complicated, who spreads suffering everywhere, who is afraid of being happy, and who, because it is easier to bear, has gone back to sleep.  The wise man is a happy child."
-Arnaud Desjardins

"Music rots when it gets too far from the dance.  Poetry atrophies when it gets too far from the music."
-Ezra Pound

>From: tbSMITH <iamgod@dementim.com>
>To: Chester Copperpot <chester.copperpot420@gmail.com>
>CC: CHUCK G <chuckg_421@yahoo.com>,The Twilight Laser Outpost 
><sfraves@hyperreal.org>
>Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR: What are the best *shows you've seen?
>Date: Tue, 09 Jan 2007 17:33:40 -0800
>
>Too many to really list...
>
>The ones I really remember was a string of about 5 tour stops I followed 
>Primus around during Pork Soda tour,
>Mr Bungle. Every time I see them. The 1999/2000 show at the Galleria with 
>Melvins and Fantomas. At midnight, when the whole place thought Y2K was 
>gonna destroy life as we knew it, at the drop of the balloons and confetti 
>they mr bungle comes out on stage and started their set to "what the world 
>needs now.... is love, sweet love". And goes immediately from that song to 
>some super heavy shit. Cathartic.
>Strapping Young Lad
>Pigface when they'd have like 25 people on stage at once.
>Idiot Flesh and now Sleepytime Gorilla Museum...
>Roni Size at the Maritime.
>Frontline Assembly at the Maritime.
>Einsturzende Neubauten.
>Tool, San Jose.
>Babyland whenever they'd play, sometimes in the desert. Thirteen years have 
>gone by and I still catch them when they come up to the Gilman.
>I never got really into seeing electronic acts live mostly because you'd 
>see this fantastic group on stage but in a concert environment and you'd 
>really want to dance your ass off but everyone else would be too dumb to 
>get into it. It just never felt the same as the way I'd imagine it in my 
>head.
>
>And what I am really certain of is that I'm going to go to Lamb of God, 
>Machine Head, and Gojira for my birthday in Santa Cruz in Feb. Hell yeah.
>
>-t
>
>

At 11:07 AM 1/10/2007, John G. wrote:
>raving has been around since the early 90's/late 80's in some parts...lets
>just admit most of us are getting old
>
>or are old :)

You bet.  And the older you get the longer the list.  For example I saw people like Janice Joplin and the Sex Pistols live.  Was at Woodstock I.

The most consistently wonderful shows/parties I've attended, tho,  were the Grateful Dead events.  

My life has been one long quest for ecstatic experience.  Getting out of the self and joining the one.  I've been lucky.  Blessed.  For I've had more of these opportunities than I deserve.  The Dead were a source of tribal reunion for decades for me and many others.  Genuine family, transcending age, race, social station  and beliefs, in search of the one and helping each other achieve it.  Like the Paradise Garage and raving though, unfortunately, raves and the Garage didn't last as long as one would have liked :-)

Apollo



<http://www.asambleapopulardeoaxaca.com/>http://www.asambleapopulardeoaxaca.com/ 

MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo 

Tribenet:   <http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k>http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k 
                
House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"An adult is one who has lost the grace, the freshness, the innocence of the child, who is no longer capable of feeling pure joy, who makes everything complicated, who spreads suffering everywhere, who is afraid of being happy, and who, because it is easier to bear, has gone back to sleep.  The wise man is a happy child."
-Arnaud Desjardins

"Music rots when it gets too far from the dance.  Poetry atrophies when it gets too far from the music."
-Ezra Pound  
--=====================_5527750==.ALT--

I was asked by the Melvins road manager to roadie for them in '99...I turned 
it down like an asshole. It's one of the few things I truly regret.

All because I was staying loyal to the band I was in at the time, who 
subsequently disbanded and stole a rack of my belongings about a month after 
I was asked.

Yay.



>From: Amber Leahey <princess_leahey@yahoo.com>
>To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR: What are the best *shows you've seen?
>Date: Tue, 9 Jan 2007 23:02:27 -0800 (PST)
>
>I am a huge Melvins fan so I have been to several shows. I think my 
>favorite show with them (one of many) was when the opened for GWAR.
>
>The Jesus Lizard was always an amazing live show.
>
>DEVO was also extremely memorable.
>
>Pink Floyd was the show I had been waiting for my entire life and they did 
>not disappoint.
>
>Goldfrapp was a recent show I saw and that was awesome.
>
>And last but far from least and probably my favorite band only second to 
>the Melvins is Jucifer. They are constantly on tour and their live shows 
>are an experience. A guitarist and drummer and a wall of speakers behind 
>them. The sound can only be described as huge.
>
>

>From: tbSMITH 
>To: Chester Copperpot 
>CC: CHUCK G ,The Twilight Laser Outpost 
>
>Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR: What are the best *shows you've seen?
>Date: Tue, 09 Jan 2007 17:33:40 -0800
>
>Too many to really list...
>
>The ones I really remember was a string of about 5 tour stops I followed 
>Primus around during Pork Soda tour,
>Mr Bungle. Every time I see them. The 1999/2000 show at the Galleria with 
>Melvins and Fantomas. At midnight, when the whole place thought Y2K was 
>gonna destroy life as we knew it, at the drop of the balloons and confetti 
>they mr bungle comes out on stage and started their set to "what the world 
>needs now.... is love, sweet love". And goes immediately from that song to 
>some super heavy shit. Cathartic.
>Strapping Young Lad
>Pigface when they'd have like 25 people on stage at once.
>Idiot Flesh and now Sleepytime Gorilla Museum...
>Roni Size at the Maritime.
>Frontline Assembly at the Maritime.
>Einsturzende Neubauten.
>Tool, San Jose.
>Babyland whenever they'd play, sometimes in the desert. Thirteen years have 
>gone by and I still catch them when they come up to the Gilman.
>I never got really into seeing electronic acts live mostly because you'd 
>see this fantastic group on stage but in a concert environment and you'd 
>really want to dance your ass off but everyone else would be too dumb to 
>get into it. It just never felt the same as the way I'd imagine it in my 
>head.
>
>And what I am really certain of is that I'm going to go to Lamb of God, 
>Machine Head, and Gojira for my birthday in Santa Cruz in Feb. Hell yeah.
>
>-t
>
>

>From: dangrsmind@yahoo.com
>To: Timothy Parris <timothy.parris@gmail.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.org

>OK, this list of shows will tell you just how damn old I really am.  Not 
>really in any order:
>
>1. Bob Marley at Santa Cruz Civic during his last US tour.  My girlfriend 
>dumped me that week and the girl I took to the concert wasn't really into 
>the whole smoke giant spliffs and dance till you can't feel your legs 
>thing.  But Marley's spiritual presence, ecstatic dancing, and the herb 
>carried the day.  I think this is the best single concert or musical event 
>of any sort I have ever been to.
>
>2. Lynyrd Skynyrd at Day on the Green.  The last tour before their plane 
>crashed.  And we were up in front with a fifth of Jack.  Peter Frampton 
>closed this show and he sucked ass.
>
>3. Led Zeppelin at Day on the Green.  Their last US tour.  OK, everyone 
>says this concert sort of sucked but I was so excited to see them and in 
>truth I don't remember anything about the concert at all.  So it must have 
>been good!
>
>4. Robin Trower and Grateful Dead at Winterland.  These were three 
>different concerts, but back in the day almost any concert at Winterland 
>was great.  What a great venue.  My favorite part was stepping over the 
>passed out people and junkies on the way to the bathroom.  Sweet!
>
>5. Oingo Boingo at the College V Cafeteria 1979.  This was the famous 
>College V/Porter Halloween bash.  I was dressed as a droog from Clockwork 
>Orange if I recall correctly.
>
>6.  The Tubes at Bimbo's 365 and later at the Berkeley Community Theater, 
>The Bimbo's cncert was the very first concert I ever went to and they had 
>their complete stage show.  Their presentation of the song "Don't Touch Me 
>There" rocked my world.  The later Community Theater concert defined my 
>high school years.
>
>7. Buddy Guy and Junior Wells at some bar in Orange County. I drove almost 
>two hours in the pouring rain  from North Hollywood to see these guys and 
>it was totally worth it.  Check out the record "Drinking TNT and Smoking 
>Dynamite" where Charlie Watts and that other guy from the Stones back them 
>up.  This is exactly what they sounded like that night.  So friggin tight!
>
>8. The Marsalis brothers with Art Blakey at the Kumbwaa Jazz Center in SC.  
>They totally blew this tiny venue apart.  Wow.
>
>9. King Crimson at the Greek.  Twice.  Robert Fripp and Adrian Belew making 
>strange guitar noises. My brain making strange connections and 
>correlations.
>
>10. Derrick May and Kevin Saunderson on 4 decks at "Red" during the Winter 
>Music Conference.  Saunderson came out and danced with the crowd between 
>mixes.  Crazy funky techno.  I discover the virtues of Red Bull and Vodka.
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>---------------------------------------------------------------------
>To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
>For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
>

know, that means i probably miss a lot of good stuff, but hey then i  
probably wouldn't have as much time to watch every episode of star  
trek 5 times over.  what the heck?  eh?

promoter actually came through with real "carnival & amusement rides" at 
a rave, and not an inflatable slide & buckin' bronco instead.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR: Coolest prop you've seen at a rave or any other show

------=_Part_32405_30443582.1168536616249
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

I remember at some fair or something that i went to when i was a kid in
Oregon they had an orbitron and the guy operating it was spinning some kid
around in it and he went to push on one of the rings to make it spin faster
and his hand slipped and got caught inbetween the inner and outer ring and
snapped it.  He yanked his arm out and ran off through the crowd screaming.

When i volunteered at the OMSI (oregon museum of science and industry) we
had an orbitron there.  That was always fun after hours just riding in that
thing for hours at a time.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR: Coolest prop you've seen at a rave or any other show

I remember my first ride on a Gravatron in the late 80's. Imagine
being 12 years old and walking into this dark closed spaceship looking
thing with loud speed metal (DRI?) playing inside and spinning up to
speed watching the teenagers smoking pot and making out in the middle.
Although I loved it, I thought the ride was pure evil and I was on my
way to hell. For sure I was once I got busted for walking on the walls
by some dude that knows why crank is called crank.

On 1/11/07, Chester Copperpot <chester.copperpot420@gmail.com> wrote:

The wise man is a happy child."
-Arnaud Desjardins

From sfraves-return-136811-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Thu Jan 11 22:18:47 2007

Received: (qmail 72855 invoked from network); 11 Jan 2007 22:18:47 -0000
From: TonyKrash@aol.com
Message-ID: <494.d7fc6cb.32d8107f@aol.com>
Date: Thu, 11 Jan 2007 17:13:19 EST
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="-----------------------------1168553599"
X-Mailer: 9.0 Security Edition for Windows sub 5352
X-Spam-Flag: NO
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] I wanna go raving in SanFran!

-------------------------------1168553599
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Hey, how are you doing?  My name's Tony  'Krash'.  I'm a 23 year old breaks 
DJ from New Orleans.  I've been  going to raves since late 98, going from a lot 
of the warehouse and skate park  parties to most of the 'Disco Donnie' State 
Palace parties. I've been  DJ'ing Lousiana and the Mississippi coast since 01 
for both club and  underground venues.  Those were good times.  The rave scene 
was  incredible for a while.  However, it seems that even the best venues  
and promoters down here have sizzled.  It's kind of sad,  actually.  I love this 
scene and the music and the people so  much!  There used to be a party pretty 
much every weekend.   Granted, I think hurricane Katrina had a big part to 
play in all of this, but I  still miss going to good shows.  All of the shows 
have been moved to the  club scene, which just defeats the purpose for me.  I 
see raving and  clubbing as two different entities.  The last big party I've 
been to was a  Caffeine show last summer, but from the looks of it, I don't think 
that venue is  viable anymore.   
    Ok, this hurricane thing has humbled me in many  ways, but I'm still 
looking for a good show.  I have a sister in San Fran  who has invited me to come 
down.  I've heard that there was a thriving  scene down there.  I would like 
to come visit up there and if I'm  incredibly lucky, I'd like to go to a nice 
show or an underground party.   Do you guys have any suggestions on any good 
shows or production  companies?  Have all of the raves moved to clubs like it 
has down  here?  Even the upcoming Mardi Gras 'Zoolu' party held down here in  
New Orleans is being moved to a club this year.  I feel that the rave scene  
may in fact be pretty close to dead down here, so my ambition is to maybe find a 
 scene someone else, like so many others have come down to New Orleans to do 
just  that in the past.  
    How is the scene in SF?  Is there any party  that I can't or shouldn't 
miss?  How's the underground?  Any  feedback would be awesome!  Much love, -Tony 
  

-------------------------------1168553599--

Mime-Version: 1.0 (Apple Message framework v752.2)

Message-Id: <A1E49560-4B9C-418B-948E-0C5B6EA39430@deepfog.com>

X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.752.2)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) Robert Anton Wilson dies

As many of you know from previous quotes of the day, Bob Wilson is  
one of my all time favorite authors.  I've always appreciated his  
witty sense of humor and if you ever want a good run down on what was  
going on in this country in the late 60's to the early 80's his  
Cosmic Trigger books are a good source.  I went to his blog site  
today, which now I'm sort of sorry I didn't go to more often, and I  
decided to post his final 2 entries, the January 6th entry really  
made me cry for a minute, ironic because he was making a funny.   
Anyway, I encourage you to visit his blog and read up.

http://robertantonwilson.blogspot.com/

THURSDAY, JANUARY 11, 2007
RAW Essence

Robert Anton Wilson Defies Medical Experts and leaves his body @4:50  
AM on binary date 01/11.


All Hail Eris!

On behalf of his children and those who cared for him, deepest love  
and gratitude for the tremendous support and lovingness bestowed upon  
us.

(that's it from Bob's bedside at his fnord by the sea)

RAW Memorial February 07
date to be announced


Posted by Robert Anton Wilson 261 comments


SATURDAY, JANUARY 6, 2007
Do Not Go Gently Into That Good Night

Various medical authorities swarm in and out of here predicting I  
have between two days and two months to live. I think they are  
guessing. I remain cheerful and unimpressed. I look forward without  
dogmatic optimism but without dread. I love you all and I deeply  
implore you to keep the lasagna flying.

Please pardon my levity, I don't see how to take death seriously. It  
seems absurd.

RAW

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

> looking for a good show.  I have a sister in San Fran  who has invited me to come
> down.  I've heard that there was a thriving  scene down there.  I would like
> to come visit up there and if I'm  incredibly lucky, I'd like to go to a nice
> show or an underground party.   Do you guys have any suggestions on any good
> shows or production  companies?  Have all of the raves moved to clubs like it
> has down  here?  Even the upcoming Mardi Gras 'Zoolu' party held down here in
> New Orleans is being moved to a club this year.  I feel that the rave scene
> may in fact be pretty close to dead down here, so my ambition is to maybe find a
>  scene someone else, like so many others have come down to New Orleans to do
> just  that in the past.
>     How is the scene in SF?  Is there any party  that I can't or shouldn't
> miss?  How's the underground?  Any  feedback would be awesome!  Much love, -Tony
>
>
>


--

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: DIRTY w/ Future Funk Squad, Fine Cut Bodies, Lobudg, Ambient Mafia - Jan. 20th

Evil Breaks presents:
DIRTY
January 20th, 2007
Fat City (old Studio Z space) - 314 11th St @ Folsom
presales: limited $10/then $15 - available soon
door: $15 b4 11pm/$20 after
10pm - 4am
21+


I don't think this lineup really needs much introduction. 4 world
class headliners, a great huge space with 2 rooms, 1 of which is
hosted by the amazing Ambient Mafia, and Viberations doing the visuals
for us once again. Viberation has done visuals for us quite a few
times for us in the past and was responsible for our room @ Love
Infusion as well as the last show we did @ Studio Z with Uberzone Live
& Carbon Community Live. You know we'll have the place decked out
propa with lighting, visuals, and sound. And the Ambient Mafia will
have there room made to relax with tons of their own decorations,
lighting, and visuals. We might even have a nice little table set up
with some snacks and fruit for all of you.



Future Funk Squad UK
(Distinctive/Default/En:Vision/Re:Connect/777/Kilowatt/Botchit/Against
the Grain/Sinister/Moving Target/Chi.........)



Fine Cut Bodies Budapest, Hungary
(Chi Recordings/Ritmic/Moving Target)



LoBudg (SOTEG & Carbon Community) Texas
(Bless Records/Sober Music/Play Recordings)


Aaron Jae (Evil Breaks/XM/Space Cowboys)
Bam (Evil Breaks/Invibe)
M.O.D. (Evil Breaks)
Athena (Evil Breaks)


Ambient Mafia room:

Redstickman w/Origami on bass
Seventh Swami
We Are Not Pandas
Mo Corleone
Boomerang Fidget + Actual Rafiq
Shane
4Matt


Visuals by: Viberation


The limited $10 presales will be made available to members of the Evil
Breaks mailing list before being made public, so if you're not a
member, please sign up at www.evilbreaks.com.
