Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR: Coolest prop you've seen at a rave or any other show

Heh... that was the first and last time *I* ever tried going to a  
cyberfest, myself; and the only time I've ever wasted money on tix to  
anything coolworld.  I've never believed another word to spew forth  
from anyone or anything coolworld-related, since.  And it even turned  
me off to the very idea of massives for a long time; until someone  
finally convinced me that, for all the crap they get on SFRaves, what  
Skills puts on their flyers if the truth.

I just wish I hadn't been so new to the city and the scene at the  
time (I'd yet even to subscribe to SFRaves...), so I'd have known  
someone more clued in than me to warn me off about the coolworld  
peoples' lying and shady nature.  I'd have started going to Skills  
parties sooner.

(Make fun of me if you want.  I do actually have a soft spot for  
cheezy trance massives once in a while.)


cya,
john

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Mighty, next Friday

>From Murph:

Some unfortunate news just came in from London today. It turns out
that the Christmas and New Year holidays have postponed the processing
of the Drumattic Twins visas by 2 weeks so that it won't be ready
until January 26th. As a result, they will be unable to play with us
at Mighty on the 19th.

We were really looking forward to having the Twins here for their SF
debut and are actively working to re-schedule them for later in the
year.

While we are bummed that they can't make it this month, the event is
still cause for celebration as it is the 2 year Anniversary for Mighty
Breaks. Mighty Breaks has established itself at the core of the SF
breaks scene and we will be celebrating with all the crews that have
helped to build the scene.

Line Up: Murphstar, Mancub, Melyss, Aaron Pope, Aaron Jae, Syd Gris,
J9, Shissla, Lud Dub, Antonio, MoPo and Mike Giannini

We are dropping the pre-sale price to $5 and the door price to $10.
The Drumattics are putting together a custom hour long mix CD for
exclusively for us that we will hand out to the first 100 people
through the door at Mighty Breaks.

Please spread the word about the change in line up, the reduced price
and the limited CD's for the first 100 people through the door.

Also, Any DJ who has ever played a Mighty Breaks gets in FREE before Midnight!

Pre-Sales are available here.
http://tinyurl.com/y6fad7

I am sorry for all of you who were eager to see the Twins, but fear
not as we are locking in a date over the next few months. We will make
it up to you and then some.

Hope to see you all out on the 19th!




On 1/11/07, Philip.X.Diaz <st_indigo@earthlink.net> wrote:
> anyone down for Drumattic Twins @ Mighty?

Subject: [sfraves] KZSU radio informational meeting

If you ever had an urge to get involved in radio, your chance is coming 
up soon.  Tues. the 16th to be specific.  That's because we're having 
our quarterly informational meeting for KZSU.  So if you want to train 
to be a DJ, or sportscaster, or newscaster, or talk show host, or if you 
want to work in promotions, publicity, public affairs, etc., now's the 
time.

You don't have to be a stanford student to get involved even.

The meeting is Tues, as I mentioned, at 7 pm in Memorial Hall, Room 125.

Web flyer is here:
http://tinyurl.com/yy92sb



http://www.jcthedj.com/Support.JC.php
http://kzsu.stanford.edu/~dougm/Reinvent.Your.World.php
AIM: jckzsu (or kzsudj during my show.)

revolutionary act."

KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

> From Murph:
>
> Some unfortunate news just came in from London today. It turns out
> that the Christmas and New Year holidays have postponed the processing
> of the Drumattic Twins visas by 2 weeks so that it won't be ready
> until January 26th. As a result, they will be unable to play with us
> at Mighty on the 19th.
>
> We were really looking forward to having the Twins here for their SF
> debut and are actively working to re-schedule them for later in the
> year.
>
> While we are bummed that they can't make it this month, the event is
> still cause for celebration as it is the 2 year Anniversary for Mighty
> Breaks. Mighty Breaks has established itself at the core of the SF
> breaks scene and we will be celebrating with all the crews that have
> helped to build the scene.
>
> Line Up: Murphstar, Mancub, Melyss, Aaron Pope, Aaron Jae, Syd Gris,
> J9, Shissla, Lud Dub, Antonio, MoPo and Mike Giannini
>
> We are dropping the pre-sale price to $5 and the door price to $10.
> The Drumattics are putting together a custom hour long mix CD for
> exclusively for us that we will hand out to the first 100 people
> through the door at Mighty Breaks.
>
> Please spread the word about the change in line up, the reduced price
> and the limited CD's for the first 100 people through the door.
>
> Also, Any DJ who has ever played a Mighty Breaks gets in FREE  
> before Midnight!
>
> Pre-Sales are available here.
> http://tinyurl.com/y6fad7
>
> I am sorry for all of you who were eager to see the Twins, but fear
> not as we are locking in a date over the next few months. We will make
> it up to you and then some.
>
> Hope to see you all out on the 19th!
>
>

Found the following info on Groovetickets when I was getting my tix for
Dirty

hope it helps


http://groovetickets.com/ordersystem/Groove/eventviewqb.asp?AffilID=93&EventsID=25361&PGname=Till+Dawn

*Talent:* Area 1: House/Trance/Tekno // HIPNOTIC STARR (NM) VS. MICHAEL LIU
(SF) , THROW3R (NM) First Nor Cal Appearance, TEAGUE (WA), DYLOOT (SF),
FELIPE AVELAR (Fresno), RossFM (SF), NASHER (Modesto), ZIPPY (Ripon), DJ
LIQUID (Manteca), OCHOA BROTHERS (Stockton) AREA 2:
D&B-Jungle-BreakBeats/HardCore-Happy HardCore // MONK of Rabbit In the Moon
(FL), MILO (Canada) First CA Appearance, COMPANY TRUCK (SF), Hi-C (SF),
CHRIStheJUNGLIST (SF), CRAZY C (Modesto), JAYSUN (Stockton), TONE DUB
(Stockton), D'N'C DJ (LA), + More TBA

*Info:* iSPIN will be located in Modesto,CA at a Secure Venue with capacity
of 1,200. All Responsible Ages Welcome, 7pm - 4am. There will be food and
drink concessions, Vendors and Till Dawn will be giving away FREE Candy All
Night. iSPIN will have Beautiful Go Go Girls, 50,000 WATTS of Sound by SPL
and Awesome Laser & Lighting set-ups in Both Areas by Stim-U-Lights. Also
bee sure not to miss the custom live visual mayhem by Hallucination On Film
during DJ Monks Set!

ctronic dance music, a cold-blooded cadre mostly from northern Europe"  who=

revolutionised people's clothing, drinking, drug-taking and socialising hab=
its beyond recognition" was "battling for survival."=0A=0Ahttp://arts.guard=
ian.co.uk/news/story/0,,1026308,00.html=0A=0AAnd then of course, some other=
 writers think that superstar DJs are on the rise as they begin moving into=

p://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/entertainment/music-gigs/article2124757.ece=
=0A=0APersonally I've always found the superstar DJ racket highly annoying =
and sort of weird.  After all you are just playing some records.  So I say =
good ridance to the "superstar" DJs and hello to DJs that know how to and a=
re interested in keeping the party rocking.  After all, that's the entire p=
oint of the exercise isn't it?  Of course the people that really know how t=
o do this day in and day out are superstars in my book.  And some of them m=
ight even be superstar DJs or from northern Europe.=0A=0ASo maybe the DJ di=
nosaurs aren't quite extinct at least not as long as the bass keeps thumpin=
g and people keep dancing.=0A=0APeace,=0A=0APeter

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] BSP: New mix to download

Meant to get this out last night, but fell asleep while the file was in 
process of uploading.

So, I was at the Open Mind sale snatching up vinyl last night (Wed.) and 
I ended up bringing the loot to the station today (thur.)  As can be the 
case, there was a fairly wide mixture of styles.  So I ended up 
arranging things into sub genre groups and decided to press record and 
start mixing.  What came out was an interesting mix covering house, 
electro, breaks, progressive, techno, acid, and a spattering of trance 
sub genres.  And other than trimming the empty space from the beginning 
and the end of the recording, no further processing has been done.

Check it out for yourself here:
http://www.mediafire.com/?andujjjd1ni

And leave me your thoughts on it if you feel inclined.

Thanks, and enjoy!



http://www.jcthedj.com/Support.JC.php
http://kzsu.stanford.edu/~dougm/Reinvent.Your.World.php
AIM: jckzsu (or kzsudj during my show.)

"In a World of universal deceit, telling the truth is a
revolutionary act."

-- 
"Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily represent those of
KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

On Jan 12, 2007, at 5:51 PM, dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:

> Officially, 2006 was the year the "superstar DJ" died.  That's  
> right, according to Jean Carey (who?) no one cares anymore about  
> the "the giants of electronic dance music, a cold-blooded cadre  
> mostly from northern Europe"  who "Suddenly, in 2006, like  
> dinosaurs shuddering in the freezing contrail of a passing comet"  
> became extinct.
>
> http://www.ocweekly.com/features/year-in-review/the-year-the- 
> superstar-dj-died/26472/
>
>
> Or maybe not.  Judge Jules doesn't agree and Pacha's Danny Whittle   
> thinks its "bullshit"
>
> http://www.inthemix.com.au/news/intl/30273/ 
> Superstar_DJs_facing_extinction
>
> Lets also remember that back in 2003, "dance music, the genre that  
> revolutionised people's clothing, drinking, drug-taking and  
> socialising habits beyond recognition" was "battling for survival."
>
> http://arts.guardian.co.uk/news/story/0,,1026308,00.html
>
> And then of course, some other writers think that superstar DJs are  
> on the rise as they begin moving into new areas such as movie  
> scores, Hollywood film productions, etc.
>
> http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/entertainment/music-gigs/ 
> article2124757.ece
>
> Personally I've always found the superstar DJ racket highly  
> annoying and sort of weird.  After all you are just playing some  
> records.  So I say good ridance to the "superstar" DJs and hello to  
> DJs that know how to and are interested in keeping the party  
> rocking.  After all, that's the entire point of the exercise isn't  
> it?  Of course the people that really know how to do this day in  
> and day out are superstars in my book.  And some of them might even  
> be superstar DJs or from northern Europe.
>
> So maybe the DJ dinosaurs aren't quite extinct at least not as long  
> as the bass keeps thumping and people keep dancing.
>
> Peace,
>
> Peter

> As many of you know from previous quotes of the day, Bob Wilson is

> decided to post his final 2 entries, the January 6th entry really  
> made me cry for a minute, ironic because he was making a funny.   
> Anyway, I encourage you to visit his blog and read up.
>
> http://robertantonwilson.blogspot.com/
>
> THURSDAY, JANUARY 11, 2007
> RAW Essence
>
> Robert Anton Wilson Defies Medical Experts and leaves his body @4:50  
> AM on binary date 01/11.
>
>
> All Hail Eris!
>
> On behalf of his children and those who cared for him, deepest love  
> and gratitude for the tremendous support and lovingness bestowed upon  
> us.
>
> (that's it from Bob's bedside at his fnord by the sea)
>
> RAW Memorial February 07
> date to be announced
>
>
> Posted by Robert Anton Wilson 261 comments
>
>
> SATURDAY, JANUARY 6, 2007
> Do Not Go Gently Into That Good Night
>
> Various medical authorities swarm in and out of here predicting I  
> have between two days and two months to live. I think they are  
> guessing. I remain cheerful and unimpressed. I look forward without  
> dogmatic optimism but without dread. I love you all and I deeply  
> implore you to keep the lasagna flying.
>
> Please pardon my levity, I don't see how to take death seriously. It  
> seems absurd.
>
> RAW
>

> breaks scene and we will be celebrating with all the crews that have
> helped to build the scene.

> J9, Shissla, Lud Dub, Antonio, MoPo and Mike Giannini

> The Drumattics are putting together a custom hour long mix CD for
> exclusively for us that we will hand out to the first 100 people
> through the door at Mighty Breaks.
>
> Please spread the word about the change in line up, the reduced price
> and the limited CD's for the first 100 people through the door.
>
> Also, Any DJ who has ever played a Mighty Breaks gets in FREE before Midnight!
>
> Pre-Sales are available here.
> http://tinyurl.com/y6fad7
>
> I am sorry for all of you who were eager to see the Twins, but fear
> not as we are locking in a date over the next few months. We will make
> it up to you and then some.
>
> Hope to see you all out on the 19th!

Paid sub so I posted the entire article.


The Twilight Years of Cap'n Crunch
Silicon Valley legend John Draper made his name with brains and  
pranks, before slipping to the margins
Three jail stints and the 'rave' scene
By CHRIS RHOADS
January 13, 2007; Page A1

MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. -- Underneath a highway bisecting this Silicon  
Valley town, home to Google Inc. and other tech giants, John Draper  
crammed his bulky frame through the door of a friend's home: a  
battered 1978 Chevy diesel bus.

Radio parts, a wrench set, arthritis medication and a book on  
robotics cluttered the dashboard. A padded bench for sleeping and a  
greasy stove filled the back.

"What do you want for lunch?" asked Dave Bengel, a self-taught engineer.

"Salmon," responded Mr. Draper, 63, who has few teeth and wears the  
same clothes for days. He is better known in Silicon Valley as "Cap'n  
Crunch," a legendary figure who 25 years ago epitomized the  
freewheeling, prank-filled culture that gave birth to high tech.

"Salmon, all right!" cried Mr. Bengel. He set about preparing the  
meal -- obtained free from a Whole Foods worker who leaves outdated  
products near a dumpster at a prearranged time.

In the decades since Mr. Draper gained fame for his hacking skills as  
a "phone phreak" -- he once claimed to have gotten then-President  
Nixon on the phone -- Silicon Valley has aged and matured. Pioneers  
that Mr. Draper worked with, such as Apple's Steve Jobs, have gone on  
to become wealthy members of the business establishment.

THEN THERE is "Cap'n Crunch," part of an aging community of high-tech  
wunderkinds. Once tolerated, even embraced, for his eccentricities,  
Mr. Draper now lives on the margins of this affluent world, still  
striving to carve out a role in the business mainstream.

Although his appearance and hand-to-mouth existence belie it, Mr.  
Draper developed one of the first word-processing programs as well as  
the technology that made possible voice-activated telephone menus. He  
receives invitations to speak to foreign governments and  
international conferences. At a recent celebration of Apple Inc.'s  
30th anniversary, Mr. Draper, sporting a straggly beard, stood to  
contribute a story, causing the room to break into applause.

Mr. Draper spent three stints in jail in the 1970s for tampering with  
the phone system. A court-appointed psychiatrist once found him to be  
"psychotic," although another found nothing wrong with him. Until a  
fall at a conference in Istanbul aggravated a back injury, Mr. Draper  
was a regular in the rave scene, where people gather in remote  
locations and dance through the night to electronic music. Mr. Draper  
once did $10,000 worth of Web-site design and other computer work for  
a Bay-area therapist in return for physical therapy on his back  
because he lacks health insurance.

"When I first met him, he was toothless, wearing ripped jeans and  
looked like a hippie," says Tolga Katas, a music producer and  
computer programmer in Las Vegas who recently hired Mr. Draper to do  
technical work for his new Web entertainment company. "Then I learned  
what he has done and was blown away."

Mr. Draper calls aging veterans like himself part of an "off-the- 
grid" community. Steve Inness, 47, helped develop touch-screen  
cellphone technology and does programming work for startups. In  
recent years, he's lived on the floors and couches of employers; he  
was last seen hitchhiking in the desert outside Las Vegas. Roy  
Kaylor, 68, built one of the first electric cars in the early 1970s  
and contributed to a government-supported effort to develop the  
technology. He lives in a trailer without electricity in the Santa  
Cruz mountains. Mr. Draper's recent lunch host, Mr. Bengel, 61,  
designed an electrohydraulic machine tool and says he has worked for  
several Silicon Valley companies.

Mr. Draper is the best known. "He was the king of the nerds," says  
Allan Lundell, who runs an independent film company and has  
chronicled the evolution of Silicon Valley.

Mr. Draper's father was a U.S. Air Force engineer and the family  
moved frequently. His younger brother, Ron, recalls John rummaging  
for electronic parts on military bases where the family lived, on one  
occasion building a radio station in his bedroom.

John was not an easy child, often bucking under the authority of his  
sometimes-distant father, who is now deceased. John threw tantrums  
when his parents smoked, says Ron, a piano teacher. Mr. Draper says  
he hated his parents' smoking and felt aggrieved by their refusal to  
stop.

"Our father didn't understand what John needed, which was a constant  
supply of education and resources," says Ron. "He absorbed this stuff  
like a sponge." Ron Draper says his parents briefly sought  
psychiatric treatment for his brother when he was a child for what  
they said was a "chemical imbalance.

"I liked the sessions," says Mr. Draper of the psychiatric  
counseling. "At least someone was listening to me." He acknowledges  
he can become obsessive but denies the idea there's anything wrong  
with him.

In 1964, after taking some college courses, Mr. Draper joined the Air  
Force, which his parents thought would provide much-needed  
discipline. He was sent to Alaska and later Maine, where he served as  
a radar technician. Since the soldiers had only one phone line on  
which to call home, Mr. Draper began tinkering with the access codes  
and figured out how to make free calls through the local switchboard.

After an honorable discharge in 1968, he built gear for several  
companies in the San Francisco Bay area. But his work, much of which  
was military-related, was out of step with the counterculture  
blooming around him. Mr. Draper grew his hair and began spending more  
time on a pirate radio station, which he operated from the back of  
his green Volkswagen van to make it harder for authorities to track  
the signal. He also turned his attention to the phone system, an  
attraction for like-minded techies before the arrival of personal  
computers.

Mr. Draper learned how to make free calls by imitating the tones used  
by the phone company. He learned from other "phone phreaks" -- as the  
hackers called themselves -- including blind teenagers with near- 
perfect pitch. Mr. Draper learned that a toy whistle found in a  
cereal box would also imitate the required tones, earning him the  
nickname Cap'n Crunch.

The point was not just to make free calls but to explore and learn  
from the phone company's rich and complicated system. On one  
occasion, Mr. Draper says he learned the code word needed to speak  
with the president -- "Olympus" -- and got through to someone on a  
secure line he thought was President Nixon. Mr. Draper says he told  
the man about a toilet-paper shortage in Los Angeles.

Authorities began to take notice, particularly after a lengthy  
article on phone phreaking appeared in the October 1971 edition of  
Esquire magazine. Mr. Draper, the group's ringleader, was arrested  
for the first time several months later on charges of wire fraud, and  
received a five-year probation.

The Esquire article also caught the attention of Steve Wozniak, an  
eventual Apple co-founder, who invited Mr. Draper to his dorm room at  
the University of California at Berkeley. When Mr. Draper appeared  
that evening, Mr. Wozniak, then 21, was taken aback by his guest's  
appearance and odor, Mr. Wozniak wrote in his recent autobiography.

"Are you Cap'n Crunch?" Mr. Wozniak asked in disbelief, according to  
the book.

"I am he," Mr. Draper responded as he strode into the room.

Mr. Draper showed Mr. Wozniak and a friend, Mr. Jobs, how to build a  
device that could produce telephone tones. The pair turned the  
knowledge into a small business on the Berkeley campus, their first  
collaboration before founding Apple a few years later.

Mr. Wozniak employed Mr. Draper at Apple, where as a contractor in  
1977 he designed a device that could immediately identify phone  
signals and lines -- such as ones that made free calls -- something  
modems were not able to do for a decade. The technology would later  
be used for tone-activated calling menus, voice mail and other purposes.

APPLE DROPPED the device, called a phone board, anxious to avoid  
negative publicity from its association with illegal phoning,  
according to former Apple employees. "It was a great board and others  
at Apple didn't recognize that," says Mr. Wozniak. Mr. Draper became  
closer to Mr. Wozniak than to Mr. Jobs, who sometimes felt  
uncomfortable around Mr. Draper, former Apple employees recall.

"John was a little strange and Jobs felt better staying away from  
him," says Mr. Wozniak, who has remained in touch with Mr. Draper  
over the years. Mr. Jobs in an email declines to comment.

Just as the computer revolution was about to begin, Mr. Draper's  
legal problems steered him away from the action. He was sentenced to  
prison for phone fraud in 1976 and again in 1978, and says he was  
attacked during that second stint by an inmate with a baseball bat,  
permanently damaging his back.

The next year -- after his third bust for phone fraud -- he was  
berated for his behavior. "You have to pay for your long-distance  
phone calls," a San Jose U.S. District Court judge told Mr. Draper at  
his sentencing, according to an account in the San Francisco  
Chronicle. "Is that a very difficult moral concept to grasp?"

Mr. Draper's lawyer replied: "His entire reality has to do with the  
technology of computers and telephones. When he gets involved with  
the technology aspect, he loses all sense of morality."

TWO COURT-APPOINTED psychiatrists examined Mr. Draper. One concluded  
he had an "underdeveloped sense of people" and was "psychotic"; the  
other found nothing wrong with him, according to the Chronicle article.

In 1979, while serving a sentence of a year of nights in the Alameda  
County jail -- it was later reduced to a few months -- Mr. Draper  
wrote the EasyWriter word-processing program. At night he wrote code  
in longhand, diligently preparing for the next day when he could  
spend time in the offices of a software company he founded with friends.

Mr. Draper received permission from the sheriff's office to attend a  
computer fair in 1979 in San Francisco, where the program, named  
after the cult film "Easy Rider," was a hit. It became Apple's first  
word-processing program. When IBM launched its first PC, it also  
chose EasyWriter, over competition from other programmers, including  
a young Bill Gates.

Mr. Draper bought a Mercedes and a home in Hawaii. But the company he  
founded, Cap'n Software Inc., earned less than $1 million in revenue  
over a six-year period, according to Mr. Draper and Matthew McIntosh,  
who ran operations. The real winner was Bill Baker, who handled  
EasyWriter's distribution and marketing through his own company.  
Without Mr. Draper's knowledge, Mr. Baker hired his own programmers  
to create EasyWriter II just as Cap'n Software was publishing  
EasyWriter 1.1.

Cap'n Software sued and the matter was settled in court with Mr.  
Baker paying the pair an undisclosed amount. Mr. Baker, now an  
Internet entrepreneur in Corona del Mar, Calif., says his version of  
EasyWriter was for the higher-end corporate market and didn't  
conflict with Mr. Draper's, although he acknowledges the possibility  
for confusion.

Mr. Baker says he helped Mr. Draper get a start in business. "There  
are people who see themselves as victims no matter how much money or  
how many opportunities you give them," says Mr. Baker, who sold his  
distribution company in 1983 for $10 million.

Mr. Draper worked for several years in the late 1980s for Autodesk  
Inc., a San Rafael, Calif., company that makes design software. He  
was laid off along with others when new management arrived. It would  
be his last corporate job.

Through the 1990s, the story was the same. Mr. Draper was qualified  
for any number of openings, but some companies didn't want to hire  
someone with a criminal record while others remained wary of his  
eccentricities. Promising opportunities with Apple and NASA came and  
went, he says.

As Silicon Valley was taking flight again, this time with the  
Internet boom, Mr. Draper turned to the rave scene. He traveled as  
far as Australia and India, where he got by for months at a time  
earning money designing Web sites and writing computer code.

Mr. Draper several years ago developed some Internet-security  
equipment and started a company. Some clients were interested, but  
the company foundered when one of its executives, a fellow raver,  
made off with much of the money from investors, say Mr. Draper and  
another executive, John Johnson.

Mr. Johnson is still trying to make a go of the product, with Mr.  
Draper's help. Mr. Johnson's dilemma is whether to use Mr. Draper's  
name -- or hide it. "Some companies say we don't want any contact  
with that guy," says Mr. Johnson, who says he's in advanced  
discussions with the U.S. Department of Defense about the product.  
The Pentagon declines to comment.

Mr. Katas, who recently hired Mr. Draper to work for his online  
entertainment company, en2go.com, recently arranged to have Mr.  
Draper meet a software executive in Beverly Hills as a possible  
source for more work. Before the meeting, Mr. Katas emailed the  
executive about the "legendary John Draper," listing his achievements.

Mr. Draper, who was included in the email, replied to the executive  
and Mr. Katas that he had no money for parking and doubted that his  
car would make the trip across town.

"John just doesn't understand that if he seems unsuccessful, then  
successful people won't understand how talented he really is," says  
Christine Marie. Ms. Marie does promotional work for Mr. Katas and  
helps Mr. Draper organize his business life, handling invitations to  
speak at conferences and an online TV show he produces that deals  
with Internet security. She also occasionally cleans up his apartment  
and washes his clothes.

Mr. Draper's friends from the EasyWriter days worry that time is  
running out. Work is getting harder to find now that tech companies  
are outsourcing programming work to inexpensive labor markets overseas.

Contemporaries who've gone on to riches and fame say they've tried to  
help Mr. Draper over the years. Mr. Wozniak, who now invests in high- 
tech companies and is involved in computer education in schools,  
recently gave Mr. Draper a new Apple Powerbook computer. He has also  
helped out with Mr. Draper's legal bills.

Mr. Wozniak says Mr. Draper's problem is that his skills lie in  
technology rather in making business deals or starting a company. "He  
didn't come from a business orientation," says Mr. Wozniak.

Mr. Draper's unusual behavior, such as shouting at anyone smoking  
anywhere near him, could wear on fellow workers and employers. "He  
was not a self-starter, or associated with all the companies  
springing up back then," says Mr. Wozniak. "But, actually, John is  
one of the happiest guys I know, no matter what his situation seems."

ON A RECENT MORNING at a Bob's Big Boy restaurant in Burbank, Calif.,  
where he goes when he has enough money, Mr. Draper ordered his usual  
breakfast: eggs and bacon first, to be followed five to seven minutes  
later by grilled pancakes loaded with butter and syrup.

The first course arrived. "The bacon's too greasy, I can't accept  
these," he shouted at the waiter. Mr. Draper sends back his bacon  
about 70% of the time. He says that since he has no opposing teeth,  
the bacon needs to be crisp enough to break off in his mouth. He lost  
most of his teeth from infrequent dental care, which he blames on his  
lack of health insurance.

After breakfast, Mr. Draper returned to his one-room apartment beside  
a four-lane expressway. The apartment was in squalor, with open  
cereal boxes, clothes in trash bags, computers and old newspapers  
strewn about. Mr. Draper left an angry voice message for a client who  
hadn't paid for some programming work. He fretted that without the  
money he would have difficulty covering his electricity bill that month.

"I'm blacklisted, man, a permanent menace to society, I guess," he  
said. "It's too bad because there are some things I think I could  
contribute."

"No sage or savior has ever endorsed greed and gluttony as a path  
toward social justice or personal fulfillment.  These sane and  
enlightened people come to us from all cultures and all eras,  
sometimes knowing of each other but more often not.  Socrates and  
Jesus, Lao Tzu and Tolstoi, Gandhi and Martin Buber -- no one can  
find in their lives and words a jot of support for a political and  
economic regime that encourages the acquisition of wealth far beyond  
what is needed for the necessaries -- or even the restorative  
pleasures -- of life while consigning the masses to live and work in  
squalor."
-Stephen J. Fortunato, Associate Justice, Rhode Island Supreme Court.

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of  
the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will  
gradually become visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Thanks for all of your input on the matter.  I  agree with most of the views 
that you guys have presented on the 'progression'  of the rave scene.  It is 
safe to say that it is not just going on in the  west coast, but in the south 
as well.  The club scene does feel like it has  turned 'thuggish', and this is 
coming from a guy that grew up in the proverbial  'hood'.  Even the whole 
experience of seeing the most appealing and  cutting-edge DJs like Donald Glaude 
and George Acostas have been, to me,  undermined by the fact that they have 
moved to more mainstream clubs with people  that are there for something to do 
rather then people that really do like (I  LOVE) the music and the people.  
    I definitely have seen the scene change since  2001.  That's a very 
specific year where the scene definitely went  through some drastic changes.  I 
remember in July-August of 2001 I was on  my way to the next Caffiene party who 
included one of my all-time favorite funky  breaks DJ, Baby Anne.  I was so 
excited to go.  I remember that wen I  got there, however, the whole place was 
swarming with police.  That was the  first time I've seen one of the parties 
really get raided.  Ever since  then, things haven't been the same.  The rules 
and  regulations set age limits and prohibited such paraphanelia as glow sticks, 
 etc.  
    I have to say, however, that I don't mind so much  about the age 
regulations.  At least now they can serve alcohol, which  is good and bad.  I started 
raving when I was fourteen and I have been  listening to the music since I was 
born, but now that I look at the bigger  picture, I guess the age limit isn't 
too bad of a thing.  What bothers me  is the attitude and vibe of the whole 
thing.  I think the culture  got lost somewhere among the popularity contests 
and  people misinterpreting the music (again).  
    I do have to acknowledge the comment on the vibe in  Europe.  I was 
fortunate enough to go to Paris last Mardi Gras to visit my  then girlfriend who 
was studying abroad.  We went to a few clubs, including  Club Rex and Vinyl, and 
the vibe was amazing, and even more so because of the  fact that I was in 
another country so I really felt like I was in tune with  the world in some ways. 
 The experience was amazing.  Now I can't  say the same about French people 
in general, but hey, a raver's a raver.   =)  
    I also had similar experience when I took a detour  to Amsterdam.  The 
club scene was vibrant and I wish I could describe it in  words in an e-mail.  I 
wish I could smoke a cigarette with you and  tell you about it.  Then we can 
get nostalgic about rave culture circa  2001.   
    I have yet to experience Ibiza but hope to in the  future.  I hope that 
it doesn't turn out to be some overrated tourist  trap.  Any feedback would be 
awesome.    
The last real rave that I have been to was in 2006 during the summer.   It 
was the last Caffiene party that was down here in New Orleans.  I  believe that 
is going to be the last real rave that is going to be in New  Orleans.  I've 
been to every one since 99, so it's kind of  disheartening.  
    However, I can say that thanks to promoter Disco  Donnie, I have seen 
almost every DJ that I have ever wanted to see and  more.  He was an amazing 
promoter and I guess I got kind of spoiled because  he threw the best parties =) . 
 If anybody is reading this and gets bored,  I found a little link about him 
and the scene here.  Pretty much every  raver in New Orleans knows this like 
common knowledge, so check it out.
_www.bestofneworleans.com/.com/<WBR>dispatch/2004-02-03/cover__ 
(http://www.bestofneworleans.com/dispatch/2004-02-03/cover_story.html) 
 
   As for my trip that I am planning for San  Fran, I really appreciate the 
feedback.  I will indeed look into the Love  Parade.  I have heard bits and 
pieces about it over the years, but I never  really looked into it.  I am also 
strongly leaning towards Burning  Man.  I hope it hasn't gotten tainted by 
commercialism yet.  I still,  however, want to go to SF before the summer, but I'm 
not sure if its viable as  far as my raving ambition goes.  Please prove me 
wrong =) .  Ok,  thanks again, drop me a line -Tony 'Krash'
 
 

-------------------------------1168725190--

From sfraves-return-136874-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Sat Jan 13 22:03:50 2007
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-136874-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>

list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 88815 invoked from network); 13 Jan 2007 22:03:48 -0000
Date: Sat, 13 Jan 2007 13:58:13 -0800 (PST)
From: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>
X-X-Sender: andy@atari
To: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <7.0.1.0.2.20070110124248.03cb1648@speakeasy.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.62.0701131239430.5752@atari>
References: <45A44274.2010100@dementim.com> <20070110070227.84398.qmail@web34204.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
 <34b166470701101044s4beda2fcs483d2c3567542c43@mail.gmail.com>
 <009701c734e9$de92b790$0300a8c0@catsnovvg4qpuf>
 <d94914790701101107p69a7343cxc560843e90682f06@mail.gmail.com>
 <7.0.1.0.2.20070110124248.03cb1648@speakeasy.org>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR: What are the best *shows you've seen?


Yarr, while there's a funny stigma about having seen many shows, I'll 
vouch here.  Dead shows were for *years* the torch burning where it didn't 
burn elsewhere.  I feel honestly fortunate to have caught the dead before 
the parking lots got totally neutered, and probably caught at least 50 
shows before my 18th birthday.  It's a big part of why I've always been at 
least hesitant to pass judgement on the youngest members of our 
community... I was an early starter in a parallel universe for sure.

Fave shows that I can think of:
Grateful Dead at one of a string of Inglewood, CA shows at the GW Forum.  
I think it was a 4 or 5 night run, and in the middle of it the drummers 
brought on Olatunji with some guests (memory was hazy but it was three 
large women doing percussion chanting and harmony stuff)and it was fucking 
insane.  I danced straight through that, just really fucking lost it in 
The Good Way [tm] for the first time in my life.  Extra points on my 
friend (a skinny persian kid who loved the music) with a memorable 
performance, we'd made a bag of trails mix 
(normal trail mix + a couple shredded up irie brownies that had been 
"dropped" and a half oz of mushrooms)... and halfway through the show I 
realized he'd eaten almost the entire bag to his head, was almost 
catatonic for a bit and went on to remove most of his clothing and run 
down the aisles with lit sparklers coming out of his pants screaming 
"we're all fucked!".  Scary, sure, but also strangely awesome.

King Crimson at the Greek (berkeley, ca):
Yeah, ok, it's a prog rock staple... but seeing the first tour of the 
"dual trio" setup of KC was amazing for everybody in the crowd.  Seeing a 
blob of aging virtuoso players have that much fun and degrade into spastic 
noise, smoothly venturing into ambient, then into songs from the early 
Discipline stuff was just nuts, and the crowd was so into it.  A 
California Guitar Trio show later that same year had similar energy, good 
stuff.

Weezer @ the Cactus Club (san jose, ca):
They were already has beens, and we were waiting for them to finish so we 
could throw our weekly (Killa Subs I think it was by then) but they were 
REALLY FUCKING GOOD.  Total surprise how awesome they were.

Revolting Cocks @ ? (los angeles, ca):
Don't remember the venue, but OMFG, what a show.  It was for the Beers 
Steers and Queers tour, this show ate any other industrial-ish show I've 
ever seen for lunch... not too reliant on drum machines or samples, just 
SICK.  Extra points for Paul Barker puking behind his amp while barely 
missing a note on bass (the whole band was smashed drunk except Willie 
Rifkin from what I recall).  My heroes.  They hit every song I'd always 
wanted to hear live, did a Front242 cover, No Devotion, all that shit.

Members of Psychic TV @ Young Moguls (Los Angeles, ca):
I wasn't ready for this, but it was insanely fun.  It must have been 
around 91-92, first time I ever saw a lo-income visuals setup, quite 
badass.  Location was an old favorite of mine, a no liquor license coffee 
shop in a warehouse full of mostly industrial art.  Nowadays would seem 
passe, back then it was mind blowing... most notably a guy who had a show 
there where he created art deco fantasy pieces almost exclusively from 
welded together vintage car bumpers.  This was the pinnacle of that scene 
in LA, where I'd rubbed elbows with RHCP, Fishbone, Janes, Beck, etc.  We 
were trying to push further in all these different directions and these 
psychotic brits came and shit in our oatmeal.

Living Color - Rock for Choice Benefit @ the Palladium (Los Angeles, CA) 
There was a string of these events actually, quite nutty.  Social 
Distortion, Lunachicks, L7, Pornos for Pyros, Helmet, list goes on.  The 
living color show stuck out cause they were shiny new fun, and the pit for 
some of the double time breakdowns was just completely fanatical.  
Probably sold the place to about 4000 capacity, stand row only, just 
madness.

Course of Empire (Salt Lake City, Utah)
I was living in SLC for a year circa 93-94.  This band had popped up on 
the radar with a sorta swingy pop-industrial tune called "Infested".  I 
bought tickets, cause nobody came thru town that was any good.  First or 
second song, they threw out plastic buckets and drumsticks, amazingly good 
noisey show.  Went home drunk, sweaty, exhausted, no knees left, a brand 
new pair of 10 holes I was wearing had scuffmarks all the way up to where 
the bottoms of my pants had gotten ripped up, I taught class the next 
monday with a still slightly black eye and there wasn't any bad blood in 
the place, just frenzied music energy and morons bouncing off each other.

Pixies, 2005 (berkeley, ca):
I'd gotten so mentally screwed over by some weird life shit in the months 
prior, and then my friends drag me out to this.  Fixed me in a big way, 
just an awesome show.

Dead Can Dance, 2005 (oakland, ca):
Most fun I ever had sitting thru a band with "dance" in their name, just 
amazingly beautiful.  Ran into a friend who found out it was my birthday 
and traded tickets with me, 4th row.  Droooool.

Oingo Boingo - Dio de los Muertos shows (yearly tradition, Irvine Meadows, 
Ca)
these were consistently some of the funnest shows around, what a great 
band, what a great crowd.  What an incredible amount of puke.

Body Count (Gazarri's, Los Angeles, CA):
One of the first shows from Ice-T's rap rock creation, fucking badass at 
the time.  Of course, I'd trade this show in for the genre never having 
existed, but a good time was had by all.

Sonic Youth (or maybe it was Kim's other band at the time...) + Pornos for 
Pyros + Rage Against the Machine (Lake Castaic, CA):
WTF, best sound I've ever heard at an outdoor venue.  Bass that was clean 
and caused ones eyes to jiggle when looking at a far away object.  
Freaking insane.  Also, this was before RATM was getting airplay, and boy 
did they seem angry.

Sonic Youth (Warfield, SF, ca):
For their Washing Machine tour, a band I'd given up hope on after a couple 
lackluster pop attempts fucking rinsed it with an incredible set of 
bizarre riff punk art rock only they can do right, head down gronky bong 
music mixed with a great crowd that would border on pit frenzy action but 
never get downright wicked.

Lollapalooza (Irvine Meadows, ca):
I HATED Janes Addicition, I'd met a couple of them being in an overlappig 
social circle.  They seemed like artsy rich kid guitar school buttheads.  
But, from the first song to the last when they headlined this show I was 
in mind blown awe.  Incredible interpretations of their recorded versions, 
stage show, lights, all that.  Incredible.  I think Jesus and Mary Chain 
also played the same one (might have been a later one, dunno), but they 
blew cracked my skull as well... best rock bass tone ever combined with 
a dense wall of guitar chord and that "I'm singing this song even though I 
can't sing on heroin" delivery.

Organic 96, LA, ca
If I ran the lineup by you, you'd puke.

Dread Zeppelin (CSUN, Northridge, ca):
Best novelty act ever, this was early on when they had the Elvis 
impersonator singing leads.  Just rich.  Scary how well they could play 
too.  Reggae + Led Zep + Elvis crooning over it > all.

Primus NYE (sf, ca):
Some people hate Primus cause they are annoying.  Others love them because 
they are annoying.  Great show, ridiculously fun.  Say baby, SAY 
BABBBBBBBBBBBYYYYYYYYYY!

Christian Death @ Helter Skelter (LA, CA):
You can't call yourself proper California goth till you've seen this shit 
at least once.  Extra points for the show getting called early cause the 
guitarist broke something on his tremelo... seeing a crowd of what looked 
like sad scorched butterflies from a black and white movie almost pissed 
enough to riot will never leave my mind.

Rush, Irvine Meadows, ca:
Ok, so i also like this nerdy band.  I'm a fucking nerd, get over it.  
This one time, I saw them with my mom and my stepdad (who is also a fan).  
Guy in the row behind us passes me a joint, and I check to see if my mom 
is looking, sneak a hit, nod and smile and hand it back to him.  Right as 
I'm about to exhale, my mom looks right at me.  I'm willing to guess I 
held my breath there for about a minute thirty before she looked away.  
Almost passed out in a big way.

Beastie Boys - Free Tibet shows (polo fields, GG park, ca):
Great shows, great vibe.  A little hot and silly but overall I've always 
been a fan of positivity in this kinda context.  Sabotage had just come 
out and the Beasties really hit it home with a bit more of the punk shit 
than usual.  Good times.

Timothy Leary and Excene Cervenka @ Highland grounds (sf, ca):
Sickest spoken word I've ever attendeded, it was a look back on the life 
of Burroughs to boot with a gallery of photos he'd taken, mostly of 
apples, guns, and his wife.

Tons more I'm sure, but I'll spare you for now.  :P

On Wed, 10 Jan 2007, Apollo wrote:

-&e->You bet.  And the older you get the longer the list.  For example I saw people like Janice Joplin and the Sex Pistols live.  Was at Woodstock I.
-&e->
-&e->The most consistently wonderful shows/parties I've attended, tho,  were the Grateful Dead events.  
-&e->
-&e->My life has been one long quest for ecstatic experience.  Getting out of the self and joining the one.  I've been lucky.  Blessed.  For I've had more of these opportunities than I deserve.  The Dead were a source of tribal reunion for decades for me and many others.  Genuine family, transcending age, race, social station  and beliefs, in search of the one and helping each other achieve it.  Like the Paradise Garage and raving though, unfortunately, raves and the Garage didn't last as long as one would have liked :-)

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Friendly Cat Needs A Home

Are you wanting to add a loving cat to your household? I've had a very 
friendly cat visiting my back door for the past month who's in need of a 
new family to make her their own. She appears to have been abandoned, as 
I've been unsuccessful in reuniting her with her humans. With the cold 
weather here, it would be wonderful to find her a warm, loving home. 
I've had her in the bathroom (I've got 2 other cats) these last two 
horribly cold nights where she's been purring, content, and seeming to 
appreciate the safe space.

The cat is black/brown with white paws and belly, medium build, and 
medium/long hair. She's female, very friendly, and affectionate. She 
looks very healthy and my best guess would be that she's around 3 or 4 
yrs. old. If interested in finding out more, please call Susan at 
415-831-5395 or email shack@kzsudj.mailshell.com.

On 11/01/07, Deepfog <sfgroove@deepfog.com> wrote:
> As many of you know from previous quotes of the day, Bob Wilson is
> one of my all time favorite authors.  I've always appreciated his
> witty sense of humor and if you ever want a good run down on what was
> going on in this country in the late 60's to the early 80's his
> Cosmic Trigger books are a good source.  I went to his blog site
> today, which now I'm sort of sorry I didn't go to more often, and I
> decided to post his final 2 entries, the January 6th entry really
> made me cry for a minute, ironic because he was making a funny.
> Anyway, I encourage you to visit his blog and read up.
>
> http://robertantonwilson.blogspot.com/

> RAW Essence

> AM on binary date 01/11.

> and gratitude for the tremendous support and lovingness bestowed upon

> date to be announced

> Posted by Robert Anton Wilson 261 comments
>
>
> SATURDAY, JANUARY 6, 2007
> Do Not Go Gently Into That Good Night
>
> Various medical authorities swarm in and out of here predicting I
> have between two days and two months to live. I think they are
> guessing. I remain cheerful and unimpressed. I look forward without
> dogmatic optimism but without dread. I love you all and I deeply
> implore you to keep the lasagna flying.
>
> Please pardon my levity, I don't see how to take death seriously. It
> seems absurd.
>
> RAW

From: Philip.X.Diaz

Subject: Re: [sfraves] cloudfactory tent


that first photo is indeed the CF tent, but you can't really see it.

the second and third photos are *not* the CF tent. that would be center 
camp @ BM.

attached are a couple photos from my wedding, with the CF tent in the 
background.

from BM05 - the tent is the background in this photo, to the right:
   http://unsafe.nebcorp.com/~st_indigo/bm05/slides/DSC00033.html

and another good one:
   http://pics.feen.com/bm05/IMG_0127

the tent's footprint is 30' x 30', and the longest poles are 15' (if i 
recall correctly), it requires a good chunk of storage space (4' x 4' x 
15' or so - like along the wall of a garage). Ideally, you'll want a 
crew of about 10 people to set it up.

if you want details beyond that, you should ask Scott Nelson - 
drenalin@cloudfactory.org

-philip-

The Needle and the Damage Done

By Michael Vazquez
Photography by Jaime Chard


ROCKS IN YOUR HEAD GETS ROCKED

The ad was pretty straightforward: Free record bins; must pick up =20
today. I headed over, not noticing the address until I crossed the =20
bridge: 157 Prince Street. It was Rock in Your Head record store in =20
SoHo. I felt like an ambulance driver called to a family member's =20
house. I clung to optimism, and then saw the toppled display cases, =20
footprint-stained records on the floor. A few months ago I'd been =20
here trading=97the clerk gave me a better-than-expected price, and a 7-=20=

inch poetically titled "Spinning and Scratching" backed with "Ageing =20
Had Never Been His Friend" by Love Is All. I shoulda come here more =20
often. I ask the man overseeing the destruction what kind of business =20=

he's putting up. "Real estate." Figures. I find a page from the =20
store's checkbook, a Saint Etienne poster and a tired dollar with =20
tape on it=97maybe the first dollar this store ever made. I load the =20
bins on top of my friend's car, and we head out in silence.

I've scavenged lots of vinyl from stores that were closing. I felt =20
like a villain buying every Exist Dance release at a cut rate, and =20
when I came across a discarded, unopened Beautiful People 12-inch I'd =20=

been looking for, it felt like the worst kind of gain, at the expense =20=

of another.

Hunting around Manhattan for $2 fixes, $5 splurges and $20 haggle-=20
downs, I find shops that are still doing OK. But for each survivor, =20
there are scores more stores you could pour liquor for. When I visit =20
the 8-by-20-foot Rainbow Records, 78-year-old Harry asks rhetorically =20=

why business is bad: "Because Tower is closing this weekend, so all =20
the kids are going there," he answers himself, sighing.

CONTINUED:  http://www.urb.com/online/features/143_vinyl.php



apollo@speakeasy.org

MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo

Tribenet:   http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm



"No sage or savior has ever endorsed greed and gluttony as a path =20
toward social justice or personal fulfillment.  These sane and =20
enlightened people come to us from all cultures and all eras, =20
sometimes knowing of each other but more often not.  Socrates and =20
Jesus, Lao Tzu and Tolstoi, Gandhi and Martin Buber -- no one can =20
find in their lives and words a jot of support for a political and =20
economic regime that encourages the acquisition of wealth far beyond =20
what is needed for the necessaries -- or even the restorative =20
pleasures -- of life while consigning the masses to live and work in =20
squalor."
-Stephen J. Fortunato, Associate Justice, Rhode Island Supreme Court.

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of =20
the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will =20
gradually become visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"



--Apple-Mail-1--678810622--

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: contacts in Berlin

Greetings everyone!  Happy New Year. <3


I will be taking a pilgrimage to Berlin with my boyfriend Sean in late 
February/early March, and will be staying hopefully until the end of 
April.  We are going in order to spend some time with the German techno 
scene and hear some yummy music, pick up some new records, and hopefully 
make friends and learn some German.  Does anyone here have any contacts 
in Berlin, for perhaps either a place to stay, connections to the 
electronic music scene, DJing gigs, etc etc ? 


We are hoping to find a place to stay with some other like minded 
electronic music enthusiasts... If you know someone or have any ideas, 
please forward them our housing-wanted post from craigslist -- 
http://berlin.craigslist.org/sbw/258358731.html


Thanks!
Love Chelsea
