The Needle and the Damage Done

By Michael Vazquez
Photography by Jaime Chard


ROCKS IN YOUR HEAD GETS ROCKED

The ad was pretty straightforward: Free record bins; must pick up =20
today. I headed over, not noticing the address until I crossed the =20
bridge: 157 Prince Street. It was Rock in Your Head record store in =20
SoHo. I felt like an ambulance driver called to a family member's =20
house. I clung to optimism, and then saw the toppled display cases, =20
footprint-stained records on the floor. A few months ago I'd been =20
here trading=97the clerk gave me a better-than-expected price, and a 7-=20=

inch poetically titled "Spinning and Scratching" backed with "Ageing =20
Had Never Been His Friend" by Love Is All. I shoulda come here more =20
often. I ask the man overseeing the destruction what kind of business =20=

he's putting up. "Real estate." Figures. I find a page from the =20
store's checkbook, a Saint Etienne poster and a tired dollar with =20
tape on it=97maybe the first dollar this store ever made. I load the =20
bins on top of my friend's car, and we head out in silence.

I've scavenged lots of vinyl from stores that were closing. I felt =20
like a villain buying every Exist Dance release at a cut rate, and =20
when I came across a discarded, unopened Beautiful People 12-inch I'd =20=

been looking for, it felt like the worst kind of gain, at the expense =20=

of another.

Hunting around Manhattan for $2 fixes, $5 splurges and $20 haggle-=20
downs, I find shops that are still doing OK. But for each survivor, =20
there are scores more stores you could pour liquor for. When I visit =20
the 8-by-20-foot Rainbow Records, 78-year-old Harry asks rhetorically =20=

why business is bad: "Because Tower is closing this weekend, so all =20
the kids are going there," he answers himself, sighing.

CONTINUED:  http://www.urb.com/online/features/143_vinyl.php



apollo@speakeasy.org

MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo

Tribenet:   http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm



"No sage or savior has ever endorsed greed and gluttony as a path =20
toward social justice or personal fulfillment.  These sane and =20
enlightened people come to us from all cultures and all eras, =20
sometimes knowing of each other but more often not.  Socrates and =20
Jesus, Lao Tzu and Tolstoi, Gandhi and Martin Buber -- no one can =20
find in their lives and words a jot of support for a political and =20
economic regime that encourages the acquisition of wealth far beyond =20
what is needed for the necessaries -- or even the restorative =20
pleasures -- of life while consigning the masses to live and work in =20
squalor."
-Stephen J. Fortunato, Associate Justice, Rhode Island Supreme Court.

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of =20
the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will =20
gradually become visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"



--Apple-Mail-1--528885123--

both moved there separately, for separate reasons)

Massage? Nope.
Holding weird positions that I've never seen in yoga? Pretty much.
Bad Chiropractic practices? felt like it.
Sexual? Nope.
Perverted? If you perceived it to be.
Would I do it again if the Crunch were a hot chick instead? Absolutely :-)

There's no denying it's a bit weird, esp. since it's also very clear he 
targets boys, it's really not fair to convict him of molestation since 
it's never been proven.

-terry

wanting a 18yo toy to play with, but honestly, what's the difference 
between somebody the day befor etheir 18th B-day, and the day after?  Not a 
damn thing in my book.  It's an abritrary age set for legal reasons of 
having a definative line in the sand.

Sadly, in our society we pat somebody on the back for banging a girl on her 
18th birthday and slap cuffs and give'em 20 years if it's the day before.

At 10:06 AM 1/16/2007, Terry Estioko wrote:
>There's no denying it's a bit weird, esp. since it's also very clear he 
>targets boys, it's really not fair to convict him of molestation since 
>it's never been proven.

Ok, I must be weird, but I never got the whole young thing. I've
listened to many locker room talks where guys are going on about young
teens and how they love to see them and have fantasies. Personally I
never got the point. Maybe I got my fill when I was in HS/college, but
I personally am more attracted to a healthy woman that is near my age
(30). I just don't get why anyone would want to be with an annoying,
immature teenaged person (like they talk too much like about like
nothing yo). Even for sex I would rather be with a pro then a novice.
but whatever, I guess I'm strange.

i'll chime in that i never really understood what the big deal was if  
someone is male or female and older or younger and likes the opposite  
of either the same sex or opposite sex.  is that umbrella enough for  
everyone?  the thing that made me wonder about it is the age of  
consent varies in different states.  isn't it like 12 or 13 in some  
states where it's 18 in most?  who determines these things anyway?

now as a free thinking person of free will, i believe i get to choose  
who i want to hang out with and who i don't.  i met john years ago at  
some party, i can't even remember, and i'll admit i'm freaked out by  
the fact he has a lot of missing teeth and wild hair and glasses.   
well, the glasses, i don't care about.  it's just he seems someone to  
me that doesn't take care of himself.  the observation by many that  
he seems to like young men really doesn't matter to me, though i get  
the feeling he's a bit persistent when maybe he ought to move on and  
find one that actually likes older men ... because i do think there  
is something for everyone in the world with 6 or 8 billion people ...  
btw, for the overpopulation hounds, i heard you could fit all the  
people in the world in the state of florida, but that's another  
thread for another day ...

anyway, if you personally like john draper and want to hang out with  
him or defend him against the allegations he's a child molester,  
which i thought that is what he went to jail for, but i could be  
wrong,  feel free and don't let me stop you.  and by the way, me  
saying these things about him i'm in no way saying i'm perfect or  
even better than him.  i was just wondering why someone wrote an  
article but hey what does it matter they have the right to, too.

was this a long enough post?  sheez.  better than turning on the boob  
tube, maybe.  i turned it on for 5 minutes and decided i didn't want  
to invest the time, even if it was DVR recorded.  that jake 2.0 show  
is just more government propaganda.  i didn't even feel like skimming  
through it today.

-d

Subject: [sfraves] [bsp] Trance hang-out in Mission district

Hi everyone,

My name is Paul (DJ Paul Ephonic) and I just joined the list. I wanted 
to take a quick sec to mention this little get-together we've been 
having at my place for over a year now. Normally we just send these 
invites out to a couple small mailing lists, but since our usual 
suspects seem to be getting busy these days I figured I'd see if there's 
anyone else out there who might be into this sort of thing. You don't 
have to be an experienced DJ to spin here, but some experience helps. 
All we ask is that you provide us a list of tracks so we can give credit 
to the artists on our site.

More info...

What:
DJs spinning trance, hanging out, and eating food (usually order in or 
make something simple). You should come and
spin, or just hang out. If you want to spin, please make sure your 
tracks are some kind of trance (progressive, psy, etc.). We prefer to do 
a 3 track tag team between all the DJs since this is more social and 
means no one gets trapped behind the decks. Alternatively, we will let 
DJs have a 30min-1hr guest slot at the end of the session. If you want 
to get deck time, please show up as early as possible and plan to stay 
til the end. This keeps the rotation going smoothly. We are equipped 
with CDJs, turntables (not currently set up, let us know if you need 
'em), and lots of inputs for whatever other devices you might want to 
hook up.

When:
Tonight. 8pm-11pm

Where:
My house (near the Mission Dolores in SF). Highly MUNI-able (J line) and 
fairly BART-able (16th and Mission). RSVP for exact location. We also 
have a couple parking spots.

Why:
You like trance, you live in the city (or can get here), and you don't 
have anything better to do on a Tuesday night.

Stream & Podcast Info:
The stream will be available from 8-11pm PST at:
http://stream.tranceportal.org:8000
If you want a copy of the set, the recording will be available through 
iTunes or for direct download via tranceportal.org. This show will be 
released in 2 weeks.

Thanks!
Paul
Tranceportal.org

---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

There are MP3 splitters available out there, which take WAV files as well.
The secondary input is a CUE file that specify the track/split times.

Google around for audio splitter, there are plenty of one-off utilities.

 I do this by splitting up the track in something like audacity (free,
but annoying) or fission (cheap, mildly annoying) and then  burn the
individual tracks with the "gapless" option set in iTunes.

  I thought about buying roxio toast to do this, but couldn't see
where the value add was.

-jasonh

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR:  advice on software to turn 1 mix into separate
 numbered tracks

Hi Jonny,

You didn't specify how you want to play the set after it is split. 
Presumably you want to put it on a CD, in which case I'd recommend using 
Nero. SoundForge will let you export the timestamps to something that 
Nero can read directly, but you could use any audio player to generate 
those manually.

The other possibility is that you want to make a file with these cue 
points in it to play on your computer. We've used the Apple Chapter Tool 
to do this for our podcast. It works pretty well, but you have use the 
AAC format for the audio.

Best of luck,
Paul

Subject: [sfraves] Oh yeah.. my interview w/ DJ Rap

So this is a segmant from the :code tv at Love Parade show that never got
editted... & like slowly, the other Executive producer/ edittor, Bruce is 
putting up the segments that we did do that day!

OK... b4 y'all watch this, I'm so like i'm gonna share a secret w/ y'all! 
Managers have alot to do w/ how the "interview" is programmed... like her
manager told me to ask "key questions" during the interview (which i
woulda asked anyway), but it was pretty much like that w/ all the DJs i
interviewed that day & their managers... lol... if my interview w/ Bad Boy
Bill ever sees the light of day, then you'll see what i mean 'cause his
manager got livid w/ me w/ 1 question I asked him... Hello 2day.. &
threatened to sue :code tv if we ever aired that interview...

Anywaze...ooh yeah... i was kinda sleep dep that whole day 'cause I only
ended up getting an hour sleep prior to going to staging that morning for
the BADNB float... so I wasn't me, but still was i guess :P  Hello 2day! 
Oh yeah.. you're gonna see the like 3rd or 4th take of the interview 'til
her manager felt it was right...

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR:  advice on software to turn 1 mix into separate
 numbered tracks

The only problem with most of these ideas is that you have to go through 
two more conversions MP3 -> wav -> MP3.  mp3directcut allows you to chop 
the mp3 up without those conversions.

On 16 January 2007, michael, the red stickman wrote:

> which is a plus in my book.
>

>> Hi Jonny,
>>
>> You didn't specify how you want to play the set after it is
>> split.
>> Presumably you want to put it on a CD, in which case I'd
>> recommend using
>> Nero. SoundForge will let you export the timestamps to
>> something that
>> Nero can read directly, but you could use any audio player to
>> generate
>> those manually.
>>
>> The other possibility is that you want to make a file with
>> these cue
>> points in it to play on your computer. We've used the Apple
>> Chapter Tool
>> to do this for our podcast. It works pretty well, but you
>> have use the
>> AAC format for the audio.
>>

>> Paul

Paul wrote:
> Hi everyone,
>
> My name is Paul (DJ Paul Ephonic) and I just joined the list. I wanted
> to take a quick sec to mention this little get-together we've been
> having at my place for over a year now. Normally we just send these
> invites out to a couple small mailing lists, but since our usual
> suspects seem to be getting busy these days I figured I'd see if there's
> anyone else out there who might be into this sort of thing. You don't
> have to be an experienced DJ to spin here, but some experience helps.
> All we ask is that you provide us a list of tracks so we can give credit
> to the artists on our site.
>
> More info...
>
> What:
> DJs spinning trance, hanging out, and eating food (usually order in or
> make something simple). You should come and
> spin, or just hang out. If you want to spin, please make sure your
> tracks are some kind of trance (progressive, psy, etc.). We prefer to do
> a 3 track tag team between all the DJs since this is more social and
> means no one gets trapped behind the decks. Alternatively, we will let
> DJs have a 30min-1hr guest slot at the end of the session. If you want
> to get deck time, please show up as early as possible and plan to stay
> til the end. This keeps the rotation going smoothly. We are equipped
> with CDJs, turntables (not currently set up, let us know if you need
> 'em), and lots of inputs for whatever other devices you might want to
> hook up.
>
> When:
> Tonight. 8pm-11pm
>
> Where:
> My house (near the Mission Dolores in SF). Highly MUNI-able (J line) and
> fairly BART-able (16th and Mission). RSVP for exact location. We also
> have a couple parking spots.
>
> Why:
> You like trance, you live in the city (or can get here), and you don't
> have anything better to do on a Tuesday night.
>
> Stream & Podcast Info:
> The stream will be available from 8-11pm PST at:
> http://stream.tranceportal.org:8000
> If you want a copy of the set, the recording will be available through
> iTunes or for direct download via tranceportal.org. This show will be
> released in 2 weeks.
>
> Thanks!
> Paul
> Tranceportal.org
>
> ---------------------------------------------------------------------
> To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
>
>

To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

What makes me laugh is the number of people I find bringing it into the 
club.  Not a bottle either, we're talking a  half tab in the pocket 
loose.  Apparently its' the rage, especially with middle aged and other gay 
guys (any of you on the list want to confirm?  Danny?  *snicker*)  to pop 
one at the club before dancing to enhance the package while at the club....

Club drug policy being what it is, it's not allowed in, and it's rather 
funny to have somebody at the door argueing that "it's just viagara!"   The 
rule here is if you'e gonna bring it, make sure it's in a perscription 
bottle with your name on it from the pharmacy...

One time I told a guy, cause I was bored...

"Look, I'm not real comfortable with you bringing this in here.  For 
starteres, its' a drug.  I don't care what you want to call it, if you need 
a perscription, it's a drug.  If you don't have your perscription, then I'm 
not letting it in.  I would say the same thing about generic asprin that 
wasn't in teh bottle and I couldn't see Bayer on the tab.

"Sondly, I'm also not comfortable with you popping Viagara in teh 
club.  Might might as well have a loaded gun yin your pocket.  You're gonan 
feel it in there, all hard up again your skin.  An dyou'r egonna run it.  I 
mean, how could you NOT want to?  Then you're gonna have to go shoot teh 
thing off and that's just gonna be a big mess that I, nor the janitor 
really want to deal with.  If you really feel the need, and teh urge, just 
take it down to the shooting range...  you have a lot of choices...  Blow 
Buddies is a half block away, or go with the big boys and take a cab to 
Power Exchange."

I don't care who you are...  thats' funny.

(and I bet there's still people on this list that think I'm a complete 
asshole.... heh heh)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR:  advice on software to turn 1 mix into separate numbered tracks

if you have a mac you can use amadeus which allows you to mark the  
track in different points and it will process the file and create  
seperate mp3 (or probably whatever format you want) files.  i don't  
know if mp3 direct cut allows you to do the same thing but it sounds  
like it and that's the easiest way to go, i think.  also, it will  
allow you to join files, which i sometimes have to do.

-d

Message-ID: <326242.15069.qm@web32012.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR:  advice on software to turn 1 mix into separate numbered tracks



You can do this with iTunes, and iTunes is totally
free!!

drop the long mix into iTunes, then right-click on it
and select "get info" and then go to the "Options" tab


In that tab, you'll find time values for "Start Time"
and "Stop Time"  set the values so that start is at
00:00.00 and stop is at the end of the first mix. 
then click "OK"

now, back in the iTunes playlist, right-click on the
mix and select "Convert Selection to MP3" (or whatever
format you want for your output, as set in the
Preferences>Advanced>Importing) and iTunes will render
down a copy of the section that you've specified.

Now, go back to the big mix and set the start for just
after the end of the previous stop (eg. of the
previous stop was at 3:45.06 make the next start at
3:45.07) and then set the stop for the end of the next
mix.

go back to the playlist and convert again and you'll
get a new file with the second track.

lather, rinse, repeat until you're all done, then set
up the tracks in the proper order in their own
playlist and set them for gapless playback.

Three DJs fired after woman dies following water-drinking contest
01-16) 17:36 PST SACRAMENTO, (AP) --


A Sacramento area radio station fired 10 employees Tuesday, including three 
morning disc jockeys, after a mother of three died following an on-air 
water-drinking contest last week at the station's studios.

Ethan, who I'm not sure if he's on the list anymore or just a lurker,

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Some cool mods for the computer geeks

About 3-4 years ago I created a home media center PC using this case:

http://www.bettercomputers.com.au/product_info.php?cPath=77&products_id=260

(I got it for a lot cheaper then that by going straight to the
original manufacturer)

I then programmed the LCD to display song/artist track names and to
say "Welcome to the Osteen media center" when I first turn it on. I
also used large (slow) fans and suspended the drives using rubber
mounts to quiet it down. It has 5.1 DTS and also analog surround,
along with an ATI component or DVI connection to my 1080i HD tv (which
I bought cheap and with better quality using a tube tv). I tested out
a few different wireless keyboards and mice and finally got a decent
logitech setup, but would rather go RF when I can find a set up cheap
enough. I can watch videos/DVD, play games, music, winamp visuals, or
browse the internet in my living room in 32 inches. I use an ATI RF
remote, but prefer to just use a mouse. The only issue I have is boot
time, I wish I could figure out a way to speed up the boot time, I
used msconfig, but it is still at least 40 seconds.

Anyway, its great for parties because you can just set up a playlist
and put visuals on and leave it alone. It beats the hell out of those
manufacturer media centers.

X-ELNK-Trace: f722cf73e4f5a6835b59645513f9ec4240683398e744b8a4f30947421052f04c9bfeeb1f06bbd3bba2d4e88014a4647c350badd9bab72f9c350badd9bab72f9c
X-Originating-IP: 67.101.38.230
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] Three DJs fired after woman dies following water-drinking contest

A nurse called in during the contest and warned about "water intoxication".
The DJ's dismissed her warning by saying that the contestants signed wavers
and knew what they were doing. The woman who died complained oh a headache
and they told her it was just the water and encouraged her to drink more.

For those who don't know the excessive intake of water (>800mL per hour2)
can lead to a condition known as hyponatremia which is a result of a loss of
sodium concentration in the body. Excessive amounts of water in the
extracellular fluid act as a hypotonic solution relative to the contents of
the body's cells. Osmosis causes water to flow into the cell and sodium to
flow out. This difference in concentrations can cause the cell walls to
swell and rupture leading to the death of the cell. It becomes most
dangerous when there is movement of water into the brain cells which causes
neurological damage, coma, and death. 



-Sean

Subject: RE: [sfraves] Three DJs fired after woman dies following water-drinking contest

--0-1904662901-1169065795=:16943
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Does this remind anybody of a debate from several years ago about OD'ing on e? Didn't somebody die in England after drinking too much water at a rave one time? Seems to me that if anybody at the radio station did ANY homework at all, they would have found this contest to be quite dangerous. Fire all the fu*&^ers.

peace
chuck

freakzone@mindspring.com wrote: A nurse called in during the contest and warned about "water intoxication".
The DJ's dismissed her warning by saying that the contestants signed wavers
and knew what they were doing. The woman who died complained oh a headache
and they told her it was just the water and encouraged her to drink more.

For those who don't know the excessive intake of water (>800mL per hour2)
can lead to a condition known as hyponatremia which is a result of a loss of
sodium concentration in the body. Excessive amounts of water in the
extracellular fluid act as a hypotonic solution relative to the contents of
the body's cells. Osmosis causes water to flow into the cell and sodium to
flow out. This difference in concentrations can cause the cell walls to
swell and rupture leading to the death of the cell. It becomes most
dangerous when there is movement of water into the brain cells which causes
neurological damage, coma, and death. 



-Sean

Subject: RE: [sfraves] Three DJs fired after woman dies following water-drinking contest

Any good raver worth his/her salt would already know that rather than E 
being the main cause of E related deaths, hyponatremia is typically the 
reason folks wind up dying, and therefore intaking that much water when u 
are NOT perspiring like mad (for any reason - heat, drugs, etc.) could kill 
you.






>From: <freakzone@mindspring.com>
>To: "'Ranger -'" <plurranger@hotmail.com>,<sfraves@hyperreal.org>
>Subject: RE: [sfraves] Three DJs fired after woman dies following 
>water-drinking contest
>Date: Wed, 17 Jan 2007 11:55:32 -0800
>
>A nurse called in during the contest and warned about "water intoxication".
>The DJ's dismissed her warning by saying that the contestants signed wavers
>and knew what they were doing. The woman who died complained oh a headache
>and they told her it was just the water and encouraged her to drink more.
>
>For those who don't know the excessive intake of water (>800mL per hour2)
>can lead to a condition known as hyponatremia which is a result of a loss 
>of
>sodium concentration in the body. Excessive amounts of water in the
>extracellular fluid act as a hypotonic solution relative to the contents of
>the body's cells. Osmosis causes water to flow into the cell and sodium to
>flow out. This difference in concentrations can cause the cell walls to
>swell and rupture leading to the death of the cell. It becomes most
>dangerous when there is movement of water into the brain cells which causes
>neurological damage, coma, and death.
>
>
>
>-Sean
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>

> Any good raver worth his/her salt would already know that rather than E
> being the main cause of E related deaths, hyponatremia is typically the

> kill

Actually drinking large volumes of water while "perspiring like mad" is more
of a risk. Large volumes of sodium and other electrolytes are lost in
perspiration. Better to drink Gatorade.


-Sean

> -----Original Message-----
> From: CHUCK G [mailto:chuckg_421@yahoo.com]

> 
> Does this remind anybody of a debate from several years ago about OD'ing
> on e? Didn't somebody die in England after drinking too much water at a
> rave one time? Seems to me that if anybody at the radio station did ANY
> homework at all, they would have found this contest to be quite dangerous.
> Fire all the fu*&^ers.
> 
> peace
> chuck
> 
> freakzone@mindspring.com wrote:
> 
>     A nurse called in during the contest and warned about "water
> intoxication".
>     The DJ's dismissed her warning by saying that the contestants signed
> wavers
>     and knew what they were doing. The woman who died complained oh a
> headache
>     and they told her it was just the water and encouraged her to drink
> more.
> 
>     For those who don't know the excessive intake of water (>800mL per
> hour2)
>     can lead to a condition known as hyponatremia which is a result of a
> loss of
>     sodium concentration in the body. Excessive amounts of water in the
>     extracellular fluid act as a hypotonic solution relative to the
> contents of
>     the body's cells. Osmosis causes water to flow into the cell and
> sodium to
>     flow out. This difference in concentrations can cause the cell walls
> to
>     swell and rupture leading to the death of the cell. It becomes most
>     dangerous when there is movement of water into the brain cells which
> causes
>     neurological damage, coma, and death.
> 
> 
> 
>     -Sean
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
>

Steve,

Bitchin! How long did it take to assemble? I've noticed msconfig doesn't 
stop a lot of processes from running in the background, perhaps those are 
causing some lag on your boot-up?

peace
Chuck

Steve Osteen <sosteen@gmail.com> wrote: About 3-4 years ago I created a home 
media center PC using this case:

http://www.bettercomputers.com.au/product_info.php?cPath=77&products_id=260

(I got it for a lot cheaper then that by going straight to the
original manufacturer)

I then programmed the LCD to display song/artist track names and to
say "Welcome to the Osteen media center" when I first turn it on. I
also used large (slow) fans and suspended the drives using rubber
mounts to quiet it down. It has 5.1 DTS and also analog surround,
along with an ATI component or DVI connection to my 1080i HD tv (which
I bought cheap and with better quality using a tube tv). I tested out
a few different wireless keyboards and mice and finally got a decent
logitech setup, but would rather go RF when I can find a set up cheap
enough. I can watch videos/DVD, play games, music, winamp visuals, or
browse the internet in my living room in 32 inches. I use an ATI RF
remote, but prefer to just use a mouse. The only issue I have is boot
time, I wish I could figure out a way to speed up the boot time, I
used msconfig, but it is still at least 40 seconds.

Anyway, its great for parties because you can just set up a playlist
and put visuals on and leave it alone. It beats the hell out of those
manufacturer media centers.

> > reason folks wind up dying, and therefore intaking that much water when 
>u
> > are NOT perspiring like mad (for any reason - heat, drugs, etc.) could
> > kill
> > you.
>
>
>Actually drinking large volumes of water while "perspiring like mad" is 
>more
>of a risk. Large volumes of sodium and other electrolytes are lost in
>perspiration. Better to drink Gatorade.
>
>
>-Sean
>
>
>
>
>

nything, let alone the problems real people face day-to-day, is as scarce a=

sider what AT&T got in the bargain. For giving up on Net Neutrality, it got=

Subject: [sfraves] new to the area/list from minneapolis

Hey everyone, been lurking about a week after being tipped off to this
list via x|k of <http://www.wayfar.net/>. We're both big into ripping
dance beats on retro hardware and met playing @ blipfestival in nyc a
few months ago.

Anyway as the subject says, I'm new to the area and looking forward to
witnessing and contributing to some sound systems out here! Currently
I'm up to doing live pa as STARPAUSE or K9D rocking LSDj on gameboy
and piggy tracker on gp2x.

I also run a creative-commons-recordings label @ <http://mp3death.us/>
and put weekly creative commons focused mixes up as podcasts @
<http://gorehole.org/podcast/>. And for those of you familiar w/ the
demo scene, I'm a member of the Northern Dragons :)

Besides the music stuff, I'm looking for work in San Francisco. I've
been doing C++ development the past few years, interested in getting
into usability/interface design. So keep those random pass-alongs
rolling!.

see you around,
<3 j.ordan

-- 
http://mp3death.us/k9d/

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Three DJs fired after woman dies following water-drinking contest

Not so much, really.

Hyponatremia is still mostly in the realm of extreme atheletes like  
marathon runners; and, apparently, people making asses out of  
themselves in fraternities or on the radio.  Overheating and  
dehydration are still much more common, immediate, and important  
hazards.  You shouldn't give up the water, just don't overdo it.

My own trick is to just bring with me a couple of fast food salt  
packets when I plan to be... well... not sober.  Dissolve one into my  
water bottle, and I'm set.  It's also encouraging that you see  
Gatorade, and the like, at parties a lot these days.  And even Red  
Bull is good for 200mg of sodium per.

The salt thing is that much extra important to me especially; not  
because I fear hyponatremia, but because my mom's half of the family  
has a history of *LOW* blood pressure.  I start to get dizzy and  
nauseous and crave salt fairly quickly when I'm exerting myself.  My  
mom's even worse... she can't even go outside (Granted... in the  
Florida sun...) for half an hour without having to go back in for  
something salty to snack on.


cya,
john


On Jan 17, 2007, at 1:02 PM, <freakzone@mindspring.com>  
<freakzone@mindspring.com> wrote:

>> Any good raver worth his/her salt would already know that rather  
>> than E
>> being the main cause of E related deaths, hyponatremia is  
>> typically the
>> reason folks wind up dying, and therefore intaking that much water  
>> when u
>> are NOT perspiring like mad (for any reason - heat, drugs, etc.)  
>> could
>> kill
>> you.
>

rs of drugs. The parents=0Acooperated with the media to produce powerful em=
otive anti Ecstasy images=0Aof their unconscious daughter dying behind them=
 as they were interviewed,=0Awith the noble aim of getting the message acro=
ss that Ecstasy is highly=0Adangerous and can kill. This was followed up by=
 billboards showing her in=0Aintensive care with the caption "Sorted. Just =
one Ecstasy tablet killed=0ALeah Betts".=0A=0A=0AIt was not for two weeks t=
hat the cause of death was given as due to=0Adrinking too much water, and t=
hen only at the bottom of page 5 of The Times.=0AAlthough the official inqu=
est confirmed this, it was revealed that she had=0Aalso had several strong =
alcoholic drinks and had smoked cannabis along with=0Athe Ecstasy. Later it=
 emerged that Leah had taken Ecstasy at least four=0Atimes before, and that=
 she and her friends had planned in advance to take=0AEcstasy at her birthd=
ay party. The media preferred to keep the message simple:=0ALeah died from =
taking a single tab of Ecstasy. To say she died from drinking=0Awater is no=
t a good story, and the fact that she was a regular Ecstasy user=0Amight le=
ad to the suspicion that her death was due to a panic reaction brought=0Aon=
 by her parents being in the next room with their intolerant attitudes.=0A=

Subject: [sfraves] [bsp] two new free techno weeklys

For the techno fans on this list...


Two Free Techno Weeklies: Fukwerk Friday/Low End Saturday
Friday, January 19 and Saturday, January 20

Location: 111 Minna Street Gallery + Retox Lounge
Minna is at 111 Minna Street
Retox is at 628 20th Street
San Francisco, CA
More Info: www.babd.org

Enough waiting! Your free techno happy hour resumes this week on Friday.
But this is just to whet your appetite.
We know a happy hour just isn't enough.

On Saturdays, make your way to Retox Lounge for Low End, a new techno
weekly that starts Saturday, Jan. 20!

Details on both events below. More info and list sign up at babd.org

Check out music and videos on myspace: www.myspace.com/lowendsaturday

----------------------------------------------------------------------
Fukwerk Friday
111 Minna
Every Friday
5-9 and sometimes later
No Cover

With the solekandi duo, James Bass (Bassaholics Anonymous) starting
your weekend off with bumping minimal jakk in one of SF's best art
gallery/nightspots.

Enjoy fresh min/max techno and tech-house mixes, 5-7 drink specials
($1 off) and no cover at SF's beloved 111 Minna every Friday with
Fukwerk Fridays, located in the Zappa Lounge (to the right).

Low End Saturday @ Retox Lounge
Retox Lounge
628 20th Street (x 3rd Street)
San Francisco, California
9 PM to 2:00 AM
No Cover

Tucked away in SF's Dogpatch neighborhood, Retox Lounge (formerly
Sublounge) is the weekly Saturday destination for the best techno in
SF with plentiful parking nearby, stiff drinks, proper vibe and of
course, no cover!

Accessible via bus # 22 and #15. New 3rd Street Lightrail runs limited
hours. Check schedule.

Get a taste of Detroit banging minimal techno sound with Peoplemuver's
Kawa plus the sparse, deep and sultry stylings of the solekandi duo.

More info on: Low End Saturday and Fukwerk Fridays at the Bay Area
Beatdrop website:

www.babd.org
http://www.myspace.com/fukwerkfridays
http://www.myspace.com/lowendsaturday

On 1/17/07, John B <SvnLyrBrto@yahoo.com> wrote:
> Not so much, really.
>
> Hyponatremia is still mostly in the realm of extreme atheletes like
> marathon runners; and, apparently, people making asses out of
> themselves in fraternities or on the radio.  Overheating and
> dehydration are still much more common, immediate, and important
> hazards.  You shouldn't give up the water, just don't overdo it.
>
> My own trick is to just bring with me a couple of fast food salt
> packets when I plan to be... well... not sober.  Dissolve one into my
> water bottle, and I'm set.  It's also encouraging that you see
> Gatorade, and the like, at parties a lot these days.  And even Red
> Bull is good for 200mg of sodium per.
>
> The salt thing is that much extra important to me especially; not
> because I fear hyponatremia, but because my mom's half of the family
> has a history of *LOW* blood pressure.  I start to get dizzy and
> nauseous and crave salt fairly quickly when I'm exerting myself.  My
> mom's even worse... she can't even go outside (Granted... in the
> Florida sun...) for half an hour without having to go back in for
> something salty to snack on.
>
>
> cya,

For the people who are the DYI types...

When I got sick earlier this month and fluuid and electrolytes were a 
serious concerns, the pharmacy reccomended this stuff called Hydralife.

It comes in ready mix packets, tastes pretty good.  Reccomends to mix with 
12oz water but I found that to be a bit strong and moxed a packet with 
16oz.  The packets are water proof unlike the salt packets so it would 
survive a night in your pocket and not get soggy.  You could also probably 
sprinkle small bits into a watter bottle to sip on for steady intake and 
fold up the packet and save the rest for later.

Comes in 4 packs per box.  Scored at Walgreens.

At 11:12 PM 1/17/2007, Bam wrote:
>i have this really strange reaction to...stuff.  at some point, i just
>can't retain any fluids and keep pissing it out.
>
>the salt used to help.  gatorade does too.

>From: dangrsmind@yahoo.com
>To: Deepfog <sfgroove@deepfog.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
>Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Thu)
>Date: Thu, 18 Jan 2007 07:24:53 -0800 (PST)
>
>Better learn how to use that gun too.  Its funny to me how many people 
>think that merely "owning" a weapon offers protection somehow.  As if 
>somehow you are going to be able to defend yourself against an organized 
>military unit simply by showing them you have a gun.  More probably they'll 
>just kill you with extreme prejudice.
>
>You see in order to effectively fight against an organized military force, 
>you need not only to have a weapon, but also to know how to utilize your 
>weapon as part of an organized military unit in action.  And that requires 
>training and practice.  How do I know this? Because I used to design 
>training systems for the U.S. Army and I spent some time learning about 
>their training methods at Fort Benning Georgia.
>
>Are you planning on joining a militia Deepfog?  Sounds like it.
>
>I'd make sure that you check the credentials of the organizers because a 
>lot of these people don't really know anything about military tactics.  
>They do know quite a bit about taking your money and (in some cases) 
>controlling your mind.  Many militia leaders have phony military 
>credentials and pretend to know how to train military units.  But that 
>won't save your ass in a fire fight.  Do you have the knowledge to evaluate 
>the training you are receiving?
>
>Consider for example the problem of defending your home. Sure you can 
>evaluate lines of fire,get some sand bags, and turn your whole world into a 
>nasty little death trap.  Now explain to me how you will defend yourself 
>against an Apache helicopter, concentrated mortar fire, or an air strike.  
>What about that microwave pain cannon?  I suspect your little AK-47 won't 
>be much help, no matter how good of a shot you are.
>
>I also note that in Iraq the populace was generally armed to the teeth, not 
>only with conventional firearms,  but also with explosives, rocket 
>propelled grenades, missiles, etc.  They seem to have a good number of 
>armed militias as well.  And we can see how well they are doing with that.  
>Organizing an armed resistance isn't as easy as it looks.
>
>Now the idea of putting 300 million or more people in "camps" is certainly 
>frightening to contemplate, and there is some history here for example in 
>Stalin's gulags, but lets examine the reality.  Where exactly are these 
>camps?  How will people be transported to them?  And how exactly will 
>owning a gun protect you?
>
>What about the global consumer economy?  Prisoners in concentration camps 
>generally don't have a lot of money to spend at Walmart.  Who exactly wants 
>that economy to cease functioning?  The globalists supporting the new world 
>order?  The global Zionist conspiracy?  George Bush?  I call bullshit on 
>this idea.
>
>You bring up Devvy Kidd, however I'm not sure I can decrypt her point about 
>McCain.  What the fuck does she mean?  Am I supposed to be informed by that 
>comment?  I wonder if she even knows what she's trying to say here.
>
>Finaly, I find it is always worth examining some of these sorts of people's 
>other views to understand what they are really all about.  For example, 
>consider http://www.newswithviews.com/Devvy/kidd55.htm and 
>http://www.newswithviews.com/Devvy/kidd18.htm  And there's a lot more in 
>this vein.  Sorry Deepfog Ms. Kidd is not someone I'm interested in 
>listening to all.  Independent thinkers: check her web site 
>(http://www.devvy.com) and use Google.
>
>Deepfog, you've fallen prey to fear and hate.  Please consider this.  These 
>ideas are not going to help you.
>
>Peace,
>
>Peter

Subject: [sfraves] promote yourself, or just have fun

hi all,
as i'm sure you all have seen in my signature, and various attempts at
promoting it myself, i run a podcast. from show to show i try to mix
up the selection, play various genres and styles and keep the show
progressing with new and unheard music. keeping up to date with the
latest tracks can be a pretty daunting task, especially when you're
working 9 hours a day and going to school three days a week...

that's where you come in. are you an aspiring musician, dj, producer,
remixer or music nerd with something you want the world to hear? if
you answer yes then i want to hear from you. i'm looking for guest
hosts to put together 30 minute free form sets (that is, a set made up
of any selection of music, non-genre specific and doesn't have to be
beat mixed) to be featured on the podcast. we try to put out a show
every 2 weeks, so there's plenty of opportunity for you to be
featured. this is a great chance for you to promote yourself and have
fun while doing it.

interested? drop me a line.

-g

-- 
Greg Albrecht (gregoryba@gmail.com)
An Indie, Hip Hop and IDM Podcast: The Letter G
http://theletterg.org

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

>> armed militias as well.  And we can see how well they are doing with that=

ts

I do believe there is, and has been for the last 120 years or so, an =20
ongoing conspiracy to set up a one world socialist government dating =20
back to the days of George Bernard Shaw and the founding of the Fabian =20
Society.  The reasoning is, people won't accept socialism if you force =20
it on them, but if you slowly work the world toward that way quietly, =20
one day there will be socialism and everyone will accept it.  They =20
work toward the idea that the things they do to institute this system =20
might not complete this in their lifetime.

This is sort of condensed in a nutshell and I don't have time to go =20
over this stuff more right now but I do think it's important for =20
people to be aware of this stuff, whether or not they agree with it.

Happy Friday 'yall. 

Just a thought. . .

I bought this Men's Health home workout bible that has all kinds of ideas for working out on the cheap. You can fill plastic milk bottles with water (or sand once you beef up a little) and pump those & do squats. Use a sturdy chair or couch to do dips which are just-as-if-not-more important. For about $15 bucks you can get a chin-up bar which IMHO is worth its weight in gold. If you're going to spend any cash, I'd recommend dropping it on a nice pair of running shoes with good cushioning. 

peace

chuck

I've been eyeing the AVIC Z1, but its a double-din, full install system. I
don't want to have a device flopping around my dashboard with cables all
over the place.

http://www.crutchfield.com/S-9a5u4JfhiMK/cgi-bin/ProdView.asp?g=300&I=130AVICZ1

It helps to play with the models to see what you like about their response
time, controls and such. This isn't something you want to fiddle with while
driving.

because I do all the maintenance and repairs myself. I have never
called a repair man for anything. My house is always clean (and I
don't do meth), I make a habit of planting poppy seeds where ever I
see fresh soil, my lawn, yard, and backyard are not a eye sore for the
community.

software that is the "newer cheaper better" alternative to the others and 
purported even much better than TomTom6 although i haven't seen TT6.

includes 1GB of flash filled with US maps and POI internal but after 
cleaning out all but CA, NV, AZ and OR, i had 800MB free to fill with MP3s 
and after hacking to get at the underlying Windows CE, i loaded Nero Mobile 
7 on it and load MP4 movies onto another 2GB of flash i put in the SD slot.

oh, and i hacked in the British female voice since so i would feel at home 
having some bitch try to tell me what to do ;)

never had a gps before... i twas a whimiscal buy but after a few weeks with 
it, i find it indespensible.  comes with a windsheild mount and cigarette 
adatper for the car that mounts and dismounts easiliy to move from car to 
car... watched movies on it while waiting around all day at jury duty last 
week, played some games, etc.

this the one i got:

in short, map points are g r a t e !

Subject: [sfraves] RIP Pete Morse

--Apple-Mail-1--187601179
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=US-ASCII;
	delsp=yes;
	format=flowed

Peter H. Morse Jr.
	 	
Peter H. Morse, Jr. 36, a pioneer and leader in harm reduction policy  
and practice, passed away on January 13, 2007. Dr. Morse was fiercely  
committed to protecting the health and well-being of drug users and  
their communities by reducing drug-related harm. His work in these  
areas has helped make harm reduction part of public policy and public  
consciousness. As the Naloxone Distribution Program Coordinator for  
the Drug Overdose Prevention Education (D.O.P.E.) Project of San  
Francisco, Dr. Morse helped to forge a groundbreaking partnership  
with the San Francisco Department of Public Health to provide  
naloxone at needle exchange sites throughout the city. Naloxone is an  
opioid antagonist that counters the deadly effects of overdose by  
heroin or other opiates. Dr. Morse helped establish and advised  
numerous syringe exchange programs throughout the country. He has  
been a member of the advisory board of the North American Syringe  
Exchange Network since 2001. He was currently serving as the advisory  
board chair for the Homeless Youth Alliance, an agency that provides  
critical services, including syringe exchange, to homeless youth in  
San Francisco. He was a member of the Injection Drug User Taskforce  
of the California HIV Planning Group, and was appointed to the San  
Francisco HIV Prevention Planning Council Substance Use and  
Structural Interventions Committee. Dr. Morse currently worked as the  
Project Coordinator of the Harm Reduction Coalition Syringe Exchange  
Technical Assistance Program and was working to expand syringe access  
in California. He was a longtime volunteer at the San Francisco  
Needle Exchange, and before that at the syringe exchange of the Lower  
East Side Harm Reduction Center when he lived in New York City. He  
was also a member of the Moving Equipment Syringe Distribution  
Collective of New York City. Dr. Morse also worked as an interviewer,  
counselor, and project coordinator for University of California San  
Francisco's UFO Study, a hepatitis prevention focused health study of  
injection drug using youth. Dr. Peter H. Morse was born in Royal Oak,  
Michigan. He was educated at DePauw University, and received his  
doctorate in history from Binghamton University in 2006. In his  
research, he worked to understand the role of race and gender in the  
formation of political identity by members of radical industrial  
organizations in the United States during the early twentieth century  
He was an avid bibliophile and political activist, and was a member  
of the Bound Together Anarchist Book Collective. Dr. Morse was also a  
DJ, bringing electronic dance music to people in New York City, San  
Francisco, the Nevada Test Site, and Black Rock City, Nevada. Pete  
Morse is survived by his partner of 11 years, Liz Turner. The couple  
lived in Berkeley, California. He is also survived by his parents  
Pete and Patty Morse of Bloomfield Hills, Michigan; his sister Carrie  
Morse of Washington, D.C. and his brother and sister-in-law, Dan and  
Meredith Morse of Berkley, Michigan. A Service will be held on  
Saturday, January 20, 2007, at 3:00 PM, at The Sullivan Funeral  
Chapel, 2254 Market St., S.F. In lieu of flowers, please send  
donations to: Tenderloin Health/Homeless Youth Alliance, Attention:  
Mary Howe, P.O. Box 170427, San Francisco, CA 94117. 
--Apple-Mail-1--187601179--

Subject: [sfraves] Hope You Saved Your Glow Stick

Content-Type: text/plain;

	delsp=yes;
	format=flowed

January 21, 2007
Hope You Saved Your Glow Stick
By SAM KNIGHT

LONDON

TO most people in Britain, rave is a memory, and a blurry one at =20
that. For four years at the end of the 1980s and the beginning of the =20=

1990s, Britain=92s youth took to the fields, forests and warehouses, =20
took Ecstasy, wore some of the silliest outfits ever devised =97 like =20=

cricket hats, white gloves and gas masks =97 and ushered out =20
Thatcherism in a strobe-lighted haze of electronic music that shook =20
the ground they danced on.

Then Parliament passed the Criminal Justice Act of 1994, which =20
humorlessly characterized rave music as =93the emission of a succession =20=

of repetitive beats,=94 and gave police the power to shut raves down. =20=

That swiftly put an end to the scene=92s drug-induced violence =97 and =
to =20
the scene itself.

But if you happen to be in London these days, there are signs that =20
something like rave is stirring again.

=93The first time around, rave really seeped into the mainstream,=94 =
said =20
Carri Mundane, 26, a designer who was a child during the first rave =20
scene but kept the fliers amassed by her older brother. =93The music =20
was in the charts, and everything just became a little bit more =20
psychedelic.=94

This time, it=92s more insular. And it=92s different in other ways, too: =
=20
some of the music is rock, not electronica, and the scene is no =20
longer as defined by the twin illegalities of drugs and trespassing.

But a collection of young creative types are dressing up and making =20
music that unmistakably refers back to the garishness, the euphoria =20
and the escapism of 15 years ago.

In mid-December, the Klaxons =97 an indie rock band and the self-=20
appointed leaders of the scene =97 invited a pack of D.J.=92s, artists =20=

and other performers to play a final gig of the year under the =20
railway arches of London Bridge.

The location was the site of illegal parties in the early 1990s but, =20
in keeping with the more sanitized character of today=92s movement, is =20=

now a well-appointed nightclub with a bouncer, sofas to lounge on and =20=

$7 beers.

The music didn=92t sound like rave. Though tinged with electronica, the =20=

Klaxons and two other bands played stripped-back rock, not unlike =20
much of the music that has been in vogue in Britain the last few =20
years. And the dance floor was more of a punkish mosh pit, with lots =20
of shoving revelers, than a blissed-out, synchronized community of =20
dancers.

Still, there were glow sticks =97 a kind of waving coral reef of neon =20=

pinks, yellow and greens =97 and between acts, young men in leather =20
jackets nudged their way around the dance floor, offering Ecstasy. =20
Teenage fans wore reflective jackets, neon paint, sunglasses, beads =20
and whistles as they hurled themselves back and forth, up and down, =20
suggesting that if this wasn=92t rave, then it was certainly a somehow-=20=

related cousin.

Like the original, the new rave scene may be a refuge from reality. =20
Although neither incarnation of rave would claim anything as coherent =20=

as an ideology, there may be an echo of Margaret Thatcher=92s =20
frustrated youth among those experiencing the last days of Tony =20
Blair=92s Britain, said Tahita Bulmer, the lead singer of the band New =20=

Young Pony Club.

=93That spirit of contentment has faded,=94 she said, with the country =20=

vehemently opposed to the way the prime minister has handled the war =20
in Iraq. But it=92s when people are unhappy, she added, that =20
=93everything goes neon and gets exciting.=94

Ms. Mundane, the designer, who wears brightly colored clothing that =20
has made her an arbiter of rave fashion, said, =93What I like about =20
rave is the positivity of it, the fact that it is so utopian.=94

The rave renaissance may be a reaction to the country=92s dour =20
political state or to the tyranny of indie rock. =93There=92s only so =20=

much partying you can do to these shoe-gazing indie bands,=94 said =20
Jaimie Hodgson, a music journalist, referring to Britain=92s emo-heavy =20=

music scene.

Many participants say they are nostalgic for a movement they are old =20
enough to at least remember, even if they have not experienced it =20
themselves. Or perhaps they=92re just looking for an excuse to dress up =20=

and take Ecstasy, otherwise known as MDMA, a drug best known for =20
inducing a touchy-feely, sensation-inducing high.

The new rave scene is a small, tightly connected movement of artists, =20=

D.J.=92s, bands and partygoers forged in a series of warehouse parties =20=

that, beginning in 2003, were organized by a gang of artists called =20
the Wowow Boys, in New Cross, a ragtag neighborhood of students and =20
boarded-up buildings southeast of London Bridge.

As in the 1990s, the gatherings attracted newly formed bands that =20
were eager to create an environment =93where the specific aim was to =20
party, =93 said Jamie Reynolds, the bass player of the Klaxons.

Hence, the outrageous outfits: At a New Young Pony Club gig, Oisin =20
Butler, a psychology student who said he was starting a band called =20
Aids Baby, sat wearing a purple bow tie, a red cardigan and glasses =20
with Day-Glo frames and no lenses. His jeans were so tight there was =20
no room for his keys. =93You can wear anything, as long as it=92s odd, =
or =20
glittery, or neon, or is really disgusting,=94 he said.

At a popular monthly dance party in Islington, North London, people =20
are encouraged to download smiley masks =97 a throwback to the original =20=

rave scene and an Ecstasy reference =97 from a Web site. The event =20
started in 2003 with a party in an abandoned public bathroom; this =20
summer 3,000 people in fluorescent attended its Glade Festival.

The dance-music scene has been =93snowballing=94 for the last three =20
years, says the party=92s D.J. and promoter, who calls himself Saint =20
Acid. He added that his early events were mainly attended by people =20
in their 30s, wearing old clothes and looking to relive the dance =20
parties of their youth, but now the crowd is =93getting younger and =20
younger.=94

Mark Archer is half of Altern8, a riotous dance act last seen playing =20=

the violin in biological warfare suits in 1991. After 15 years of =20
relative quiet, Mr. Archer, now 38, played at the recent Islington =20
party and is enjoying the unlikely satisfaction of seeing a young =20
band, Trash Fashion, cover one of Altern8=92s old tracks.

=93If someone had told me 16 years ago that I would still be playing =20
now the same music I was then, and that rock bands would be covering =20
our songs, I would have laughed,=94 he said. =93All of a sudden rave has =
=20
become cool again. It=92s been a bit of a shock.=94

http://www.nytimes.com/2007/01/21/fashion/21Rave.html?=20
_r=3D1&ref=3Dfashion&pagewanted=3Dprint&oref=3Dslogin







apollo@speakeasy.org

MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo

Tribenet:   http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm



"No sage or savior has ever endorsed greed and gluttony as a path =20
toward social justice or personal fulfillment.  These sane and =20
enlightened people come to us from all cultures and all eras, =20
sometimes knowing of each other but more often not.  Socrates and =20
Jesus, Lao Tzu and Tolstoi, Gandhi and Martin Buber -- no one can =20
find in their lives and words a jot of support for a political and =20
economic regime that encourages the acquisition of wealth far beyond =20
what is needed for the necessaries -- or even the restorative =20
pleasures -- of life while consigning the masses to live and work in =20
squalor."
-Stephen J. Fortunato, Associate Justice, Rhode Island Supreme Court.

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of =20
the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will =20
gradually become visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"



--Apple-Mail-1--140848897--

Apollo wrote:
> January 21, 2007
> Hope You Saved Your Glow Stick
> By SAM KNIGHT
>
> LONDON
>
> TO most people in Britain, rave is a memory, and a blurry one at
> that. For four years at the end of the 1980s and the beginning of the
> 1990s, Britain’s youth took to the fields, forests and warehouses,
> took Ecstasy, wore some of the silliest outfits ever devised — like
> cricket hats, white gloves and gas masks — and ushered out
> Thatcherism in a strobe-lighted haze of electronic music that shook
> the ground they danced on.
>
> Then Parliament passed the Criminal Justice Act of 1994, which
> humorlessly characterized rave music as “the emission of a succession
> of repetitive beats,” and gave police the power to shut raves down.
> That swiftly put an end to the scene’s drug-induced violence — and to
> the scene itself.
>
> But if you happen to be in London these days, there are signs that
> something like rave is stirring again.
>
> “The first time around, rave really seeped into the mainstream,” said
> Carri Mundane, 26, a designer who was a child during the first rave
> scene but kept the fliers amassed by her older brother. “The music
> was in the charts, and everything just became a little bit more
> psychedelic.”
>
> This time, it’s more insular. And it’s different in other ways, too:
> some of the music is rock, not electronica, and the scene is no
> longer as defined by the twin illegalities of drugs and trespassing.
>
> But a collection of young creative types are dressing up and making
> music that unmistakably refers back to the garishness, the euphoria
> and the escapism of 15 years ago.
>
> In mid-December, the Klaxons — an indie rock band and the self-
> appointed leaders of the scene — invited a pack of D.J.’s, artists
> and other performers to play a final gig of the year under the
> railway arches of London Bridge.
>
> The location was the site of illegal parties in the early 1990s but,
> in keeping with the more sanitized character of today’s movement, is
> now a well-appointed nightclub with a bouncer, sofas to lounge on and
> $7 beers.
>
> The music didn’t sound like rave. Though tinged with electronica, the
> Klaxons and two other bands played stripped-back rock, not unlike
> much of the music that has been in vogue in Britain the last few
> years. And the dance floor was more of a punkish mosh pit, with lots
> of shoving revelers, than a blissed-out, synchronized community of
> dancers.
>
> Still, there were glow sticks — a kind of waving coral reef of neon
> pinks, yellow and greens — and between acts, young men in leather
> jackets nudged their way around the dance floor, offering Ecstasy.
> Teenage fans wore reflective jackets, neon paint, sunglasses, beads
> and whistles as they hurled themselves back and forth, up and down,
> suggesting that if this wasn’t rave, then it was certainly a somehow-
> related cousin.
>
> Like the original, the new rave scene may be a refuge from reality.
> Although neither incarnation of rave would claim anything as coherent
> as an ideology, there may be an echo of Margaret Thatcher’s
> frustrated youth among those experiencing the last days of Tony
> Blair’s Britain, said Tahita Bulmer, the lead singer of the band New
> Young Pony Club.
>
> “That spirit of contentment has faded,” she said, with the country
> vehemently opposed to the way the prime minister has handled the war
> in Iraq. But it’s when people are unhappy, she added, that
> “everything goes neon and gets exciting.”
>
> Ms. Mundane, the designer, who wears brightly colored clothing that
> has made her an arbiter of rave fashion, said, “What I like about
> rave is the positivity of it, the fact that it is so utopian.”
>
> The rave renaissance may be a reaction to the country’s dour
> political state or to the tyranny of indie rock. “There’s only so
> much partying you can do to these shoe-gazing indie bands,” said
> Jaimie Hodgson, a music journalist, referring to Britain’s emo-heavy
> music scene.
>
> Many participants say they are nostalgic for a movement they are old
> enough to at least remember, even if they have not experienced it
> themselves. Or perhaps they’re just looking for an excuse to dress up
> and take Ecstasy, otherwise known as MDMA, a drug best known for
> inducing a touchy-feely, sensation-inducing high.
>
> The new rave scene is a small, tightly connected movement of artists,
> D.J.’s, bands and partygoers forged in a series of warehouse parties
> that, beginning in 2003, were organized by a gang of artists called
> the Wowow Boys, in New Cross, a ragtag neighborhood of students and
> boarded-up buildings southeast of London Bridge.
>
> As in the 1990s, the gatherings attracted newly formed bands that
> were eager to create an environment “where the specific aim was to
> party, “ said Jamie Reynolds, the bass player of the Klaxons.
>
> Hence, the outrageous outfits: At a New Young Pony Club gig, Oisin
> Butler, a psychology student who said he was starting a band called
> Aids Baby, sat wearing a purple bow tie, a red cardigan and glasses
> with Day-Glo frames and no lenses. His jeans were so tight there was
> no room for his keys. “You can wear anything, as long as it’s odd, or
> glittery, or neon, or is really disgusting,” he said.
>
> At a popular monthly dance party in Islington, North London, people
> are encouraged to download smiley masks — a throwback to the original
> rave scene and an Ecstasy reference — from a Web site. The event
> started in 2003 with a party in an abandoned public bathroom; this
> summer 3,000 people in fluorescent attended its Glade Festival.
>
> The dance-music scene has been “snowballing” for the last three
> years, says the party’s D.J. and promoter, who calls himself Saint
> Acid. He added that his early events were mainly attended by people
> in their 30s, wearing old clothes and looking to relive the dance
> parties of their youth, but now the crowd is “getting younger and
> younger.”
>
> Mark Archer is half of Altern8, a riotous dance act last seen playing
> the violin in biological warfare suits in 1991. After 15 years of
> relative quiet, Mr. Archer, now 38, played at the recent Islington
> party and is enjoying the unlikely satisfaction of seeing a young
> band, Trash Fashion, cover one of Altern8’s old tracks.
>
> “If someone had told me 16 years ago that I would still be playing
> now the same music I was then, and that rock bands would be covering
> our songs, I would have laughed,” he said. “All of a sudden rave has
> become cool again. It’s been a bit of a shock.”
>
> http://www.nytimes.com/2007/01/21/fashion/21Rave.html?
> _r=1&ref=fashion&pagewanted=print&oref=slogin
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
> apollo@speakeasy.org
>
> MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo
>
> Tribenet:   http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k
>
> Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
>
> House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
>
>
>
> "No sage or savior has ever endorsed greed and gluttony as a path
> toward social justice or personal fulfillment.  These sane and
> enlightened people come to us from all cultures and all eras,
> sometimes knowing of each other but more often not.  Socrates and
> Jesus, Lao Tzu and Tolstoi, Gandhi and Martin Buber -- no one can
> find in their lives and words a jot of support for a political and
> economic regime that encourages the acquisition of wealth far beyond
> what is needed for the necessaries -- or even the restorative
> pleasures -- of life while consigning the masses to live and work in
> squalor."
> -Stephen J. Fortunato, Associate Justice, Rhode Island Supreme Court.
>
> "Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of
> the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will
> gradually become visible."
> -Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"
>
>
>

Subject: RE: [sfraves] The Twilight Years of Cap'n Crunch

a lot of stuff that is very disturbing, and i don't have any of the =20
links memorized or stored anywhere, but i think a simple google search =20
of CPS child abuse or child protective services abuses are a good =20
start if you're interested in knowing more.  you can also watch the =20
cathy o'brien video on google video where she talks about the things =20
she wrote in her book trance:formation of america, which i'd like to =20
read, but a lot of the books i'd like to read aren't available at the =20
chain bookstores.  hmpf.

anyway, CPS is a big subject and cathy o'brien's claims are probably =20
easily refutable because they're all what she says happened to her =20
from a very young age and she came from a family with a generational =20
history of abuse.  but still, check it out for starters and see what =20
you believe.  don't take my word for it.  on the other hand, i would =20
understand if a lot of people here would rather just think about what =20
the next cool party coming up instead is.

but why not do both?

now getting back to john draper, you guys asking me to talk about this =20
stuff, i kind of don't want to think about it right now, it's even so =20
disturbing to me.  and i was looking at pictures of afghan kids =20
deformed from DU, that's even more disturbing.  but i think maybe i'll =20
just say that i'm sorry i even brought it up that john draper would be =20
a good candidate for CPS, because i don't even actually know the guy =20
very well and i don't think he's that sick of a person to get off on =20
these kinds of things.  and it's even possible he's just a victim of =20
the system.  once you're in it, it's easy to be picked on.

well i think i've maybe said enough here tonight and i'll let some of =20
you respond and tell me i'm promoting hate and world zionist =20
conspiracies or whatever you're going to say.  that's fine, i hope =20
there's some of you out there that maybe know i'm a little more =20
genuine than that and i care about people and would like to spread the =20
word about corruption so hopefully someone somewhere can avoid getting =20
caught up in it inadvertently.

anyway i smell like fuel been working on an engine i'm going to shower =20
now.  DF out

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Mon)

I've got another stellar Pat Robertson quote in the wings.  Not =20
enough, perhaps, for a quote of the week, but we'll see after Tuesday.

I can't remember if I told you guys the weirdest thing I have ever =20
done.  The vaccum cleaner story?

No?  OK, here goes.  So I was living at that EBF house back in the =20
day, car was not running at the time, and vaccum cleaner was in sorry =20
shape.  So I had Peter give me a ride to a shop, over by his house, =20
near a BART station, and I took BART home.  Came back, few days later, =20
the vaccum is ready to pick up.  Car still not running.  So I go, take =20
my happy self, and pick up the vaccum, and get on BART.

With a vaccum cleaner.  See where this is going?

So you know how things go, you get bored waiting for the train, and =20
then by the time you get on the train, you're bored waiting for your =20
stop, at least I do, so I was bored and decided to start vaccuming.  =20
Well, there are no obvious electrical outlets in the train cars, so I =20
just pretended I was vaccuming.  And there were about 7 people in the =20
car, I didn't really look at them, but they even moved their feet out =20
of the way so I could get under the benches.  What a riot!  Made the =20
stop come by a whole lot faster.

Moral of the story?  I don't know that there is one.  But what seems =20
to come to mind is if you look like you're doing something important, =20
most people won't question what you're doing.

--

I keep seeing Pat Robertson in a green and orange plaid suit on a
corner somewhere trying to sell you used hot dogs.

- Pastor Davidson Loehr

>

well i'll have to take a look at this book and see what i think about it.


>
> Robert Anton Wilson addresses this exact point.  How can we tell the =20
>  difference between our fantasies (reality tunnels), whether they  =20
> originate with mind control or not, and the true nature of external  =20
> reality?  What he's saying is that to a large extent you can't tell  =20
> the difference, and therefore the best course is to remain agnostic. =20
>   See also fuzzy logic (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuzzy_logic)

i think reality tunnels and trying to discern from what is true and =20
what isn't is most often subjective and constantly subject to review.  =20
i think even trying to look beyond our own reality tunnels in itself =20
might be its own reality tunnel.  you're right, what is real and what =20
isn't?

>
> I think you are greatly underestimating the intelligence of the  =20
> people on this list when you suggest that everyone is just  =20
> interested in the "next cool party coming up"  Maybe we just aren't  =20

well you may be right that i'm underestimating the intelligence of =20
people on the list.  now conversely, you might be underestimating my =20
belief that just because i listen to and agree with some of the things =20
jeff rense, devvy kidd, cathy o'brien, alex jones, etc.  doesn't mean =20
i buy every last thing they say, nor does it mean i'm a hateful racist =20
gay basher that believes everything is a conspiracy.

i guess i was kind of not understanding how you made that connection =20
in the first place, but i guess maybe i didn't explain myself well =20
enough.  in fact, i've never understood discrimination of any kind, =20
but i'm also convinced that the key to making people less racist and =20
bigoted is to let them air their anger.  most of them that i've =20
encountered personally usually start to see that for themselves when i =20
just listen but don't buy into the bigotry by egging it on.

the main thing is, i'm not afraid to be wrong.  in fact, in a lot of =20
cases, i'd rather stick my neck out there and be wrong a few times to =20
maybe learn something.

>

well no, i actually agree with you that a rave is a party with a =20
purpose.  now of course, i've met people that don't feel that way.

anyway, i have to run.  i'm sorry if i offended anyone with my =20
postings.  i hope the discussion was something in the end maybe a =20
positive thing where some of us learned things.  i know i did.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] cure for cancer

--0-352464927-1169487585=:50135
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Beware the one cure fixes all. I happen to work in cancer research and can tell you that there is not just one event that causes cancer. There are many, many types of cancer and they all tend to behave differently.

Many people want to view pharmaceutical companies as suppressing a cure because it would not make them large sums of money. While it is true that some things are not pursued further because it does not make sense to invest millions of dollars in something that will not gain returns it is not wise to believe in a conspiracy of hiding medical truths. I have worked in this industry for a long time and can genuinely tell you that the people working on cancer research genuinely and scientifically are working towards medicines that treat many various cancers.

On that note, there was an article I read recently about AIDS in Africa. It was about how record numbers of people were dieing because they refused to take the drug cocktail provided to them because it made them sick. Instead there was this herbal concoction that was said to cure AIDS. The witch doctors, I think, believed this themselves all the while making money hand over fist. Now, while I don't think our system is perfect or the FDA is free of corruption it is much better than the rampant quackery that is occurring in Africa.  

-Amber

Phillip Mispagel <phillip@viberation.com> wrote: 
//beknown to me thanks to tigerstar on another list

that's right, and it might be available soon:

http://www.newscientist.com/channel/health/dn10971-cheap-safe-drug-kills-most-cancers.html

Subject: Re: [sfraves] cure for cancer

On 22/01/07, Amber Leahey <princess_leahey@yahoo.com> wrote:
> Beware the one cure fixes all. I happen to work in cancer research and can tell you that there is not just one event that causes cancer. There are many, many types of cancer and they all tend to behave differently.

on the topic of cancer, and it's potential cure, earlier this month i
listened to an interview with carl zimmer where he discussed his
article "evolved for cancer" (sci. american, jan 2007):

"Norman E. Sharpless of the University of North Carolina at Chapel
Hill genetically engineered mice to study the effect of one of these
proteins, called p16 (or, more properly, p16-Ink4a). He and his
colleagues created a line of mice that lacked a functional gene for
p16 and thus could not produce the protein. In September 2006 the
group published three studies on the mice. As expected, the animals
were more prone to cancer, which could arise when they were only a
year old. "

"But losing the p16 gene had an upside. ... They destroyed
insulin-producing cells in the pancreases of the animals. The normal
rodents could no longer produce insulin and developed fatal diabetes.
But the ones without the p16 protein developed only mild diabetes and
survived. The progenitors of their insulinproducing cells could still
multiply quickly, and they repopulated the pancreas with new cells. "

article: http://tinyurl.com/2kambf
interview: http://podcast.sciam.com/weekly/sa_podcast_070110.mp3


> On that note, there was an article I read recently about AIDS in Africa. It was about how record numbers of people were dieing because they refused to take the drug cocktail provided to them because it made them sick. Instead there was this herbal concoction that was said to cure AIDS. The witch doctors, I think, believed this themselves all the while making money hand over fist. Now, while I don't think our system is perfect or the FDA is free of corruption it is much better than the rampant quackery that is occurring in Africa.

in a discussion this weekend someone brought up Kary Mullis and his
hypothesis that HIV does not cause AIDS. this idea was the basis for
at least one political policy in south africa:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thabo_Mbeki#Controversies:_AIDS

although i haven't all of the related articles yet, one of the
observations was that the symptoms of malnutrition and starvation are
not dissimilar from the symptoms of aids.

see also:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AIDS_dissident
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kary_Mullis
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peter_Duesberg

-g

to the world of intrigue.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR:  advice on software to turn 1 mix into
  separate numbered tracks


I've done it with Nero.  Very easy.

The only problem I had was that my burner requires that there is a 
manditory 2 second break between tracks 1 & 2.  My work around was to 
create a 1 byte air track to put in for track 1, then everything was fine 
afte rthat.

Nero breaks the mix into seperate song files.  Then you just tell teh 
burner not to put any spaces bretween tracks and it's pretty good.

Probably a better way to do it, but that's why i did with software I 
already had on my system.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Some cool mods for the computer geeks


You've got a few choices:

Pretty much boils down to what software and video you're running.  The ATI 
All in wonder internal solutions are some of the most tested and 
reccomended solutions.  What it all boils down to is ditching teh TiVO and 
building a dedicated machine to act as your PVR.  Amost most all of the TV 
Tuner Cards will have PVR capability, which in effect makes them run just 
like TiVO.

For you open source people look no further than 
http://www.mythtv.org/   DOn't like it? There's plenty of others out there.

I've seen some real nice cases designed as media center for home brew 
people, with your entire entertainment system being powered and ran from a 
dedicated PC.  Drop in a 500 gig drive for hours of storage, a nice 7.1 
Audigy X-fi sound card.  A lot of the new video card all have componet out 
on them, so all you need to do is get the signal in.

http://ati.amd.com/products/radeonx1900/aiwx1900/index.html
http://us.creative.com/products/product.asp?category=1&subcategory=208&product=14065

>From: CHUCK G <chuckg_421@yahoo.com>

>Date: Wed, 17 Jan 2007 11:39:58 -0800 (PST)

>Steve,

>Bitchin! How long did it take to assemble? I've noticed msconfig doesn't 
>stop a lot of processes from running in the background, perhaps those are 
>causing some lag on your boot-up?
>
>peace
>Chuck
>
>Steve Osteen <sosteen@gmail.com> wrote: About 3-4 years ago I created a 
>home media center PC using this case:
>
>http://www.bettercomputers.com.au/product_info.php?cPath=77&products_id=260
>
>(I got it for a lot cheaper then that by going straight to the
>original manufacturer)
>
>I then programmed the LCD to display song/artist track names and to
>say "Welcome to the Osteen media center" when I first turn it on. I
>also used large (slow) fans and suspended the drives using rubber
>mounts to quiet it down. It has 5.1 DTS and also analog surround,
>along with an ATI component or DVI connection to my 1080i HD tv (which
>I bought cheap and with better quality using a tube tv). I tested out
>a few different wireless keyboards and mice and finally got a decent
>logitech setup, but would rather go RF when I can find a set up cheap
>enough. I can watch videos/DVD, play games, music, winamp visuals, or
>browse the internet in my living room in 32 inches. I use an ATI RF
>remote, but prefer to just use a mouse. The only issue I have is boot
>time, I wish I could figure out a way to speed up the boot time, I
>used msconfig, but it is still at least 40 seconds.
>
>Anyway, its great for parties because you can just set up a playlist
>and put visuals on and leave it alone. It beats the hell out of those
>manufacturer media centers.
>

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: "FRESH" @ Shine, Friday 2/2

A new RIPE event is kicking off in February at SHINE called FRESH.
Each month a different members of the Space Cowboys take the reigns
and rotate ownership of the event, mixing it up with different styles
and flavors always keeping it "fresh".

"Double the Pleasure, Double the Fun"
Friday, 2/2
$5 cover
21+ up
Shine @ 1337 Mission St (btwn 9th and 10th)
9PM =96 2AM
www.shinesf.com

Two DJ's for the price of one, tag sets all night long!

8Ball (Space Cowboys) vs. Benchun (False Profit)
Kapt'n Kirk (Space Cowboys) vs. J9 (Angels of Bass)
Ernie Trevino (Space Cowboys) vs. Bam (Evil Breaks)

The opportunity to double your drinking pleasure: two 4 one (you flip
for it, you call it, before 11.)
And if you come with your "twin" (aka your friend and you dressed
alike) get in 2 for 1.

Mark your calendar's twice!

*all proceeds to benefit Killagirl and her family*
Donations can also be made at www.asylumvillage.com/killa-donate.htm

--=20
--------------------------
< Brandon / DJ Bam >

DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
http://www.getbammed.com
http://www.evilbreaks.com
January 20th:  DIRTY w/ Future Funk Squad, Fine Cut Bodies, Lobudg @ Fat Ci=
ty
February 2nd:  Space Cowboys - Killagrrl fundraiser @ Shine
February 18th:  Infuse: Elite Intentions w/ Elite Force @ Mighty
March 14th:  Qool @ 111 Minna
