As someone who suffers from bipolar...it's a bitch to grasp at times...and it sure scared off guys many times before...it's a scary feeling at times when you feel like no one can help you and my lowest seems to hit when no one is around which puts me in a state of mind that no one cares but i know that isnt true..it's a bitch of a battle and i continue to battle it everyday...as for help...i have tried many approaches from lithium to therapy...docs are always trying to get you on some sort of medication...but i rather deal with it directly...anywho...

it is sad to hear that dave is gone...he will be miss for sure...

xoxo
adriana

dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote: Sorry to hear about this.

I never met Disco D, but my ex-wife suffers from this disease.  And although she seems to be doing sort of OK right now, it wrecked our marriage, seriously harmed our children, and to a very large extent has wrecked her life as well.  In my experience it is much often more serious and difficult to deal with than people seem to think.   

If someone you know or love is suffering from depression or bipolar disorder don't ignore it, get some help.  In my own case, at the time I didn't understand the nature of my ex's illness at all.   I just thought she was a bitch.  

Bad things happened as a result.

Peace,

Peter

"An adult is one who has lost the grace, the freshness, the innocence of the child, who is no longer capable of feeling pure joy, who makes everything complicated, who spreads suffering everywhere, who is afraid of being happy, and who, because it is easier to bear, has gone back to sleep.  The wise man is a happy child."
-Arnaud Desjardins

"Music rots when it gets too far from the dance.  Poetry atrophies when it gets too far from the music."
-Ezra Pound

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Wed)

I find this to be an interesting quote.  That book Creature from =20
Jekyll Island I read recently claims the Civil War was not about =20
ending slavery originally, it was about the Northern states =20
economically strangling the Southern states with the laws they were =20
passing.  It even suggested that slavery was on its own way out the =20
door into nonexistence, because the slave trade had already been =20
abolished.

Now before I read this book, I personally talked to a lot of people =20
from the South, I'm talking North Carolina, South Carolina, Louisiana, =20
Texas, of all ages, and they *all* agreed that the Civil War was not =20
about slavery.  So if this is true, why the war and why did I learn in =20
all my history courses in high school and college differently?  Was =20
Lincoln manipulated?  It reminds me of that saying that history is =20
written by the victors.  Are the schools really just government =20
training camps?

These questions I hope we will all turn the boob tube off for an hour =20
today to ponder.  Have a nice day, quote of the day out.

--

The people are the masters, not to overthrow the Constitution, but to
overthrow the men who pervert it.

- Abraham Lincoln

The problem is did Lincoln actually ever say that? =0A=0AIf you try to find=
 the source of that quotation you won't find it. Or at least I couldn't. =
=0A=0AApparently Teddy Roosevelt actually said something like this in a pap=
er he wrote in 1913 . (http://teachingamericanhistory.org/library/index.asp=
?document=3D1140) =0A=0AI couldn't find a source for the quotation Roosevel=
t uses however. I'd guess this is most likely a paraphrase of something Lin=
coln actually said in his inaugural speech in 1861. See http://www.famousqu=
otes.me.uk/speeches/Abraham_Lincoln/1.htm I don't have time today to do mor=
e thorough research, so you'll have to form your own opinion or do your own=
 research. =0A=0AOne point to keep in mind, note the differences in languag=
e usage between Lincoln's actual speech and this purported quotation.  Pers=
onally I'm a bit skeptical that a public figure would have used the word "p=
erverted" in a speech in the 1860s.  Maybe I am mistaken.=0A=0AAs far as th=
is book, G. Edward Griffin is merely retelling a story first reported in a =
previous book by Eustace Mullins. If you want to learn more about the origi=
ns of this story, you should go to the source and that's Eustace Mullins.=
=0A=0AI'd encourage everyone to do their own research about Mullins, but in=
 case you want some quick starting points:=0A=0Ahttp://en.wikipedia.org/wik=
i/Eustace_Mullins =0Ahttp://www.rense.com/general39/EUSTACE.htm =0Ahttp://w=
ww.rense.com/general72/contract.htm =0A=0AAs usual these people's own words=
 are the best place to start understanding their true beliefs.=0A=0AI am ce=
rtain that many in the Confederacy believed that "the Civil War was not abo=
ut slavery" but about "the Northern states economically strangling the Sout=
hern states with the laws they were passing" as you say.  That doesn't make=
 it true. The southern states relied on slaves to keep their economy operat=
ing, so any law addressing slavery would have had that effect. I am not sur=
prised that some people, at least in certain circles, still believe this to=
 be a clear fact however.  I suppose it would depend on who you asked.=0A=
=0AWars are rarely "about" just one thing. Maybe, just maybe, complicated q=
uestions don't always have simple answers.  Of course sometimes certain peo=
ple need to find simple explanations for complicated things, especially for=
 those things that are frightening to them. Simple answers give direction s=
and focus to the fear, at least for a little while.  The more thoughful amo=
ng us rarely find these simple explanations satisfying however.=0A=0AWhat a=
re you really afraid of Deepfog?  Maybe you should consult a spritual advis=
or, family member, or trusted friend. Preferably someone that knew you befo=
re you fell prey to the merchants of fear and hatred.  Because that's what =
they are.  Kidd and Rense and their friends profit directly from your fear =
and your hate.=0A=0AWho else profits from fear and hate?  This point is wor=
thy of some reflection IMO.=0A=0A=93I must not fear. Fear is the mind-kille=
r. Fear is the little-death that brings total obliteration. I will face my =
fear... And when it is gone past I will turn the inner eye to see its path.=
 Where the fear is gone there will be nothing. Only I will remain.=94 =0A=
=0A-- Paul Muad'Dib from Frank Herbert's Dune=0A=0APeace, =0A=0APeter =0A=

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: More White Power BS on SFRAVES...(was QOD)


I thought is was pretty muh a given that the civil war was about 
confederacy attempting to suceed from the Union, and the Union opposing 
that move.  Many issues were involved in why those states wanted to leave 
the union, Slavery being one of them, but the bottom line reason was that 
they didn't want to be part of the federal gov't and the federal gov't said 
"tough shit".

It's not much different any other country that splits in half and the sides 
start fighting over territory.  There's various issues, and individuals 
(Lincoln for example) will have their personal opinons on those issues, but 
going to war over them is another issue.

Afte rthe civil war the 14th and 15th ammendments were passed, both of 
which moving the country towards being more civilized and was one of the 
smarter things our gov't has done in it's history.  IMHO if the north was 
serious about the issues, they would have passed those ammendments or at 
least made them a law previous to the war.  IMHO the ammendments were 
passed in the same light as a campaign promise made good.  It's 
speculation, but based on general political movites, it pans out.

As for the use of the word perverted, it very easily could have been used, 
since it's meaning was different back then.  Pervert is taken form the 
latin word "perverto perverti perversum" which literally means "to turn 
upside down, overturn, overthrow."

Considering most of our educated leaders were versed in Latin, this is the 
way I interpret it.


At 09:09 AM 1/24/2007, dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
>The problem is did Lincoln actually ever say that?
>
>If you try to find the source of that quotation you won't find it. Or at 
>least I couldn't.
>
>Apparently Teddy Roosevelt actually said something like this in a paper he 
>wrote in 1913 . 
>(http://teachingamericanhistory.org/library/index.asp?document=1140)
>
>I couldn't find a source for the quotation Roosevelt uses however. I'd 
>guess this is most likely a paraphrase of something Lincoln actually said 
>in his inaugural speech in 1861. See 
>http://www.famousquotes.me.uk/speeches/Abraham_Lincoln/1.htm I don't have 
>time today to do more thorough research, so you'll have to form your own 
>opinion or do your own research.
>
>One point to keep in mind, note the differences in language usage between 
>Lincoln's actual speech and this purported quotation.  Personally I'm a 
>bit skeptical that a public figure would have used the word "perverted" in 
>a speech in the 1860s.  Maybe I am mistaken.
>
>As far as this book, G. Edward Griffin is merely retelling a story first 
>reported in a previous book by Eustace Mullins. If you want to learn more 
>about the origins of this story, you should go to the source and that's 
>Eustace Mullins.
>
>I'd encourage everyone to do their own research about Mullins, but in case 
>you want some quick starting points:
>
>http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eustace_Mullins
>http://www.rense.com/general39/EUSTACE.htm
>http://www.rense.com/general72/contract.htm
>
>As usual these people's own words are the best place to start 
>understanding their true beliefs.
>
>I am certain that many in the Confederacy believed that "the Civil War was 
>not about slavery" but about "the Northern states economically strangling 
>the Southern states with the laws they were passing" as you say.  That 
>doesn't make it true. The southern states relied on slaves to keep their 
>economy operating, so any law addressing slavery would have had that 
>effect. I am not surprised that some people, at least in certain circles, 
>still believe this to be a clear fact however.  I suppose it would depend 
>on who you asked.
>
>Wars are rarely "about" just one thing. Maybe, just maybe, complicated 
>questions don't always have simple answers.  Of course sometimes certain 
>people need to find simple explanations for complicated things, especially 
>for those things that are frightening to them. Simple answers give 
>direction sand focus to the fear, at least for a little while.  The more 
>thoughful among us rarely find these simple explanations satisfying however.
>
>What are you really afraid of Deepfog?  Maybe you should consult a 
>spritual advisor, family member, or trusted friend. Preferably someone 
>that knew you before you fell prey to the merchants of fear and 
>hatred.  Because that's what they are.  Kidd and Rense and their friends 
>profit directly from your fear and your hate.
>
>Who else profits from fear and hate?  This point is worthy of some 
>reflection IMO.
>
>"I must not fear. Fear is the mind-killer. Fear is the little-death that 
>brings total obliteration. I will face my fear... And when it is gone past 
>I will turn the inner eye to see its path. Where the fear is gone there 
>will be nothing. Only I will remain."
>
>-- Paul Muad'Dib from Frank Herbert's Dune
>
>Peace,

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: More White Power BS on SFRAVES...(was QOD)

I'm no historian, but your description matches essentially matches my under=
standing of those events.  However, it always seems questionable to me to s=
tate what any war is really about in one sentence or less.  How can you det=
ermine what a war is really about?=0A =0AFrom what I read this AM in Lincol=
n's speech, it is clear that there were already concerns about what he migh=
t do with the Southerner's "property" which, as a reminder happened to incl=
ude human beings, since he specifically addressed this issue in his speech.=
 He specifically says he won't free the slaves, so I assume he felt that he=
 needed to address this because some feared he would.  As you correctly poi=
nt out he didn't do that until after the war.=0A =0AIt also wasn't decided =
until after the war (in the 14th amendment) that slave owners would not be =
reimbursed for their losses due to the freeing of their slaves.  Therefore =
to say the war was really about harming the South economically when this wa=
sn't decided until after the war seems highly questionable to me.  Possibly=
 the slaves could have been freed and their former owners reimbursed for th=
eir losses had the South not seceded in the first place.  Maybe not, I wasn=
't there.=0A =0AFWIW, and fior the sake of completeness I'm happy to report=
 that after a bit of further research I've found the original source of thi=
s quotation,  in the Lincoln-Douglas debates in 1858.  (http://www.nps.gov/=
archive/liho/debates.htm) =0A=0AFWIW here's the full quotation in context:=
=0A =0A"I say that we must not interfere with the institution of slavery in=
 the States where it exists, because the Constitution forbids it, and the g=
eneral welfare does not require us to do so. We must not withhold an effici=
ent Fugitive Slave law, because the Constitution requires us, as I understa=
nd it, not to withhold such a law. But we must prevent the outspreading of =
the institution, because neither the Constitution nor general welfare requi=
res us to extend it. We must prevent the revival of the African slave-trade=
, and the enacting by Congress of a Territorial slave code. We must prevent=
 each of these things being done by either congresses or courts. The people=
 of these United States are the rightful masters of both congresses and cou=
rts, not to overthrow the Constitution, but to overthrow the men who perver=
t the Constitution.=0A=0ATo do these things we must employ instrumentalitie=
s. We must hold conventions; we must adopt platforms, if we conform to ordi=
nary custom; we must nominate candidates; and we must carry elections. In a=
ll these things, I think that we ought to keep in view our real purpose, an=
d in none do anything that stands adverse to our purpose. If we shall adopt=
 a platform that fails to recognize or express our purpose, or elect a man =
that declares himself inimical to our purpose, we not only take nothing by =
our success, but we tacitly admit that we act upon no other principle than =
a desire to have 'the loaves and fishes,' by which, in the end, our apparen=
t success is really an injury to us."=0A =0Ahttp://www.bartleby.com/251/pag=
es/page494.html=0A=0AIf you are interested, I'd advise going back a few pag=
es to read this in the full context of his entire speech.=0A=0ASo Griffin d=
id almost quote Lincoln correctly, though not accurately word for word, but=
 he's conveniently omitted the context in which it was said.  He's actually=
 arguing for the rule of law and against secession and armed rebellion here=
 I think.  He's arguing for practicality too.  Doing what needs to be done =
to win, rather than impractical idealism about freeing the slaves.  At leas=
t that's my interpretation.  YMMV.=0A =0APeace,=0A =0APeter=0A =0A=0A=0A---=

Subject: [sfraves] Tonal: Electric Blue underground this Sat w/ Q-Burns Abstract Message!

Sat Jan 27, Tonal: Electric Blue @ NEW Underground Location

Rock It Science, Prismatic Tracks, Crush Collective, SFHousemusic.com and
Blue Collar Entertainment Present

Tonal: Electric Blue

SF Location: call 888-482-9281 or 415-412-0406, or visit prismatictracks.com
or sfhousemusic.com the day of for directions
$10 before midnight, $15 after
$5 discount for dressing in Electric Blue (at door person's discretion)

Get ready for the first in a series of sick new color themed parties brought
to you by some of the hottest crews in the underground house scene. We are
teaming up to bring you only the best in funky, floorshaking underground
house music to keep you grooving until the break of dawn. Tonal parties will
showcase talent flown in from out of town as well as some of your favorite
local house jocks. Strap on your dancing shoes and get ready to move it!

DJ's:
Q-Burns Abstract Message (Eight Tracks, Blue Collar Entertainment, Orlando
FL)
We are very excited to bring Q-Burns here for the first installment of
Tonal! He brings a ton of energy to the decks and makes everybody freak out
on the dancefloor with his ultra funky track selection, seamless mixing, and
super-fun presence. Q-Burns is also quickly gaining notoriety for his
production and remixes, and rocks crowds all over the world. We are honored
to have him back to SF, one of his favorite cities. It's been too long!
http://www.q-burnsabstractmessage.com/

Leonard (In House, Tocadisco, SF)
What would SF's house scene be like without Mr. Leonard? One of the oldest
school heads around, Leonard has one of the sickest record collections in
our fine city. We look very much forward to seeing what Leonard pulls out of
the crates for a closing set not to be missed. www.myspace.com/djleonard

Andrew Phelan & Origami (Prismatic, Eight Tracks, SF)
One of SF's fastest growing duos in both the DJ and production realms,
Andrew and Origami put down some serious business. A Chicago native, Mr.
Phelan brings the funk just how we like it with Origami backing him up on
live bass keeping the speakers booming and your bodies moving!
www.prismatictracks.com

Eric Sharp (Rock It Science, SF)
Founder of the Rock It Science crew, Eric Sharp has quickly built a name for
himself with his infectious energy behind the decks and the versatility to
rock any party. Eric will throw down a 2 hour opening set, setting the vibe
just right for a night you will never forget. www.myspace.com/ericsharp

Finally keep your eyes peeled as well for Tonal: Fire Engine Red coming at
cha on Saturday, February 24th with Miles Maeda, Brown, and more!

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: More White Power BS on SFRAVES...(was QOD)

Lalalalala. I agree with Shatter's e-mail. From my understanding of
the civil war it was not about slavery, but it became about slavery
afterwards during reconstruction. Also, a lot of people started making
it about slavery once the civil rights movement took place in the
50's/60's and changed the whole meaning of the war.

This discussion has nothing to do with "white power BS" since it is
only about factual history and I'm pretty sure no one here is pro
slavery and all racism (even against white people) is ignorance.


On 1/24/07, dangrsmind@yahoo.com <dangrsmind@yahoo.com> wrote:
> I'm no historian, but your description matches essentially matches my understanding of those events.  However, it always seems questionable to me to state what any war is really about in one sentence or less.  How can you determine what a war is really about?
>
> From what I read this AM in Lincoln's speech, it is clear that there were already concerns about what he might do with the Southerner's "property" which, as a reminder happened to include human beings, since he specifically addressed this issue in his speech. He specifically says he won't free the slaves, so I assume he felt that he needed to address this because some feared he would.  As you correctly point out he didn't do that until after the war.
>
> It also wasn't decided until after the war (in the 14th amendment) that slave owners would not be reimbursed for their losses due to the freeing of their slaves.  Therefore to say the war was really about harming the South economically when this wasn't decided until after the war seems highly questionable to me.  Possibly the slaves could have been freed and their former owners reimbursed for their losses had the South not seceded in the first place.  Maybe not, I wasn't there.
>
> FWIW, and fior the sake of completeness I'm happy to report that after a bit of further research I've found the original source of this quotation,  in the Lincoln-Douglas debates in 1858.  (http://www.nps.gov/archive/liho/debates.htm)
>
> FWIW here's the full quotation in context:
>
> "I say that we must not interfere with the institution of slavery in the States where it exists, because the Constitution forbids it, and the general welfare does not require us to do so. We must not withhold an efficient Fugitive Slave law, because the Constitution requires us, as I understand it, not to withhold such a law. But we must prevent the outspreading of the institution, because neither the Constitution nor general welfare requires us to extend it. We must prevent the revival of the African slave-trade, and the enacting by Congress of a Territorial slave code. We must prevent each of these things being done by either congresses or courts. The people of these United States are the rightful masters of both congresses and courts, not to overthrow the Constitution, but to overthrow the men who pervert the Constitution.
>
> To do these things we must employ instrumentalities. We must hold conventions; we must adopt platforms, if we conform to ordinary custom; we must nominate candidates; and we must carry elections. In all these things, I think that we ought to keep in view our real purpose, and in none do anything that stands adverse to our purpose. If we shall adopt a platform that fails to recognize or express our purpose, or elect a man that declares himself inimical to our purpose, we not only take nothing by our success, but we tacitly admit that we act upon no other principle than a desire to have 'the loaves and fishes,' by which, in the end, our apparent success is really an injury to us."
>
> http://www.bartleby.com/251/pages/page494.html
>
> If you are interested, I'd advise going back a few pages to read this in the full context of his entire speech.
>
> So Griffin did almost quote Lincoln correctly, though not accurately word for word, but he's conveniently omitted the context in which it was said.  He's actually arguing for the rule of law and against secession and armed rebellion here I think.  He's arguing for practicality too.  Doing what needs to be done to win, rather than impractical idealism about freeing the slaves.  At least that's my interpretation.  YMMV.
>
> Peace,
>
> Peter
>
>
>
> ----- Original Message ----
> From: Shatter <shatter@sonic.net>
> To: dangrsmind@yahoo.com; Deepfog <sfgroove@deepfog.com>; sfraves@hyperreal.org
> Sent: Wednesday, January 24, 2007 12:14:28 PM
> Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: More White Power BS on SFRAVES...(was QOD)
>
>
> I thought is was pretty muh a given that the civil war was about
> confederacy attempting to suceed from the Union, and the Union opposing
> that move.  Many issues were involved in why those states wanted to leave
> the union, Slavery being one of them, but the bottom line reason was that
> they didn't want to be part of the federal gov't and the federal gov't said
> "tough shit".
>
> It's not much different any other country that splits in half and the sides
> start fighting over territory.  There's various issues, and individuals
> (Lincoln for example) will have their personal opinons on those issues, but
> going to war over them is another issue.
>
> Afte rthe civil war the 14th and 15th ammendments were passed, both of
> which moving the country towards being more civilized and was one of the
> smarter things our gov't has done in it's history.  IMHO if the north was
> serious about the issues, they would have passed those ammendments or at
> least made them a law previous to the war.  IMHO the ammendments were
> passed in the same light as a campaign promise made good.  It's
> speculation, but based on general political movites, it pans out.
>
> As for the use of the word perverted, it very easily could have been used,
> since it's meaning was different back then.  Pervert is taken form the
> latin word "perverto perverti perversum" which literally means "to turn
> upside down, overturn, overthrow."
>
> Considering most of our educated leaders were versed in Latin, this is the
> way I interpret it.
>
>
> At 09:09 AM 1/24/2007, dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
> >The problem is did Lincoln actually ever say that?
> >
> >If you try to find the source of that quotation you won't find it. Or at
> >least I couldn't.
> >
> >Apparently Teddy Roosevelt actually said something like this in a paper he
> >wrote in 1913 .
> >(http://teachingamericanhistory.org/library/index.asp?document=1140)
> >
> >I couldn't find a source for the quotation Roosevelt uses however. I'd
> >guess this is most likely a paraphrase of something Lincoln actually said
> >in his inaugural speech in 1861. See
> >http://www.famousquotes.me.uk/speeches/Abraham_Lincoln/1.htm I don't have
> >time today to do more thorough research, so you'll have to form your own
> >opinion or do your own research.
> >
> >One point to keep in mind, note the differences in language usage between
> >Lincoln's actual speech and this purported quotation.  Personally I'm a
> >bit skeptical that a public figure would have used the word "perverted" in
> >a speech in the 1860s.  Maybe I am mistaken.
> >
> >As far as this book, G. Edward Griffin is merely retelling a story first
> >reported in a previous book by Eustace Mullins. If you want to learn more
> >about the origins of this story, you should go to the source and that's
> >Eustace Mullins.
> >
> >I'd encourage everyone to do their own research about Mullins, but in case
> >you want some quick starting points:
> >
> >http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eustace_Mullins
> >http://www.rense.com/general39/EUSTACE.htm
> >http://www.rense.com/general72/contract.htm
> >
> >As usual these people's own words are the best place to start
> >understanding their true beliefs.
> >
> >I am certain that many in the Confederacy believed that "the Civil War was
> >not about slavery" but about "the Northern states economically strangling
> >the Southern states with the laws they were passing" as you say.  That
> >doesn't make it true. The southern states relied on slaves to keep their
> >economy operating, so any law addressing slavery would have had that
> >effect. I am not surprised that some people, at least in certain circles,
> >still believe this to be a clear fact however.  I suppose it would depend
> >on who you asked.
> >
> >Wars are rarely "about" just one thing. Maybe, just maybe, complicated
> >questions don't always have simple answers.  Of course sometimes certain
> >people need to find simple explanations for complicated things, especially
> >for those things that are frightening to them. Simple answers give
> >direction sand focus to the fear, at least for a little while.  The more
> >thoughful among us rarely find these simple explanations satisfying however.
> >
> >What are you really afraid of Deepfog?  Maybe you should consult a
> >spritual advisor, family member, or trusted friend. Preferably someone
> >that knew you before you fell prey to the merchants of fear and
> >hatred.  Because that's what they are.  Kidd and Rense and their friends
> >profit directly from your fear and your hate.
> >
> >Who else profits from fear and hate?  This point is worthy of some
> >reflection IMO.
> >
> >"I must not fear. Fear is the mind-killer. Fear is the little-death that
> >brings total obliteration. I will face my fear... And when it is gone past
> >I will turn the inner eye to see its path. Where the fear is gone there
> >will be nothing. Only I will remain."
> >
> >-- Paul Muad'Dib from Frank Herbert's Dune
> >
> >Peace,
> >
> >Peter
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >----- Original Message ----
> >From: Deepfog <sfgroove@deepfog.com>
> >To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
> >Sent: Wednesday, January 24, 2007 4:06:54 AM
> >Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Wed)
> >
> >
> >by the way, before anyone flies off the handle with accusations, i'll
> >just say there was more to the story i read but didn't include here
> >but don't have time right now to post so i'll just see if anyone has
> >any comments and i'll be back tonight maybe love you muah fog out
> >
> >Quoting Deepfog <sfgroove@deepfog.com>:
> >
> > > I find this to be an interesting quote. That book Creature from
> > > Jekyll Island I read recently claims the Civil War was not about
> > > ending slavery originally, it was about the Northern states
> > > economically strangling the Southern states with the laws they were
> > > passing. It even suggested that slavery was on its own way out the
> > > door into nonexistence, because the slave trade had already been
> > > abolished.
> > >
> > > Now before I read this book, I personally talked to a lot of people
> > > from the South, I'm talking North Carolina, South Carolina, Louisiana,
> > > Texas, of all ages, and they *all* agreed that the Civil War was not
> > > about slavery. So if this is true, why the war and why did I learn in
> > > all my history courses in high school and college differently? Was
> > > Lincoln manipulated? It reminds me of that saying that history is
> > > written by the victors. Are the schools really just government
> > > training camps?
> > >
> > > These questions I hope we will all turn the boob tube off for an hour
> > > today to ponder. Have a nice day, quote of the day out.

> > > overthrow the men who pervert it.

rm your own opinion.  I hadn't read it before today actually.  =0A=0AThe em=

her quotations Deepfog has been serving up daily for quite a while now.  =

power movement.  You can do your own research and determine this yourself. =
 =0A=0AIt is not just one posting either, but a daily barrage of this garba=
ge from Deepfog.  I'm just responding to that barrage by pointing out where=
 his quotations come from and what sort of people he's quoting.  Not everyo=
ne understands where these ideas are coming from and I'll keep contesting t=
hese ideas as long as he keeps posting them. =0A=0AI agree with you that al=
l racism is ignorance, and I'd suggest further that those that promote raci=
sm are both ignorant and afraid.  Personally I oppose spreading fear and ig=
norance, but obviously some disagree with me there.  =0A=0ARacism, ignoranc=
e, and fear are old problems that clearly aren't going to be solved here on=
 sfraves.  But they don't have to be promoted here either.  IMO.  YMMV. etc=
.=0A=0APeace,=0A=0APeter=0A=0A----- Original Message ----=0AFrom: Steve Ost=
een <sosteen@gmail.com>=0ATo: "dangrsmind@yahoo.com" <dangrsmind@yahoo.com>=

ala. I agree with Shatter's e-mail. From my understanding of=0Athe civil wa=
r it was not about slavery, but it became about slavery=0Aafterwards during=
 reconstruction. Also, a lot of people started making=0Ait about slavery on=
ce the civil rights movement took place in the=0A50's/60's and changed the =
whole meaning of the war.=0A=0AThis discussion has nothing to do with "whit=
e power BS" since it is=0Aonly about factual history and I'm pretty sure no=
 one here is pro=0Aslavery and all racism (even against white people) is ig=
norance.=0A=0A=0AOn 1/24/07, dangrsmind@yahoo.com <dangrsmind@yahoo.com> wr=
ote:=0A> I'm no historian, but your description matches essentially matches=
 my understanding of those events.  However, it always seems questionable t=
o me to state what any war is really about in one sentence or less.  How ca=
n you determine what a war is really about?=0A>=0A> From what I read this A=
M in Lincoln's speech, it is clear that there were already concerns about w=
hat he might do with the Southerner's "property" which, as a reminder happe=
ned to include human beings, since he specifically addressed this issue in =
his speech. He specifically says he won't free the slaves, so I assume he f=
elt that he needed to address this because some feared he would.  As you co=
rrectly point out he didn't do that until after the war.=0A>=0A> It also wa=
sn't decided until after the war (in the 14th amendment) that slave owners =
would not be reimbursed for their losses due to the freeing of their slaves=
.  Therefore to say the war was really about harming the South economically=
 when this wasn't decided until after the war seems highly questionable to =
me.  Possibly the slaves could have been freed and their former owners reim=
bursed for their losses had the South not seceded in the first place.  Mayb=
e not, I wasn't there.=0A>=0A> FWIW, and fior the sake of completeness I'm =
happy to report that after a bit of further research I've found the origina=
l source of this quotation,  in the Lincoln-Douglas debates in 1858.  (http=
://www.nps.gov/archive/liho/debates.htm)=0A>=0A> FWIW here's the full quota=
tion in context:=0A>=0A> "I say that we must not interfere with the institu=
tion of slavery in the States where it exists, because the Constitution for=
bids it, and the general welfare does not require us to do so. We must not =
withhold an efficient Fugitive Slave law, because the Constitution requires=
 us, as I understand it, not to withhold such a law. But we must prevent th=
e outspreading of the institution, because neither the Constitution nor gen=
eral welfare requires us to extend it. We must prevent the revival of the A=
frican slave-trade, and the enacting by Congress of a Territorial slave cod=
e. We must prevent each of these things being done by either congresses or =
courts. The people of these United States are the rightful masters of both =
congresses and courts, not to overthrow the Constitution, but to overthrow =
the men who pervert the Constitution.=0A>=0A> To do these things we must em=
ploy instrumentalities. We must hold conventions; we must adopt platforms, =
if we conform to ordinary custom; we must nominate candidates; and we must =
carry elections. In all these things, I think that we ought to keep in view=
 our real purpose, and in none do anything that stands adverse to our purpo=
se. If we shall adopt a platform that fails to recognize or express our pur=
pose, or elect a man that declares himself inimical to our purpose, we not =
only take nothing by our success, but we tacitly admit that we act upon no =
other principle than a desire to have 'the loaves and fishes,' by which, in=
 the end, our apparent success is really an injury to us."=0A>=0A> http://w=
ww.bartleby.com/251/pages/page494.html=0A>=0A> If you are interested, I'd a=
dvise going back a few pages to read this in the full context of his entire=
 speech.=0A>=0A> So Griffin did almost quote Lincoln correctly, though not =
accurately word for word, but he's conveniently omitted the context in whic=
h it was said.  He's actually arguing for the rule of law and against seces=
sion and armed rebellion here I think.  He's arguing for practicality too. =
 Doing what needs to be done to win, rather than impractical idealism about=
 freeing the slaves.  At least that's my interpretation.  YMMV.=0A>=0A> Pea=
ce,=0A>=0A> Peter=0A>=0A>=0A>=0A> ----- Original Message ----=0A> From: Sha=

Just wanted to refute this:

"and I'd suggest further that those that promote racism are both ignorant
and afraid."

never underestimate the intelligence of someone who has been able to
manipulate youth, i.e. :

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tom_Metzger
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Front
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Girnt_Butler

etc.

these people are not ignorant by any means, just sick twisted fucks.

i would argue on the whole civil war/slavery issue, but i was born and
raised in the south and i've seen compelling arguments on both sides. point
being, who gives a shit, it's not like we're going to start the slave trade
back up now that it's cheaper to have it automated(i.e. the cotton gin and
several other inventions would have killed it anyways, regardless)


On 1/24/07, dangrsmind@yahoo.com <dangrsmind@yahoo.com> wrote:
>
> As I said, IMO, it is hard to say what a war was really "about" especially
> more than a century after the fact.  Read the Lincoln-Douglas debate and
> form your own opinion.  I hadn't read it before today actually.
>
> The email title was a bit excessive perhaps, but IMO not in the context of
> the other quotations Deepfog has been serving up daily for quite a while
> now.
>
> Griffin, Devvy Kidd and Jeff Rense are deeply connected to the white power
> movement.  You can do your own research and determine this yourself.
>
> It is not just one posting either, but a daily barrage of this garbage
> from Deepfog.  I'm just responding to that barrage by pointing out where his
> quotations come from and what sort of people he's quoting.  Not everyone
> understands where these ideas are coming from and I'll keep contesting these
> ideas as long as he keeps posting them.
>
> I agree with you that all racism is ignorance, and I'd suggest further
> that those that promote racism are both ignorant and afraid.  Personally I
> oppose spreading fear and ignorance, but obviously some disagree with me
> there.
>
> Racism, ignorance, and fear are old problems that clearly aren't going to
> be solved here on sfraves.  But they don't have to be promoted here
> either.  IMO.  YMMV. etc.

> ----- Original Message ----
> From: Steve Osteen <sosteen@gmail.com>
> To: "dangrsmind@yahoo.com" <dangrsmind@yahoo.com>
> Cc: Shatter <shatter@sonic.net>; Deepfog <sfgroove@deepfog.com>;
> sfraves@hyperreal.org
> Sent: Wednesday, January 24, 2007 3:27:42 PM
> Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: More White Power BS on SFRAVES...(was QOD)
>
>
> Lalalalala. I agree with Shatter's e-mail. From my understanding of
> the civil war it was not about slavery, but it became about slavery
> afterwards during reconstruction. Also, a lot of people started making
> it about slavery once the civil rights movement took place in the
> 50's/60's and changed the whole meaning of the war.
>
> This discussion has nothing to do with "white power BS" since it is
> only about factual history and I'm pretty sure no one here is pro
> slavery and all racism (even against white people) is ignorance.
>
>
> On 1/24/07, dangrsmind@yahoo.com <dangrsmind@yahoo.com> wrote:
> > I'm no historian, but your description matches essentially matches my
> understanding of those events.  However, it always seems questionable to me
> to state what any war is really about in one sentence or less.  How can you
> determine what a war is really about?
> >
> > From what I read this AM in Lincoln's speech, it is clear that there
> were already concerns about what he might do with the Southerner's
> "property" which, as a reminder happened to include human beings, since he
> specifically addressed this issue in his speech. He specifically says he
> won't free the slaves, so I assume he felt that he needed to address this
> because some feared he would.  As you correctly point out he didn't do that
> until after the war.
> >
> > It also wasn't decided until after the war (in the 14th amendment) that
> slave owners would not be reimbursed for their losses due to the freeing of
> their slaves.  Therefore to say the war was really about harming the South
> economically when this wasn't decided until after the war seems highly
> questionable to me.  Possibly the slaves could have been freed and their
> former owners reimbursed for their losses had the South not seceded in the
> first place.  Maybe not, I wasn't there.
> >
> > FWIW, and fior the sake of completeness I'm happy to report that after a
> bit of further research I've found the original source of this
> quotation,  in the Lincoln-Douglas debates in 1858.  (
> http://www.nps.gov/archive/liho/debates.htm)
> >
> > FWIW here's the full quotation in context:
> >
> > "I say that we must not interfere with the institution of slavery in the
> States where it exists, because the Constitution forbids it, and the general
> welfare does not require us to do so. We must not withhold an efficient
> Fugitive Slave law, because the Constitution requires us, as I understand
> it, not to withhold such a law. But we must prevent the outspreading of the
> institution, because neither the Constitution nor general welfare requires
> us to extend it. We must prevent the revival of the African slave-trade, and
> the enacting by Congress of a Territorial slave code. We must prevent each
> of these things being done by either congresses or courts. The people of
> these United States are the rightful masters of both congresses and courts,
> not to overthrow the Constitution, but to overthrow the men who pervert the
> Constitution.
> >
> > To do these things we must employ instrumentalities. We must hold
> conventions; we must adopt platforms, if we conform to ordinary custom; we
> must nominate candidates; and we must carry elections. In all these things,
> I think that we ought to keep in view our real purpose, and in none do
> anything that stands adverse to our purpose. If we shall adopt a platform
> that fails to recognize or express our purpose, or elect a man that declares
> himself inimical to our purpose, we not only take nothing by our success,
> but we tacitly admit that we act upon no other principle than a desire to
> have 'the loaves and fishes,' by which, in the end, our apparent success is
> really an injury to us."
> >
> > http://www.bartleby.com/251/pages/page494.html
> >
> > If you are interested, I'd advise going back a few pages to read this in
> the full context of his entire speech.
> >
> > So Griffin did almost quote Lincoln correctly, though not accurately
> word for word, but he's conveniently omitted the context in which it was
> said.  He's actually arguing for the rule of law and against secession and
> armed rebellion here I think.  He's arguing for practicality too.  Doing
> what needs to be done to win, rather than impractical idealism about freeing
> the slaves.  At least that's my interpretation.  YMMV.
> >
> > Peace,
> >
> > Peter
> >
> >
> >

> > I thought is was pretty muh a given that the civil war was about
> > confederacy attempting to suceed from the Union, and the Union opposing

> leave
> > the union, Slavery being one of them, but the bottom line reason was
> that
> > they didn't want to be part of the federal gov't and the federal gov't
> said
> > "tough shit".
> >
> > It's not much different any other country that splits in half and the
> sides
> > start fighting over territory.  There's various issues, and individuals
> > (Lincoln for example) will have their personal opinons on those issues,
> but
> > going to war over them is another issue.
> >
> > Afte rthe civil war the 14th and 15th ammendments were passed, both of
> > which moving the country towards being more civilized and was one of the
> > smarter things our gov't has done in it's history.  IMHO if the north
> was
> > serious about the issues, they would have passed those ammendments or at
> > least made them a law previous to the war.  IMHO the ammendments were
> > passed in the same light as a campaign promise made good.  It's
> > speculation, but based on general political movites, it pans out.
> >
> > As for the use of the word perverted, it very easily could have been
> used,
> > since it's meaning was different back then.  Pervert is taken form the
> > latin word "perverto perverti perversum" which literally means "to turn
> > upside down, overturn, overthrow."
> >
> > Considering most of our educated leaders were versed in Latin, this is
> the
> > way I interpret it.
> >
> >
> > At 09:09 AM 1/24/2007, dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:

> > >
> > >I couldn't find a source for the quotation Roosevelt uses however. I'd
> > >guess this is most likely a paraphrase of something Lincoln actually
> said
> > >in his inaugural speech in 1861. See
> > >http://www.famousquotes.me.uk/speeches/Abraham_Lincoln/1.htm I don't
> have
> > >time today to do more thorough research, so you'll have to form your
> own
> > >opinion or do your own research.
> > >
> > >One point to keep in mind, note the differences in language usage
> between
> > >Lincoln's actual speech and this purported quotation.  Personally I'm a
> > >bit skeptical that a public figure would have used the word "perverted"
> in
> > >a speech in the 1860s.  Maybe I am mistaken.
> > >
> > >As far as this book, G. Edward Griffin is merely retelling a story
> first
> > >reported in a previous book by Eustace Mullins. If you want to learn
> more
> > >about the origins of this story, you should go to the source and that's
> > >Eustace Mullins.
> > >
> > >I'd encourage everyone to do their own research about Mullins, but in
> case
> > >you want some quick starting points:
> > >
> > >http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eustace_Mullins
> > >http://www.rense.com/general39/EUSTACE.htm
> > >http://www.rense.com/general72/contract.htm
> > >
> > >As usual these people's own words are the best place to start
> > >understanding their true beliefs.
> > >
> > >I am certain that many in the Confederacy believed that "the Civil War
> was
> > >not about slavery" but about "the Northern states economically
> strangling
> > >the Southern states with the laws they were passing" as you say.  That
> > >doesn't make it true. The southern states relied on slaves to keep
> their
> > >economy operating, so any law addressing slavery would have had that
> > >effect. I am not surprised that some people, at least in certain
> circles,
> > >still believe this to be a clear fact however.  I suppose it would
> depend
> > >on who you asked.
> > >
> > >Wars are rarely "about" just one thing. Maybe, just maybe, complicated
> > >questions don't always have simple answers.  Of course sometimes
> certain
> > >people need to find simple explanations for complicated things,
> especially
> > >for those things that are frightening to them. Simple answers give
> > >direction sand focus to the fear, at least for a little while.  The
> more
> > >thoughful among us rarely find these simple explanations satisfying
> however.
> > >
> > >What are you really afraid of Deepfog?  Maybe you should consult a
> > >spritual advisor, family member, or trusted friend. Preferably someone

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: More White Power BS on SFRAVES...(was QOD)


Wars are NEVER about a single issue, there is always ulertior motives.

My statement was more towards the political and constitutional reasons 
behind the war.  Lincoln was first and foremost a believer in "United We 
Stand" and as such, splitting the union would be one of the worst things to 
happen to the country.  If you go back farther to the Federalist papers and 
such, you'll find a lot of talk about theevil of Factions, which is 
essentially what the confederacy was all about.  It was a Faction that 
didn't agree with teh Union, and therefore would be a seperatists and form 
their own nation, with currency.  Anyone who invested in Conferderacy Bills 
lost quite a bit of money in that bank.

The extended quote you posted is VERY good, as it's showing exactly my 
point about the war, motives, and legalities.  The ideas of hindering or 
helping.  Allowing but not encouraging.  Existing without growing.  Lincoln 
opposed Slavery.  This can't be argued.  However could he launch a war 
against the south on teh general principal?  No.  Slavery was not illeagal 
or unconstitutional.  Might as well have a President launch a war against 
the farmlands for use of a Tractor (which at that times was the same as a 
slave).  As previous to the ammendment, Black's wern't even counted as a 
whole person for reasons of census and voting.  Remember also that at the 
time, all men did not get an equal vote, but the LANDOWNERS that got a 
vote, with the amount of slaves owned giving additional votes for that 
landowner.  This was all constuitutionally legal.  (This all also makes for 
great arguments when people say we need to reinstate our original costitution!)

Thus, the civil was was fought on the basis that the southers states formed 
a Faction with the intent of seperating and forming their own independent 
nation, away from the United States.  Everything else regarding the war 
were details and pork barrel concerns.  It wasn't the slaves per se, but 
the concept of slavery, and states rights over federal rights.

If you study constitutional history (very facinating imho) you will see the 
basis of all aspects of our government, both state level and federal.  Why 
we have two Senators and a bunch of reps.  Senators are representative of 
the right of the states, all states being equal (100 total) and the 
Representatives are to represent the people, based on population 
density.  Under the Articles of conferation (1776) the states were VERY 
autonomous, printing their own currency, having their own laws, and 
such.  It wasn't until the Constitutional Convention (1789) that the 
Constitution was drafted because the Articles just wasn't working.  Quite a 
bit of the writing from the constitution can be found in the Federalist 
papers which were written by the Founding Father under various pen 
names.  They also borrowed quite a bit from John Calvin and Thomas Hobbs 
(Leviathon specifically).

The south felt that States autonomy wasn't being properly represented, in 
regards to the Slave Trade.  They wanted to do as they liked.  In truth, 
this could have been anything trades or prodiced, and included those as 
well such as suger, cotton, grains, etc.  They didn't like the Taxes, 
Tariffs, trade restrictions that were being imposed.    They felt the 
Federal Gov't was over stepping it's bounds.

The honest truth was that they had come to become so dependent on Slave 
labor that the entire economy would have shut down without it, and you can 
draw several lines between this and the migrant worker situation of today, 
and our reliance on foreign made goods from 3rd world nations and China.

Lincoln was no fool, and that's why in the quote he even stated that 
stopping slavery wasn't the concern, but preventing it's EXPANSION was.  To 
complete abolish would cayse a major economic depression.  Continued 
expasion would only cause a greater relience and dependence on it, so it 
had to stop, however it had to stop in an accorded and planned method to 
transition out of itm which is what they're always talking about when they 
say "Greater Good"


*sigh*  ya, I can go on for hours about this stuff....     ;)


At 02:54 PM 1/24/2007, dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
>I'm no historian, but your description matches essentially matches my 
>understanding of those events.  However, it always seems questionable to 
>me to state what any war is really about in one sentence or less.  How can 
>you determine what a war is really about?
>
> From what I read this AM in Lincoln's speech, it is clear that there were 
> already concerns about what he might do with the Southerner's "property" 
> which, as a reminder happened to include human beings, since he 
> specifically addressed this issue in his speech. He specifically says he 
> won't free the slaves, so I assume he felt that he needed to address this 
> because some feared he would.  As you correctly point out he didn't do 
> that until after the war.
>
>It also wasn't decided until after the war (in the 14th amendment) that 
>slave owners would not be reimbursed for their losses due to the freeing 
>of their slaves.  Therefore to say the war was really about harming the 
>South economically when this wasn't decided until after the war seems 
>highly questionable to me.  Possibly the slaves could have been freed and 
>their former owners reimbursed for their losses had the South not seceded 
>in the first place.  Maybe not, I wasn't there.
>
>FWIW, and fior the sake of completeness I'm happy to report that after a 
>bit of further research I've found the original source of this 
>quotation,  in the Lincoln-Douglas debates in 
>1858.  (http://www.nps.gov/archive/liho/debates.htm)
>
>FWIW here's the full quotation in context:
>
>"I say that we must not interfere with the institution of slavery in the 
>States where it exists, because the Constitution forbids it, and the 
>general welfare does not require us to do so. We must not withhold an 
>efficient Fugitive Slave law, because the Constitution requires us, as I 
>understand it, not to withhold such a law. But we must prevent the 
>outspreading of the institution, because neither the Constitution nor 
>general welfare requires us to extend it. We must prevent the revival of 
>the African slave-trade, and the enacting by Congress of a Territorial 
>slave code. We must prevent each of these things being done by either 
>congresses or courts. The people of these United States are the rightful 
>masters of both congresses and courts, not to overthrow the Constitution, 
>but to overthrow the men who pervert the Constitution.
>
>To do these things we must employ instrumentalities. We must hold 
>conventions; we must adopt platforms, if we conform to ordinary custom; we 
>must nominate candidates; and we must carry elections. In all these 
>things, I think that we ought to keep in view our real purpose, and in 
>none do anything that stands adverse to our purpose. If we shall adopt a 
>platform that fails to recognize or express our purpose, or elect a man 
>that declares himself inimical to our purpose, we not only take nothing by 
>our success, but we tacitly admit that we act upon no other principle than 
>a desire to have 'the loaves and fishes,' by which, in the end, our 
>apparent success is really an injury to us."
>
>http://www.bartleby.com/251/pages/page494.html
>
>If you are interested, I'd advise going back a few pages to read this in 
>the full context of his entire speech.
>
>So Griffin did almost quote Lincoln correctly, though not accurately word 
>for word, but he's conveniently omitted the context in which it was 
>said.  He's actually arguing for the rule of law and against secession and 
>armed rebellion here I think.  He's arguing for practicality too.  Doing 
>what needs to be done to win, rather than impractical idealism about 
>freeing the slaves.  At least that's my interpretation.  YMMV.
>
>Peace,
>
>Peter
>
>
>

>
>I thought is was pretty muh a given that the civil war was about
>confederacy attempting to suceed from the Union, and the Union opposing
>that move.  Many issues were involved in why those states wanted to leave
>the union, Slavery being one of them, but the bottom line reason was that
>they didn't want to be part of the federal gov't and the federal gov't said
>"tough shit".
>
>It's not much different any other country that splits in half and the sides
>start fighting over territory.  There's various issues, and individuals
>(Lincoln for example) will have their personal opinons on those issues, but
>going to war over them is another issue.
>
>Afte rthe civil war the 14th and 15th ammendments were passed, both of
>which moving the country towards being more civilized and was one of the
>smarter things our gov't has done in it's history.  IMHO if the north was
>serious about the issues, they would have passed those ammendments or at
>least made them a law previous to the war.  IMHO the ammendments were
>passed in the same light as a campaign promise made good.  It's
>speculation, but based on general political movites, it pans out.
>
>As for the use of the word perverted, it very easily could have been used,
>since it's meaning was different back then.  Pervert is taken form the
>latin word "perverto perverti perversum" which literally means "to turn
>upside down, overturn, overthrow."
>
>Considering most of our educated leaders were versed in Latin, this is the
>way I interpret it.
>
>
>At 09:09 AM 1/24/2007, dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:

> >wrote in 1913 .

> >I couldn't find a source for the quotation Roosevelt uses however. I'd
> >guess this is most likely a paraphrase of something Lincoln actually said
> >in his inaugural speech in 1861. See
> >http://www.famousquotes.me.uk/speeches/Abraham_Lincoln/1.htm I don't have
> >time today to do more thorough research, so you'll have to form your own
> >opinion or do your own research.
> >
> >One point to keep in mind, note the differences in language usage between
> >Lincoln's actual speech and this purported quotation.  Personally I'm a
> >bit skeptical that a public figure would have used the word "perverted" in
> >a speech in the 1860s.  Maybe I am mistaken.
> >
> >As far as this book, G. Edward Griffin is merely retelling a story first
> >reported in a previous book by Eustace Mullins. If you want to learn more
> >about the origins of this story, you should go to the source and that's
> >Eustace Mullins.
> >
> >I'd encourage everyone to do their own research about Mullins, but in case
> >you want some quick starting points:

> >http://www.rense.com/general72/contract.htm
> >
> >As usual these people's own words are the best place to start
> >understanding their true beliefs.
> >
> >I am certain that many in the Confederacy believed that "the Civil War was
> >not about slavery" but about "the Northern states economically strangling
> >the Southern states with the laws they were passing" as you say.  That
> >doesn't make it true. The southern states relied on slaves to keep their
> >economy operating, so any law addressing slavery would have had that
> >effect. I am not surprised that some people, at least in certain circles,
> >still believe this to be a clear fact however.  I suppose it would depend
> >on who you asked.
> >
> >Wars are rarely "about" just one thing. Maybe, just maybe, complicated

> >people need to find simple explanations for complicated things, especially

> >thoughful among us rarely find these simple explanations satisfying however.

The problem I think that's being really adressed is that there, in recent 
years, has been a problem with "Revisionist" history, in which people put 
out books attempting to change our view of history.  Books that demonize 
the founding fathers (Jefferson and his slave relations) or discredit them 
(Lincoln was gay!!  OMG!  Who cares!) and such.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Wed)

you had some different history lessons than me, I guess that explains 
a lot, really.

I didn't learn that the Civil War was all about slavery - it was 
involved certainly, but the north passed laws allowing it's 
industrial center to grow and prosper, and not the farming that was 
going on in the south.  Slavery wasn't an accepted practice in other 
countries at the time, but we needed the war to put those ornery 
southerners in their place.


sarilion

At 03:57 AM 1/24/2007, Deepfog wrote:
>I find this to be an interesting quote.  That book Creature from
>Jekyll Island I read recently claims the Civil War was not about
>ending slavery originally, it was about the Northern states
>economically strangling the Southern states with the laws they were
>passing.  It even suggested that slavery was on its own way out the
>door into nonexistence, because the slave trade had already been
>abolished.
>
>Now before I read this book, I personally talked to a lot of people
>from the South, I'm talking North Carolina, South Carolina, Louisiana,
>Texas, of all ages, and they *all* agreed that the Civil War was not
>about slavery.  So if this is true, why the war and why did I learn in
>all my history courses in high school and college differently?  Was

> Lalalalala. I agree with Shatter's e-mail. From my understanding of
> the civil war it was not about slavery, but it became about slavery
> afterwards during reconstruction. Also, a lot of people started making
> it about slavery once the civil rights movement took place in the
> 50's/60's and changed the whole meaning of the war.
>
> This discussion has nothing to do with "white power BS" since it is
> only about factual history and I'm pretty sure no one here is pro

> On 1/24/07, dangrsmind@yahoo.com <dangrsmind@yahoo.com> wrote:
>> I'm no historian, but your description matches essentially matches  
>> my understanding of those events.  However, it always seems  
>> questionable to me to state what any war is really about in one  
>> sentence or less.  How can you determine what a war is really about?
>>
>> From what I read this AM in Lincoln's speech, it is clear that  
>> there were already concerns about what he might do with the  
>> Southerner's "property" which, as a reminder happened to include  
>> human beings, since he specifically addressed this issue in his  
>> speech. He specifically says he won't free the slaves, so I assume  
>> he felt that he needed to address this because some feared he  
>> would.  As you correctly point out he didn't do that until after  
>> the war.
>>
>> It also wasn't decided until after the war (in the 14th amendment)  
>> that slave owners would not be reimbursed for their losses due to  
>> the freeing of their slaves.  Therefore to say the war was really  
>> about harming the South economically when this wasn't decided  
>> until after the war seems highly questionable to me.  Possibly the  
>> slaves could have been freed and their former owners reimbursed  
>> for their losses had the South not seceded in the first place.   
>> Maybe not, I wasn't there.
>>
>> FWIW, and fior the sake of completeness I'm happy to report that  
>> after a bit of further research I've found the original source of  
>> this quotation,  in the Lincoln-Douglas debates in 1858.  (http:// 
>> www.nps.gov/archive/liho/debates.htm)
>>
>> FWIW here's the full quotation in context:
>>
>> "I say that we must not interfere with the institution of slavery  
>> in the States where it exists, because the Constitution forbids  
>> it, and the general welfare does not require us to do so. We must  
>> not withhold an efficient Fugitive Slave law, because the  
>> Constitution requires us, as I understand it, not to withhold such  
>> a law. But we must prevent the outspreading of the institution,  
>> because neither the Constitution nor general welfare requires us  
>> to extend it. We must prevent the revival of the African slave- 
>> trade, and the enacting by Congress of a Territorial slave code.  
>> We must prevent each of these things being done by either  
>> congresses or courts. The people of these United States are the  
>> rightful masters of both congresses and courts, not to overthrow  
>> the Constitution, but to overthrow the men who pervert the  
>> Constitution.
>>
>> To do these things we must employ instrumentalities. We must hold  
>> conventions; we must adopt platforms, if we conform to ordinary  
>> custom; we must nominate candidates; and we must carry elections.  
>> In all these things, I think that we ought to keep in view our  
>> real purpose, and in none do anything that stands adverse to our  
>> purpose. If we shall adopt a platform that fails to recognize or  
>> express our purpose, or elect a man that declares himself inimical  
>> to our purpose, we not only take nothing by our success, but we  
>> tacitly admit that we act upon no other principle than a desire to  
>> have 'the loaves and fishes,' by which, in the end, our apparent  
>> success is really an injury to us."
>>
>> http://www.bartleby.com/251/pages/page494.html
>>
>> If you are interested, I'd advise going back a few pages to read  
>> this in the full context of his entire speech.
>>
>> So Griffin did almost quote Lincoln correctly, though not  
>> accurately word for word, but he's conveniently omitted the  
>> context in which it was said.  He's actually arguing for the rule  
>> of law and against secession and armed rebellion here I think.   
>> He's arguing for practicality too.  Doing what needs to be done to  
>> win, rather than impractical idealism about freeing the slaves.   
>> At least that's my interpretation.  YMMV.
>>
>> Peace,
>>
>> Peter
>>
>>
>>

>> At 09:09 AM 1/24/2007, dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
>>> The problem is did Lincoln actually ever say that?
>>>
>>> If you try to find the source of that quotation you won't find  
>>> it. Or at
>>> least I couldn't.
>>>
>>> Apparently Teddy Roosevelt actually said something like this in a  
>>> paper he
>>> wrote in 1913 .
>>> (http://teachingamericanhistory.org/library/index.asp?document=1140)
>>>
>>> I couldn't find a source for the quotation Roosevelt uses  
>>> however. I'd
>>> guess this is most likely a paraphrase of something Lincoln  
>>> actually said
>>> in his inaugural speech in 1861. See
>>> http://www.famousquotes.me.uk/speeches/Abraham_Lincoln/1.htm I  
>>> don't have
>>> time today to do more thorough research, so you'll have to form  
>>> your own
>>> opinion or do your own research.
>>>
>>> One point to keep in mind, note the differences in language usage  
>>> between
>>> Lincoln's actual speech and this purported quotation.  Personally  
>>> I'm a
>>> bit skeptical that a public figure would have used the word  
>>> "perverted" in
>>> a speech in the 1860s.  Maybe I am mistaken.
>>>
>>> As far as this book, G. Edward Griffin is merely retelling a  
>>> story first
>>> reported in a previous book by Eustace Mullins. If you want to  
>>> learn more
>>> about the origins of this story, you should go to the source and  
>>> that's
>>> Eustace Mullins.
>>>
>>> I'd encourage everyone to do their own research about Mullins,  
>>> but in case
>>> you want some quick starting points:
>>>
>>> http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eustace_Mullins
>>> http://www.rense.com/general39/EUSTACE.htm
>>> http://www.rense.com/general72/contract.htm
>>>
>>> As usual these people's own words are the best place to start
>>> understanding their true beliefs.
>>>
>>> I am certain that many in the Confederacy believed that "the  
>>> Civil War was
>>> not about slavery" but about "the Northern states economically  
>>> strangling
>>> the Southern states with the laws they were passing" as you say.   
>>> That
>>> doesn't make it true. The southern states relied on slaves to  
>>> keep their
>>> economy operating, so any law addressing slavery would have had that
>>> effect. I am not surprised that some people, at least in certain  
>>> circles,
>>> still believe this to be a clear fact however.  I suppose it  
>>> would depend
>>> on who you asked.
>>>
>>> Wars are rarely "about" just one thing. Maybe, just maybe,  
>>> complicated
>>> questions don't always have simple answers.  Of course sometimes  
>>> certain
>>> people need to find simple explanations for complicated things,  
>>> especially
>>> for those things that are frightening to them. Simple answers give
>>> direction sand focus to the fear, at least for a little while.   
>>> The more
>>> thoughful among us rarely find these simple explanations  
>>> satisfying however.
>>>
>>> What are you really afraid of Deepfog?  Maybe you should consult a

>>> friends
>>> profit directly from your fear and your hate.
>>>

>>> there

>>>> Jekyll Island I read recently claims the Civil War was not about

>>>> economically strangling the Southern states with the laws they were

>>>> abolished.

>>>> Louisiana,

>>>> not

>>>> learn in

 FWIW here's the full quotation in context:=0A>>=0A>> "I say that we must n=
ot interfere with the institution of slavery  =0A>> in the States where it =
exists, because the Constitution forbids  =0A>> it, and the general welfare=
 does not require us to do so. We must  =0A>> not withhold an efficient Fug=
itive Slave law, because the  =0A>> Constitution requires us, as I understa=
nd it, not to withhold such  =0A>> a law. But we must prevent the outspread=
ing of the institution,  =0A>> because neither the Constitution nor general=
 welfare requires us  =0A>> to extend it. We must prevent the revival of th=
e African slave- =0A>> trade, and the enacting by Congress of a Territorial=
 slave code.  =0A>> We must prevent each of these things being done by eith=
er  =0A>> congresses or courts. The people of these United States are the  =
=0A>> rightful masters of both congresses and courts, not to overthrow  =0A=
>> the Constitution, but to overthrow the men who pervert the  =0A>> Consti=
tution.=0A>>=0A>> To do these things we must employ instrumentalities. We m=
ust hold  =0A>> conventions; we must adopt platforms, if we conform to ordi=
nary  =0A>> custom; we must nominate candidates; and we must carry election=
s.  =0A>> In all these things, I think that we ought to keep in view our  =
=0A>> real purpose, and in none do anything that stands adverse to our  =0A=
>> purpose. If we shall adopt a platform that fails to recognize or  =0A>> =
express our purpose, or elect a man that declares himself inimical  =0A>> t=
o our purpose, we not only take nothing by our success, but we  =0A>> tacit=
ly admit that we act upon no other principle than a desire to  =0A>> have '=
the loaves and fishes,' by which, in the end, our apparent  =0A>> success i=
s really an injury to us."=0A>>=0A>> http://www.bartleby.com/251/pages/page=
494.html=0A>>=0A>> If you are interested, I'd advise going back a few pages=

>> promoted here either.  IMO.  YMMV. etc.

>> Lalalalala. I agree with Shatter's e-mail. From my understanding of
>> the civil war it was not about slavery, but it became about slavery
>> afterwards during reconstruction. Also, a lot of people started  
>> making

>> 50's/60's and changed the whole meaning of the war.

>> On 1/24/07, dangrsmind@yahoo.com <dangrsmind@yahoo.com> wrote:
>>> I'm no historian, but your description matches essentially matches
>>> my understanding of those events.  However, it always seems
>>> questionable to me to state what any war is really about in one
>>> sentence or less.  How can you determine what a war is really about?
>>>
>>> From what I read this AM in Lincoln's speech, it is clear that
>>> there were already concerns about what he might do with the
>>> Southerner's "property" which, as a reminder happened to include
>>> human beings, since he specifically addressed this issue in his
>>> speech. He specifically says he won't free the slaves, so I assume
>>> he felt that he needed to address this because some feared he
>>> would.  As you correctly point out he didn't do that until after
>>> the war.
>>>
>>> It also wasn't decided until after the war (in the 14th amendment)
>>> that slave owners would not be reimbursed for their losses due to
>>> the freeing of their slaves.  Therefore to say the war was really
>>> about harming the South economically when this wasn't decided
>>> until after the war seems highly questionable to me.  Possibly the
>>> slaves could have been freed and their former owners reimbursed
>>> for their losses had the South not seceded in the first place.
>>> Maybe not, I wasn't there.
>>>
>>> FWIW, and fior the sake of completeness I'm happy to report that
>>> after a bit of further research I've found the original source of
>>> this quotation,  in the Lincoln-Douglas debates in 1858.  (http://
>>> www.nps.gov/archive/liho/debates.htm)
>>>
>>> FWIW here's the full quotation in context:
>>>
>>> "I say that we must not interfere with the institution of slavery
>>> in the States where it exists, because the Constitution forbids
>>> it, and the general welfare does not require us to do so. We must
>>> not withhold an efficient Fugitive Slave law, because the
>>> Constitution requires us, as I understand it, not to withhold such
>>> a law. But we must prevent the outspreading of the institution,
>>> because neither the Constitution nor general welfare requires us
>>> to extend it. We must prevent the revival of the African slave-
>>> trade, and the enacting by Congress of a Territorial slave code.
>>> We must prevent each of these things being done by either
>>> congresses or courts. The people of these United States are the
>>> rightful masters of both congresses and courts, not to overthrow
>>> the Constitution, but to overthrow the men who pervert the
>>> Constitution.
>>>
>>> To do these things we must employ instrumentalities. We must hold
>>> conventions; we must adopt platforms, if we conform to ordinary
>>> custom; we must nominate candidates; and we must carry elections.
>>> In all these things, I think that we ought to keep in view our
>>> real purpose, and in none do anything that stands adverse to our
>>> purpose. If we shall adopt a platform that fails to recognize or
>>> express our purpose, or elect a man that declares himself inimical
>>> to our purpose, we not only take nothing by our success, but we
>>> tacitly admit that we act upon no other principle than a desire to
>>> have 'the loaves and fishes,' by which, in the end, our apparent
>>> success is really an injury to us."
>>>
>>> http://www.bartleby.com/251/pages/page494.html
>>>
>>> If you are interested, I'd advise going back a few pages to read
>>> this in the full context of his entire speech.
>>>
>>> So Griffin did almost quote Lincoln correctly, though not
>>> accurately word for word, but he's conveniently omitted the
>>> context in which it was said.  He's actually arguing for the rule
>>> of law and against secession and armed rebellion here I think.
>>> He's arguing for practicality too.  Doing what needs to be done to
>>> win, rather than impractical idealism about freeing the slaves.
>>> At least that's my interpretation.  YMMV.
>>>
>>> Peace,
>>>
>>> Peter
>>>
>>>
>>>

>>> I thought is was pretty muh a given that the civil war was about
>>> confederacy attempting to suceed from the Union, and the Union
>>> opposing
>>> that move.  Many issues were involved in why those states wanted
>>> to leave
>>> the union, Slavery being one of them, but the bottom line reason
>>> was that
>>> they didn't want to be part of the federal gov't and the federal
>>> gov't said
>>> "tough shit".
>>>
>>> It's not much different any other country that splits in half and
>>> the sides
>>> start fighting over territory.  There's various issues, and
>>> individuals
>>> (Lincoln for example) will have their personal opinons on those
>>> issues, but
>>> going to war over them is another issue.

>>> Afte rthe civil war the 14th and 15th ammendments were passed,
>>> both of
>>> which moving the country towards being more civilized and was one
>>> of the
>>> smarter things our gov't has done in it's history.  IMHO if the
>>> north was
>>> serious about the issues, they would have passed those ammendments
>>> or at
>>> least made them a law previous to the war.  IMHO the ammendments  
>>> were
>>> passed in the same light as a campaign promise made good.  It's
>>> speculation, but based on general political movites, it pans out.
>>>
>>> As for the use of the word perverted, it very easily could have
>>> been used,
>>> since it's meaning was different back then.  Pervert is taken form
>>> the
>>> latin word "perverto perverti perversum" which literally means "to
>>> turn
>>> upside down, overturn, overthrow."
>>>
>>> Considering most of our educated leaders were versed in Latin,
>>> this is the
>>> way I interpret it.

>>> At 09:09 AM 1/24/2007, dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
>>>> The problem is did Lincoln actually ever say that?
>>>>
>>>> If you try to find the source of that quotation you won't find
>>>> it. Or at
>>>> least I couldn't.
>>>>
>>>> Apparently Teddy Roosevelt actually said something like this in a
>>>> paper he
>>>> wrote in 1913 .
>>>> (http://teachingamericanhistory.org/library/index.asp? 
>>>> document=1140)
>>>>
>>>> I couldn't find a source for the quotation Roosevelt uses
>>>> however. I'd
>>>> guess this is most likely a paraphrase of something Lincoln
>>>> actually said
>>>> in his inaugural speech in 1861. See
>>>> http://www.famousquotes.me.uk/speeches/Abraham_Lincoln/1.htm I
>>>> don't have
>>>> time today to do more thorough research, so you'll have to form
>>>> your own
>>>> opinion or do your own research.
>>>>
>>>> One point to keep in mind, note the differences in language usage
>>>> between
>>>> Lincoln's actual speech and this purported quotation.  Personally
>>>> I'm a
>>>> bit skeptical that a public figure would have used the word
>>>> "perverted" in
>>>> a speech in the 1860s.  Maybe I am mistaken.
>>>>
>>>> As far as this book, G. Edward Griffin is merely retelling a
>>>> story first
>>>> reported in a previous book by Eustace Mullins. If you want to
>>>> learn more
>>>> about the origins of this story, you should go to the source and
>>>> that's
>>>> Eustace Mullins.
>>>>
>>>> I'd encourage everyone to do their own research about Mullins,
>>>> but in case
>>>> you want some quick starting points:
>>>>
>>>> http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eustace_Mullins
>>>> http://www.rense.com/general39/EUSTACE.htm
>>>> http://www.rense.com/general72/contract.htm
>>>>
>>>> As usual these people's own words are the best place to start
>>>> understanding their true beliefs.
>>>>
>>>> I am certain that many in the Confederacy believed that "the
>>>> Civil War was
>>>> not about slavery" but about "the Northern states economically
>>>> strangling
>>>> the Southern states with the laws they were passing" as you say.
>>>> That
>>>> doesn't make it true. The southern states relied on slaves to
>>>> keep their
>>>> economy operating, so any law addressing slavery would have had  
>>>> that
>>>> effect. I am not surprised that some people, at least in certain
>>>> circles,
>>>> still believe this to be a clear fact however.  I suppose it
>>>> would depend
>>>> on who you asked.
>>>>
>>>> Wars are rarely "about" just one thing. Maybe, just maybe,
>>>> complicated
>>>> questions don't always have simple answers.  Of course sometimes
>>>> certain
>>>> people need to find simple explanations for complicated things,
>>>> especially
>>>> for those things that are frightening to them. Simple answers give
>>>> direction sand focus to the fear, at least for a little while.
>>>> The more
>>>> thoughful among us rarely find these simple explanations
>>>> satisfying however.
>>>>
>>>> What are you really afraid of Deepfog?  Maybe you should consult a

=0A>>> "I say that we must not interfere with the institution of slavery=0A=
>>> in the States where it exists, because the Constitution forbids=0A>>> i=
t, and the general welfare does not require us to do so. We must=0A>>> not =
withhold an efficient Fugitive Slave law, because the=0A>>> Constitution re=

nstitution nor general welfare requires us=0A>>> to extend it. We must prev=
ent the revival of the African slave-=0A>>> trade, and the enacting by Cong=
ress of a Territorial slave code.=0A>>> We must prevent each of these thing=
s being done by either=0A>>> congresses or courts. The people of these Unit=
ed States are the=0A>>> rightful masters of both congresses and courts, not=
 to overthrow=0A>>> the Constitution, but to overthrow the men who pervert =
the=0A>>> Constitution.=0A>>>=0A>>> To do these things we must employ instr=
umentalities. We must hold=0A>>> conventions; we must adopt platforms, if w=
e conform to ordinary=0A>>> custom; we must nominate candidates; and we mus=
t carry elections.=0A>>> In all these things, I think that we ought to keep=
 in view our=0A>>> real purpose, and in none do anything that stands advers=
e to our=0A>>> purpose. If we shall adopt a platform that fails to recogniz=
e or=0A>>> express our purpose, or elect a man that declares himself inimic=
al=0A>>> to our purpose, we not only take nothing by our success, but we=0A=
>>> tacitly admit that we act upon no other principle than a desire to=0A>>=
> have 'the loaves and fishes,' by which, in the end, our apparent=0A>>> su=
ccess is really an injury to us."=0A>>>=0A>>> http://www.bartleby.com/251/p=
ages/page494.html=0A>>>=0A>>> If you are interested, I'd advise going back =
a few pages to read=0A>>> this in the full context of his entire speech.=0A=
>>>=0A>>> So Griffin did almost quote Lincoln correctly, though not=0A>>> a=
ccurately word for word, but he's conveniently omitted the=0A>>> context in=
 which it was said.  He's actually arguing for the rule=0A>>> of law and ag=
ainst secession and armed rebellion here I think.=0A>>> He's arguing for pr=
acticality too.  Doing what needs to be done to=0A>>> win, rather than impr=
actical idealism about freeing the slaves.=0A>>> At least that's my interpr=
etation.  YMMV.=0A>>>=0A>>> Peace,=0A>>>=0A>>> Peter=0A>>>=0A>>>=0A>>>=0A>>=
