Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Thu)

I haven't looked at the SFR posts this week, maybe out of fear of =20
being flamed from my post yesterday.  Well, hopefully not.

Anyway, I was having an interesting little conversation last night, I =20
was working late and smoking, and talking with this guy and he was =20
talking about what he does at home and how he has the kids watch some =20
TV and stuff and then I mentioned how I don't really watch TV anymore. =20
  By the way, I stopped watching so much TV after listening to Alex =20
Jones interview Jeff Rense and they talked about how studies show that =20
TV puts your brain to a low sleep state, but that's beside the point, =20
it's good we had those debates the last few weeks.  I'll leave that =20
one alone for a while or at least for a while.  I want to talk about =20
rubber chickens.

Yes, my friend Tony joined us and listened to our conversation.  This =20
other guy I was talking to mentioned how he reads a lot and how his =20
kids get bored with TV and just go play by themselves or they talk or =20
interact.  I also mentioned something else I heard on that interview =20
that I thought interesting, that is 50 years ago, people used to talk =20
to each other at night, you'd hear fights going on in cities in =20
apartments, etc.  and now all the windows glow blue.  Now maybe that's =20
a little extreme and I'm pretty sure a lot of the SFR crowd already =20
doesn't watch so much, and it was mostly my problem, and I've gone =20
through stages where I don't watch any TV basically because there =20
isn't one around, for the first time now I go home and I actually =20
don't even turn the thing on because it's no longer interesting to me =20
at all.  I'd rather do other things.  I even used to leave it on =20
during regeneration cycles but I don't even do that anymore.

So we talked about the book Mayan Prophecies and that movie Apocalypto =20
and the other guy I was talking to mentioned it's hard to know what to =20
believe, and I made that comment that history is written by the =20
victors, and my firend Tony popped in with his little comment that I =20
would like to dedicate as today's QOD:

--

Yea, that's because when I write my book, I'll be whoopin some ass!

--

... and then he started talking about how rubber chickens are the =20
shit.  This guy claims to have been a bouncer for raves in the NW and =20
says he's heard the name Groovinkim before.

Anyway, guess you had to be there, have a nice Thursday, talk to you soon.

DF out

Perhaps you should explain it to the goose stepping aryans marching around 
with pictures of Hitler chanting WHITE POWER.

As for White Pride, they are a subset of WAR (White Aryan Resistance) and 
are for all practicle purposes a gang not unlike the bloods or 
crips.  They're more concentrated in suburb areas, at least in 
california.  Pretty much the recruiting grounds for the upper ranks of the 
organizations.

The concept of pride in ones self is fine, however let's ot forget it's one 
of the deadly sins, and for good reason.  Humility is the better part of valor.

Basing your pride on a color is, well, really fucking lame.  It's 
racial.  Plain and simple.  Please note, I didn't say Racist, I said 
Racial.  What has a race done?  Nothing.  Not a fucking thing.  Races 
breed.  Culture on the other hand, grows, develops, advances, suffers 
through hardships and either is wiped out, or excels.  I can go on at 
length about this, but i shoudl have to.  This list SHOULD be smart enough 
to easily draw their own examples.  Pick any race, and you can find it's 
winners and losers, however if you find the difference between the winners 
and losers, the divideing lines will be culturally based, because when 
looking at a race, there's no lines of division within that race.  Simple 
logic.

Pride of culture, pride of country, pride of history.

Not pride in genetics.

Fuck Racism.

Subject: [sfraves] BSP - This week's Fukwerk & Low End (feat. Japan's Saya Sat @
	Retox Lounge!)

Thanks to all of you who have been coming out these past few weeks to
Fukwerk Friday at 111 Minna and especially those who made our first
night at Low End Saturday last weekend a memorable sweaty, freaking
blast!

We can't wait till this weekend to do this all again with our favorite
techno lineup. And that's a good thing, cause there's little time left
to recover.

This week at the Low End Saturdays catch our special guest DJ Saya
from Tokyo, along with residents James Bass and the Solekandi Duo.

Don't forget to drop by 111 Minna Friday for Fukwerk for the best end
of the week happy hour dance party in the city. The Solekandi duo and
Peoplemuver's Kawa will do the after work unwinding for you.

More details on both events Friday and Saturday below:

Fukwerk Friday
111 Minna (2nd and Howard)
DJs: Bay Area Beatdrop residents The Solekandi Duo and Kawa (Peoplemuver)
Time: 5-9 PM
$1 drinks from 5-7
No Cover

===========================================================

Low End Saturdays
Retox Lounge (628 20th Street @ 3rd St)
DJs: Saya, Solekandi Duo, James Bass
Time: 9-2 PM
No Cover

About Saya:

Saya, who originally hails from Japan, was a regular in Tokyo's techno
scene, throwing her own events and playing with some of the world's
best techno DJs such as countrymen Ken Ishi and Fumiya Tanaka, plus
Detroit's Jeff Mills and Claude Young. Saya's tight blend of danceable
yet minimal tech grooves reminiscent of Japan's Op.Disc crew have
definately caught our attention with both a skillset and track
selection that's worthy of an entire Saturday night on the Retox
dancefloor.

Review of Low End @ Retox in this week's Nitevibe:

"Shh, don't tell anyone, but Retox, home of the old Sublounge, is
turning into one of the hottest out-of-the-way haunts in SF. The new
ownership has done wonders for the space, and the quality of the beats
is matching that of the drinks as Bay Area Beat Drop brings the sounds
that a discerning ear will desire. Solekandi and James Bass like to
drop bass-heavy love, and special guest DJ Saya is a treat for sure.
(SG)" (Nitevibe)


Info + schedules:

www.babd.org
www.solekandi.com

Join us!

http://www.myspace.com/fukwerkfridays
http://www.myspace.com/lowendsaturday

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] BSP:  Disco D Remembrance Tonight

--Apple-Mail-1-325989546
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=US-ASCII;
	delsp=yes;
	format=flowed

Come pay your respects to the late Disco D tonight at Compression,  
one of D's favorite parties to play at in SF. This will be a low key  
night in which you can bring a white candle, flowers, a picture, CD,  
or anything else that reminds you of D to display on a little alter  
in his rememberance. Disco D was an incredibly talented pioneer and  
producer in the music industry working with people such as 50 Cent,  
Kevin Federline, the international Brazilian hiphop group Braza, and  
numerous other artists. He was one of the first musicians to truly  
expose Ghetto-tech and he has melted numerous genres of music  
together to make some incredibly talented beats. He was loved by all  
those who knew him, so come down tonight to pay your respects.

THE CELLAR
685 Sutter @ Taylor in SF
10PM

For more information about Disco D, visit discod.com, youtube.com,  
myspace.com/gringolouco
For more information about his death, visit the Jan 22 & 23 news  
archives of mtv.com, urb.com, & xlr8r.com, just to name a few.

DISCO D YOU WILL BE MISSED HOMIE! WE LOVED AND SUPPORTED YOU SO MUCH  
AS YOU GOT US SHAKIN OUR ASSES ON THE DANCEFLOOR ONE GROOVE AT A  
TIME! MUCH LOVE!



--Apple-Mail-1-325989546--

On Jan 25, 2007, at 11:38 AM, Shatter wrote:

> Basing your pride on a color is, well, really fucking lame.  It's  
> racial.  Plain and simple.  Please note, I didn't say Racist, I  
> said Racial.  What has a race done?  Nothing.  Not a fucking  
> thing.  Races breed.  Culture on the other hand, grows, develops,  
> advances, suffers through hardships and either is wiped out, or  
> excels.  I can go on at length about this, but i shoudl have to.   
> This list SHOULD be smart enough to easily draw their own  
> examples.  Pick any race, and you can find it's winners and losers,  
> however if you find the difference between the winners and losers,  
> the divideing lines will be culturally based, because when looking  
> at a race, there's no lines of division within that race.  Simple  
> logic.

I must not be smart enough to understand this simple logic, because  
my train of thought keeps getting derailed every time I try to  
understand what you just said.

> Pride of culture, pride of country, pride of history.
>
> Not pride in genetics.

My turn for some simple logic:

Pride in your parents: (mom and dad) OK
Pride in your family's in-country lineage: (iowa, california) OK
Pride in your family's out-of-country national ancestry: (germany,  
norway) OK
Pride in the accomplishments and culture of the nation of your  
family's ancestry (german and norwegian culture): OK
Pride in the accomplishments and culture of the nations and peoples  
surrounding the nation of your family's ancestry (european culture-  
aka "race"): UH OH- SUDDENLY NOT OK!

Also, I find it amusing that your name is the past tense of "shitter" :P

From: Uncle Noah <unclenoah@yahoo.com>

Message-ID: <612116.3602.qm@web32013.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: More White Power BS on SFRAVES...(was QOD)



i think everyone has stuff to be proud of.  that stuff
might be related to your culture (eg. your day-to-day
living practices, etc.), it might be related to your
nationality (eg. what flag you salute), it might be
related to an ethnicity (eg. what group of people you
identify as "us") or it might be realted to your race
(eg. your genetic makeup).

the problem is when that pride couples with the ego
and makes you think that any one particular
culture/nationality/ethnicity/race is better or worse
than the others.

they key to harmony is understanding and appreciating
the differences that we all have, and then using those
differences as a point for sharing rather than as a
point for oppression.

something that's always irked me is hearing caucasian
folks say, "I'm just white."  *just* white?  so,
because you're white you don't have any cultural,
ethnic or other parts to you?  

this was actually the one good thing that came from
the time i spent in Detroit.  out there, i met and
worked with a bunch of 2nd and 3rd generation
caucasion immigrants.  these guys would bring differnt
cultural and ethnic foods to work for lunch during the
week, and would often share stories that their
families had handed down for generations, talk about
cultural music etc. etc. etc.  

all of these men were very in touch with their ethnic,
cultural and racial identities.  none of them would
have self-identified as "just white."  but they were
open and interested in sharing with other people, and
they didn't think they were better or worse because of
who they were.

i wound up having a very wonderful cultural exchange
with these guys, and yes, it was racial, ethnical (?),
national and cultural.  but no one was afraid to share
what they had, and no one was afraid to accept what
others were sharing.

just don't be afraid, brothers and sisters.  don't be
afraid to share, and don't be afraid to let others
share with you.

PLUR, right?

>>> On 1/24/07, dangrsmind@yahoo.com <dangrsmind@yahoo.com> wrote:
>>>> I'm no historian, but your description matches essentially matches
>>>> my understanding of those events.  However, it always seems
>>>> questionable to me to state what any war is really about in one
>>>> sentence or less.  How can you determine what a war is really  
>>>> about?
>>>>
>>>> From what I read this AM in Lincoln's speech, it is clear that
>>>> there were already concerns about what he might do with the
>>>> Southerner's "property" which, as a reminder happened to include
>>>> human beings, since he specifically addressed this issue in his
>>>> speech. He specifically says he won't free the slaves, so I assume
>>>> he felt that he needed to address this because some feared he
>>>> would.  As you correctly point out he didn't do that until after
>>>> the war.
>>>>
>>>> It also wasn't decided until after the war (in the 14th amendment)
>>>> that slave owners would not be reimbursed for their losses due to
>>>> the freeing of their slaves.  Therefore to say the war was really
>>>> about harming the South economically when this wasn't decided
>>>> until after the war seems highly questionable to me.  Possibly the
>>>> slaves could have been freed and their former owners reimbursed
>>>> for their losses had the South not seceded in the first place.
>>>> Maybe not, I wasn't there.
>>>>
>>>> FWIW, and fior the sake of completeness I'm happy to report that
>>>> after a bit of further research I've found the original source of
>>>> this quotation,  in the Lincoln-Douglas debates in 1858.  (http://
>>>> www.nps.gov/archive/liho/debates.htm)
>>>>
>>>> FWIW here's the full quotation in context:
>>>>
>>>> "I say that we must not interfere with the institution of slavery
>>>> in the States where it exists, because the Constitution forbids
>>>> it, and the general welfare does not require us to do so. We must
>>>> not withhold an efficient Fugitive Slave law, because the
>>>> Constitution requires us, as I understand it, not to withhold such
>>>> a law. But we must prevent the outspreading of the institution,
>>>> because neither the Constitution nor general welfare requires us
>>>> to extend it. We must prevent the revival of the African slave-
>>>> trade, and the enacting by Congress of a Territorial slave code.
>>>> We must prevent each of these things being done by either
>>>> congresses or courts. The people of these United States are the
>>>> rightful masters of both congresses and courts, not to overthrow
>>>> the Constitution, but to overthrow the men who pervert the
>>>> Constitution.
>>>>
>>>> To do these things we must employ instrumentalities. We must hold
>>>> conventions; we must adopt platforms, if we conform to ordinary
>>>> custom; we must nominate candidates; and we must carry elections.
>>>> In all these things, I think that we ought to keep in view our
>>>> real purpose, and in none do anything that stands adverse to our
>>>> purpose. If we shall adopt a platform that fails to recognize or
>>>> express our purpose, or elect a man that declares himself inimical
>>>> to our purpose, we not only take nothing by our success, but we
>>>> tacitly admit that we act upon no other principle than a desire to
>>>> have 'the loaves and fishes,' by which, in the end, our apparent
>>>> success is really an injury to us."
>>>>
>>>> http://www.bartleby.com/251/pages/page494.html
>>>>
>>>> If you are interested, I'd advise going back a few pages to read
>>>> this in the full context of his entire speech.
>>>>
>>>> So Griffin did almost quote Lincoln correctly, though not
>>>> accurately word for word, but he's conveniently omitted the
>>>> context in which it was said.  He's actually arguing for the rule
>>>> of law and against secession and armed rebellion here I think.
>>>> He's arguing for practicality too.  Doing what needs to be done to
>>>> win, rather than impractical idealism about freeing the slaves.
>>>> At least that's my interpretation.  YMMV.
>>>>
>>>> Peace,
>>>>
>>>> Peter
>>>>
>>>>
>>>>

>>>> I thought is was pretty muh a given that the civil war was about

>>>> was that
>>>> they didn't want to be part of the federal gov't and the federal
>>>> gov't said
>>>> "tough shit".
>>>>
>>>> It's not much different any other country that splits in half and
>>>> the sides
>>>> start fighting over territory.  There's various issues, and
>>>> individuals
>>>> (Lincoln for example) will have their personal opinons on those
>>>> issues, but
>>>> going to war over them is another issue.

>>>> both of
>>>> which moving the country towards being more civilized and was one
>>>> of the
>>>> smarter things our gov't has done in it's history.  IMHO if the
>>>> north was
>>>> serious about the issues, they would have passed those ammendments
>>>> or at
>>>> least made them a law previous to the war.  IMHO the ammendments
>>>> were
>>>> passed in the same light as a campaign promise made good.  It's
>>>> speculation, but based on general political movites, it pans out.
>>>>
>>>> As for the use of the word perverted, it very easily could have
>>>> been used,
>>>> since it's meaning was different back then.  Pervert is taken form
>>>> the
>>>> latin word "perverto perverti perversum" which literally means "to
>>>> turn
>>>> upside down, overturn, overthrow."
>>>>
>>>> Considering most of our educated leaders were versed in Latin,
>>>> this is the
>>>> way I interpret it.
>>>>

>>>>> guess this is most likely a paraphrase of something Lincoln

>>>>> your own

>>>>> between
>>>>> Lincoln's actual speech and this purported quotation.  Personally
>>>>> I'm a
>>>>> bit skeptical that a public figure would have used the word
>>>>> "perverted" in

>>>>> story first

>>>>> I am certain that many in the Confederacy believed that "the
>>>>> Civil War was
>>>>> not about slavery" but about "the Northern states economically

>>>>> doesn't make it true. The southern states relied on slaves to

>>>>> still believe this to be a clear fact however.  I suppose it
>>>>> would depend
>>>>> on who you asked.

>>>>> Wars are rarely "about" just one thing. Maybe, just maybe,
>>>>> complicated
>>>>> questions don't always have simple answers.  Of course sometimes
>>>>> certain
>>>>> people need to find simple explanations for complicated things,

>>> Lalalalala. I agree with Shatter's e-mail. From my understanding of
>>> the civil war it was not about slavery, but it became about slavery
>>> afterwards during reconstruction. Also, a lot of people started
>>> making

>>> On 1/24/07, dangrsmind@yahoo.com  wrote:
>>>> I'm no historian, but your description matches essentially matches
>>>> my understanding of those events.  However, it always seems
>>>> questionable to me to state what any war is really about in one
>>>> sentence or less.  How can you determine what a war is really  
>>>> about?
>>>>
>>>> From what I read this AM in Lincoln's speech, it is clear that
>>>> there were already concerns about what he might do with the
>>>> Southerner's "property" which, as a reminder happened to include
>>>> human beings, since he specifically addressed this issue in his
>>>> speech. He specifically says he won't free the slaves, so I assume
>>>> he felt that he needed to address this because some feared he
>>>> would.  As you correctly point out he didn't do that until after
>>>> the war.
>>>>
>>>> It also wasn't decided until after the war (in the 14th amendment)
>>>> that slave owners would not be reimbursed for their losses due to
>>>> the freeing of their slaves.  Therefore to say the war was really
>>>> about harming the South economically when this wasn't decided
>>>> until after the war seems highly questionable to me.  Possibly the
>>>> slaves could have been freed and their former owners reimbursed
>>>> for their losses had the South not seceded in the first place.
>>>> Maybe not, I wasn't there.
>>>>
>>>> FWIW, and fior the sake of completeness I'm happy to report that
>>>> after a bit of further research I've found the original source of
>>>> this quotation,  in the Lincoln-Douglas debates in 1858.  (http://
>>>> www.nps.gov/archive/liho/debates.htm)
>>>>
>>>> FWIW here's the full quotation in context:
>>>>
>>>> "I say that we must not interfere with the institution of slavery
>>>> in the States where it exists, because the Constitution forbids
>>>> it, and the general welfare does not require us to do so. We must
>>>> not withhold an efficient Fugitive Slave law, because the
>>>> Constitution requires us, as I understand it, not to withhold such
>>>> a law. But we must prevent the outspreading of the institution,
>>>> because neither the Constitution nor general welfare requires us
>>>> to extend it. We must prevent the revival of the African slave-
>>>> trade, and the enacting by Congress of a Territorial slave code.
>>>> We must prevent each of these things being done by either
>>>> congresses or courts. The people of these United States are the
>>>> rightful masters of both congresses and courts, not to overthrow
>>>> the Constitution, but to overthrow the men who pervert the
>>>> Constitution.
>>>>
>>>> To do these things we must employ instrumentalities. We must hold
>>>> conventions; we must adopt platforms, if we conform to ordinary
>>>> custom; we must nominate candidates; and we must carry elections.
>>>> In all these things, I think that we ought to keep in view our
>>>> real purpose, and in none do anything that stands adverse to our
>>>> purpose. If we shall adopt a platform that fails to recognize or
>>>> express our purpose, or elect a man that declares himself inimical
>>>> to our purpose, we not only take nothing by our success, but we
>>>> tacitly admit that we act upon no other principle than a desire to
>>>> have 'the loaves and fishes,' by which, in the end, our apparent
>>>> success is really an injury to us."
>>>>
>>>> http://www.bartleby.com/251/pages/page494.html
>>>>
>>>> If you are interested, I'd advise going back a few pages to read
>>>> this in the full context of his entire speech.
>>>>
>>>> So Griffin did almost quote Lincoln correctly, though not
>>>> accurately word for word, but he's conveniently omitted the
>>>> context in which it was said.  He's actually arguing for the rule
>>>> of law and against secession and armed rebellion here I think.
>>>> He's arguing for practicality too.  Doing what needs to be done to
>>>> win, rather than impractical idealism about freeing the slaves.
>>>> At least that's my interpretation.  YMMV.
>>>>
>>>> Peace,
>>>>
>>>> Peter
>>>>
>>>>
>>>>

>>>> I thought is was pretty muh a given that the civil war was about
>>>> confederacy attempting to suceed from the Union, and the Union
>>>> opposing
>>>> that move.  Many issues were involved in why those states wanted
>>>> to leave
>>>> the union, Slavery being one of them, but the bottom line reason
>>>> was that
>>>> they didn't want to be part of the federal gov't and the federal
>>>> gov't said
>>>> "tough shit".
>>>>
>>>> It's not much different any other country that splits in half and
>>>> the sides
>>>> start fighting over territory.  There's various issues, and
>>>> individuals
>>>> (Lincoln for example) will have their personal opinons on those
>>>> issues, but
>>>> going to war over them is another issue.
>>>>
>>>> Afte rthe civil war the 14th and 15th ammendments were passed,
>>>> both of
>>>> which moving the country towards being more civilized and was one
>>>> of the
>>>> smarter things our gov't has done in it's history.  IMHO if the
>>>> north was
>>>> serious about the issues, they would have passed those ammendments
>>>> or at
>>>> least made them a law previous to the war.  IMHO the ammendments
>>>> were
>>>> passed in the same light as a campaign promise made good.  It's
>>>> speculation, but based on general political movites, it pans out.
>>>>
>>>> As for the use of the word perverted, it very easily could have
>>>> been used,
>>>> since it's meaning was different back then.  Pervert is taken form
>>>> the
>>>> latin word "perverto perverti perversum" which literally means "to
>>>> turn
>>>> upside down, overturn, overthrow."
>>>>
>>>> Considering most of our educated leaders were versed in Latin,
>>>> this is the
>>>> way I interpret it.
>>>>

>>>>>
>>>>> If you try to find the source of that quotation you won't find
>>>>> it. Or at

>>>>> paper he
>>>>> wrote in 1913 .

>>>>> document=1140)
>>>>>
>>>>> I couldn't find a source for the quotation Roosevelt uses
>>>>> however. I'd
>>>>> guess this is most likely a paraphrase of something Lincoln
>>>>> actually said
>>>>> in his inaugural speech in 1861. See
>>>>> http://www.famousquotes.me.uk/speeches/Abraham_Lincoln/1.htm I
>>>>> don't have
>>>>> time today to do more thorough research, so you'll have to form
>>>>> your own
>>>>> opinion or do your own research.
>>>>>
>>>>> One point to keep in mind, note the differences in language usage
>>>>> between
>>>>> Lincoln's actual speech and this purported quotation.  Personally
>>>>> I'm a
>>>>> bit skeptical that a public figure would have used the word
>>>>> "perverted" in
>>>>> a speech in the 1860s.  Maybe I am mistaken.
>>>>>
>>>>> As far as this book, G. Edward Griffin is merely retelling a
>>>>> story first
>>>>> reported in a previous book by Eustace Mullins. If you want to
>>>>> learn more
>>>>> about the origins of this story, you should go to the source and
>>>>> that's
>>>>> Eustace Mullins.
>>>>>
>>>>> I'd encourage everyone to do their own research about Mullins,
>>>>> but in case
>>>>> you want some quick starting points:
>>>>>
>>>>> http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eustace_Mullins
>>>>> http://www.rense.com/general39/EUSTACE.htm
>>>>> http://www.rense.com/general72/contract.htm
>>>>>
>>>>> As usual these people's own words are the best place to start
>>>>> understanding their true beliefs.
>>>>>
>>>>> I am certain that many in the Confederacy believed that "the
>>>>> Civil War was
>>>>> not about slavery" but about "the Northern states economically
>>>>> strangling
>>>>> the Southern states with the laws they were passing" as you say.
>>>>> That
>>>>> doesn't make it true. The southern states relied on slaves to
>>>>> keep their
>>>>> economy operating, so any law addressing slavery would have had
>>>>> that
>>>>> effect. I am not surprised that some people, at least in certain
>>>>> circles,
>>>>> still believe this to be a clear fact however.  I suppose it
>>>>> would depend
>>>>> on who you asked.
>>>>>
>>>>> Wars are rarely "about" just one thing. Maybe, just maybe,
>>>>> complicated
>>>>> questions don't always have simple answers.  Of course sometimes
>>>>> certain
>>>>> people need to find simple explanations for complicated things,
>>>>> especially
>>>>> for those things that are frightening to them. Simple answers give
>>>>> direction sand focus to the fear, at least for a little while.
>>>>> The more
>>>>> thoughful among us rarely find these simple explanations
>>>>> satisfying however.
>>>>>
>>>>> What are you really afraid of Deepfog?  Maybe you should consult a
>>>>> spritual advisor, family member, or trusted friend. Preferably

I was going to say Race !=3D Culture, but the dictionary is much more=
 forgiving:

=97Synonyms 1. tribe, clan, family, stock, line,=20
breed. Race, people, nation are terms for a large=20
body of persons who may be thought of as a unit=20
because of common characteristics. In the=20
traditional biological and anthropological=20
systems of classification race refers to a group=20
of persons who share such genetically transmitted=20
traits as skin color, hair texture, and eye shape=20
or color: the white race; the yellow race. In=20
reference to classifying the human species, race=20
is now under dispute among modern biologists and=20
anthropologists. Some feel that the term has no=20
biological validity; others use it to specify=20
only a partially isolated reproductive population=20
whose members share a considerable degree of=20
genetic similarity. In certain broader or less=20
technical senses race is sometimes used=20
interchangeably with people. People refers to a=20
body of persons united usually by common=20
interests, ideals, or culture but sometimes also=20
by a common history, language, or ethnic=20
character: We are one people; the peoples of the=20
world; the Swedish people. Nation refers to a=20
body of persons living under an organized=20
government or rule, occupying a defined area, and=20
acting as a unit in matters of peace and war: the English nation.


sarilion

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Desperately seeking loBudg / Carbon Community / S.O.T.E.G sets live / streamed, anything please :-))

we used to have a recording online of the first time Lobudg played in
the bay area, way back at Furious 2 in 2005.  it's not online anymore,
but i've got it on my computer somewhere.

Bil and Dave rarely play live together as Lobudg.  i think Evil Breaks
is the only crew that's had them play in the United States and we've
had them here 3 times!  woo!

there are a few of their individual sets online.

http://www.mnvibe.com/php/event.php?action=view&eventID=1896

http://www.podcastdirectory.com/podshows/321869

Addictech sells Bil's tracks and there is a mixed CD up there, as
well.  It's under "The Disciple's Grin" which is another one of Bil's
monikers (other than SOTEG, Son of the Electric Ghost, and SST).

http://www.addictech.com

Search for Bless records, Bil's own label.

Dave has a full length album of material that he's supposed to be
releasing.  but he's dragging his feet.  i've heard most of it and
it's good stuff.

hope this helps!

A Chinese New Year Celebration

Downstairs: techno.electro.acidhouse::

Ark (Ark Music Productions)


*Intimate San Francisco Underground Location

> Get ready for the first in a series of sick new color themed parties brought
> to you by some of the hottest crews in the underground house scene. We are
> teaming up to bring you only the best in funky, floorshaking underground
> house music to keep you grooving until the break of dawn. Tonal parties will
> showcase talent flown in from out of town as well as some of your favorite
> local house jocks. Strap on your dancing shoes and get ready to move it!
>
> DJ's:
> Q-Burns Abstract Message (Eight Tracks, Blue Collar Entertainment, Orlando
> FL)
> We are very excited to bring Q-Burns here for the first installment of
> Tonal! He brings a ton of energy to the decks and makes everybody freak out
> on the dancefloor with his ultra funky track selection, seamless mixing, and
> super-fun presence. Q-Burns is also quickly gaining notoriety for his
> production and remixes, and rocks crowds all over the world. We are honored
> to have him back to SF, one of his favorite cities. It's been too long!
> http://www.q-burnsabstractmessage.com/
>
> Leonard (In House, Tocadisco, SF)
> What would SF's house scene be like without Mr. Leonard? One of the oldest
> school heads around, Leonard has one of the sickest record collections in
> our fine city. We look very much forward to seeing what Leonard pulls out of
> the crates for a closing set not to be missed. www.myspace.com/djleonard
>
> Andrew Phelan & Origami (Prismatic, Eight Tracks, SF)
> One of SF's fastest growing duos in both the DJ and production realms,
> Andrew and Origami put down some serious business. A Chicago native, Mr.
> Phelan brings the funk just how we like it with Origami backing him up on
> live bass keeping the speakers booming and your bodies moving!
> www.prismatictracks.com
>
> Eric Sharp (Rock It Science, SF)
> Founder of the Rock It Science crew, Eric Sharp has quickly built a name for
> himself with his infectious energy behind the decks and the versatility to
> rock any party. Eric will throw down a 2 hour opening set, setting the vibe
> just right for a night you will never forget. www.myspace.com/ericsharp
>
> Finally keep your eyes peeled as well for Tonal: Fire Engine Red coming at
> cha on Saturday, February 24th with Miles Maeda, Brown, and more!
>
>

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: more fone phun (razr phone modding tip)

Ok, I've been playing around a bit more with my razr cell phone.  I got min=
e from Sprint, so most/all of the cool features (i.e. camcorder mode) that =
come locked on the Verizon version of the phone were unlocked.  But it only=
 came with a 64 MB chip.  That's enough for a few pix and some ringtones, b=
ut that's about it.  A little online research told me that my model (the v3=
m) can accept 2 GB micro SD chips.=0A=0ASo I went looking for a 2 GB chip f=
or it and this took a bit of doing.  Adding a 2 GB chip to the phone essent=
ially turns it into a iPod nano equivalent music player, but with removable=
 media, phone, web, bluetooth support, and more.  Its also sort of convenie=
nt for moving work files from home to the office; its essentially equivalen=
t to a thumb drive.  I figure the thing can hold something like 20 mixes pe=
r chip but we'll see when I'm done filling it.=0A=0ANow you can order these=
 chips online from Amazon and a few other places, but being impatient I wan=
ted to find one at a local retailer.  Couldn't find them anywhere.  Courtes=
y of one of the guys at the lcoal Sprint store, I found out that Verizon ha=
s an exclusive from Sandisk to sell the 2 GB chips in retail.   Headed to t=
he Verizon store to buy the chip, and they had them.  They grumbled a bit w=
hen they discovered I didn't have a Verizon locked phone, but they sold it =
to me anyway. :p=0A=0ASo if you want to add big memory to your razr, regard=
less of your carrier, head on over to Verizon and pick up a 2 GB chip.  Its=
 pretty slick once you get it all working!=0A=0APeace,=0A=0APeter=0A=0AP.S.=
 Just moving Ben Haus's trapped in a wormhole mix into it.  Thanks Ben!

Saturday, February 3rd

[ K O N T R O L ]

minimal techno + avant house
every first Saturday at the Endup


featuring New York's Twin Towers of techno!


=====>  DEREK PLASLAIKO  <=====

Spectral Sound . Ghostly Int'l . The Bunker :: NYC
This former stalwart of the Detroit party scene moved
to New York City a few years back and has made a
quick ascent to the top, recently being crowned
2006's "Best Techno DJ" by the Village Voice.


=====> TIM XAVIER <=====

LTD400 . Klikhaus . Klink . Cocoon :: Brooklyn
As an amazingly prolific producer, international DJ,
owner of 2 highly regarded minimal labels, and chief
engineer at one of the country's best  mastering studios,
Tim has become one of the US's true techno treasures.


plus special guest from across the pond:

=====>  PHILIP SHERBURNE  <=====

Raum Club . XLR8R . Pitchfork :: Barcelona
San Francisco's own minimal-loving expat and renound
music journalist returns to show off his exhaustive
knowledge of the genre and skills honed as a resident
at Barcelona's famed Raum Club.


with resident DJs:

SAMMY D  ( classic . dirtybird . utensil )
ALLAND BYALLO  ( liebe detail . floppy funk )
CRAIG KUNA  ( concept sf . esdjco )
NIKOLA BAYTALA ( robsoul . junior boys own . s.w.a.t. )

401 6th St @ Harrison, SF
10pm-6am / 21+ / $15
http://www.theendup.com

FREE until 11pm!

_________________________________________________


DEREK PLASLAIKO

Some people filter through the record bins, taking what are on the wall or
record store employee suggestions. Then there are people who dig deeper into
the dusty crates, and absorb music like a sponge; ignoring labels, bucking
trends and are forever on a quest to find the perfect record. The ones that
make the staunchest of chin stroking, note taking trainspotters lose their
shit on the dancefloor, hanging on every record from one to the next.

Derek Plaslaiko unquestionably falls into the latter category. As a teen
equally transfixed by Mojo and Wizard cassettes and Minor Threat 7"s,
Plaslaiko followed the beats from his hometown 20 miles south of Detroit to
the epicenter of Detroit techno, then enjoying its third wave of success. He
quietly paid his dues on Detroit's rave circuit, and was a crucial piece of
the puzzle for the legendary Poorboy and Syst3m parties of the mid-nineties.
He quickly earned a reputation for forward thinking DJ sets that were
clinical, sophisticated and extremely sensual. This combination resulted in
a residency for Family, the weekly party at Detroit's legendary Motor.  With
a reputation for high energy sets that were versatile and tasteful,
Plaslaiko slowly became in demand on the Midwestern club circuit; sharing
the stage with such techno luminares as John Acquaviva, Kevin Saunderson,
Richardo Villalobos, Baby Ford, and Matthew Herbert. It was also during that
time Plaslaiko was asked by Carl Craig to perform at the inaugural edition
of the Detroit Electronic Music Festival.

In 2003, Plaslaiko became part of the original team of DJs at Detroit's
Untitled parties, sharing a residency with Tadd Mullinix (aka James T.
Cotton), Matthew Dear and Mike Servito. In 2004 he made the decision to head
east and set up camp in New York City, determined to bring a slice of the
Motor City to the Big Apple.  Currently, Derek is one of the resident DJs at
the Bunker (Subtonic) in NYC, as well as an integral part of the Wolf + Lamb
monthly parties. Most recently, he was honored in the Village Voice 2006's
"Best Of" poll as New York's Best Techno DJ.


Derek Plaslaiko's website:
http://plaslaiko.net
Derek on MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/plaslaiko


MIXES:

Live @ Yura Yura, Philadelphia  (2 hours - 111MB)
http://www.kontrolsf.com/AUD/Derek_Plaslaiko_-_Live_@_Yura_Yura_-_Philadelphia_07.15.06.mp3


Live @ Wolf+Lamb, New Year's Eve, New York  (3+ hours - 182MB)
http://www.kontrolsf.com/AUD/Derek_Plaslaiko_-_Live_@_Wolf+Lamb_-_NYC_12.31.05.mp3


_________________________________________________


TIM XAVIER

Tim Xavier made himself a household name for techno fans in the late 90s
with his innovative releases on Blueline, and since he has continued to push
the envelope with new sounds and ideas. His techno releases have been
consistent and solid, having signed work to major labels such as Default,
Advanced and PV. He has been featured on CD compilations by well known
techno artists such as Chris Liebing and Christian Wunsch, and his tracks
get repeated play by top names such as Luciano, Pan-Pot, Richie Hawtin,
Magda, Marco Carola, Troy Pierce and Adam Beyer.

More recently, he has expanded his talents and broadened his production
spectrum into the minimal genre, starting two new labels in 2005: LTD400 and
Klickhaus. LTD400 is his solo label featuring his own work, and the releases
have been featured on mix compilations by Ricardo Villalobos and Steve Bug.
His new project, Klickhaus, will feature his own production as well as other
artists. Tim has also collaborated with Tony Rohr as the Afternoon Coffee
Boys, their debut release on Clink selling out in days and continuously
demanding repress. Upcoming releases from them include a full EP on Cocoon
due out in February.

As if Tim isn't busy enough, he is also the owner and chief mastering
engineer at Manmade Mastering in Brooklyn, NY, where he cuts dubplates and
masters. His precise ear, attention to detail and demand for perfection have
created a devoted following with his clients. Somehow between producing,
running his labels and cutting records, he still finds time play
international gigs, sharing his sought-after sound with fans and dancefloors
alike.


Tim Xavier's website:
http://www.manmademastering.com/

Tim's discography:
http://www.discogs.com/artist/Tim%20Xavier

Tim on MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/timxavier


MIXES:

Zombie Mix  (66min6sec - 154MB)
http://www.kontrolsf.com/AUD/Tim_Xavier_-_Zombie_Mix.mp3

The Art of Happiness  (62min - 141MB)
http://www.kontrolsf.com/AUD/Tim_Xavier_-_The_Art_of_Happiness.mp3


_________________________________________________


PHILIP SHERBURNE

San Francisco critic Philip Sherburne has been heavily involved in the
electronic-music world for the past seven years, writing for publications
including the New York Times, Village Voice, Slate, XLR8R, URB, Wax Poetics,
Grooves, Nylon, RES, Neumu.net <http://neumu.net/> and many others --
including The Wire, where his "Critical Beats" column offers a monthly
roundup of experimental dance music. Philip has also written on sound art
and avant-garde practice for Frieze and Parkett, curated the companion CD
for Leonardo Music Journal's 2003 issue, and given talks at SFMOMA, PS1,
Tate Modern and the MUTEK festival. A book chapter on classical minimalism
and minimal techno is forthcoming in Christoph Cox and Daniel Warner's Audio
Culture: Readings in Modern Music (Continuum Press).  He is widely credited
as coining the name of the sub-genre "Microhouse" when writing for The Wire
in 2001.  As a DJ, Philip holds a residence at Barcelona's Raum Club,
formerly held a monthly event in San Francisco called "Soda", and has
performed in New York, Austin, Portland, Seattle, and Montreal.


Philip Sherburne's website:
http://www.philipsherburne.com/

Philip on MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/194425


MIX:
Live @ Raum, Barcelona  (73min - 101MB)
http://www.kontrolsf.com/Philip_Sherburne_-_Live_@_Raum_-_Barcelona_July_2006.mp3

http://www.kontrolsf.com

--- Holt Sorenson <hso@hsomusic.com> wrote:

> On Sat, Jan 27, 2007 at 03:46:42PM -0800, Queen B
> wrote:
> >Hey guys, 
> >whats up, guys? Im planning on going to Tonal
> tonight,
> >but got no one to go with! I don't live in the
> frisco
> >area, id be coming from the south bay. I really
> dont
> >want to miss Tonal! So hit me up if you're
> interested
> >in coming with, I dont know frisco all that well. 
> >will be fun
> 
> Infos in case going earlier doesn't work or it's
> otherwise helpful:
> 
> Costco has an all night parking lot for $5 that's
> well lit and has been safe in the past:
> 450 10th St., 94103
> 
> Here's a map of the muni/metro bus route that you
> can
> use from the Costco parking lot to Tonal:
> http://www.sfmuni.com/cms/mmaps/documents/12.pdf
> 
> You have to walk a block and a half up to Folsom to
> ride route 12.
> 
> 10th has several clubs on it, so it's been pretty
> safe when I've
> been on it in the past.
> 
> Here's a map from the Costco Parking lot to Tonal:
>
http://maps.google.com/maps?f=d&hl=en&saddr=450+10th+St.,+94103&daddr=3300+18th+St.,+94103&sll=37.771902,-122.410569&sspn=0.015537,0.049396&ie=UTF8&z=15&ll=37.76644,-122.412415&spn=0.015538,0.035319&om=1
> 
> Parking is hard in the mission, that's why I'm going
> to use the Costco
> parking lot. There might be something closer to
> Tonal, in the mission,
> but I haven't been down there much, so I don't have
> any recommendations.
> 
> When I've gone to the city in the past, it's been to
> go to DNA Lounge
> (on 10th), Ruby Skye (up near Union Square), 1015
> Folsom, or a couple of
> other places.
> 
> (This isn't the exact address of the location, you
> should
> call the info line to get it if you haven't already)
> 
> Hope this helps.
> 
> -- 
> Holt Sorenson
> hso@hsomusic.com
> http://www.hsomusic.com/
> 
>

the party end up going?  I left around 5:45 because my driver was exhausted,
would have loved to stay and listen to that dirty bass all night.  God I
love good house, nothing else quite like it.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Tonal: Electric Blue underground this Sat w/ Q-Burns Abstract Message!

On Sun, Jan 28, 2007 at 09:48:25PM -0800, Matthew Johnson wrote:
>This party was incredible.  Big thanks to those who put it on.  How late did
>the party end up going?  I left around 5:45 because my driver was exhausted,
>would have loved to stay and listen to that dirty bass all night.  God I
>love good house, nothing else quite like it.

It was a great night. Speedy J @ RML was an incredible experience (I
highly recommending finding an event at RML that suits your tastes
and then going--Naut, the owner, and the rest of the RML staff,
are very approachable and excited about their facility--as well
they should be).

The eleven p.m. show (and related chatting) finished in time to
get to Tonal shortly before QBAM took the decks (while Andrew
was still spinning) and the rest of the morning was hopping,
sweaty, greasy, underground fun.

e. =0A=0A'You're Not Going to Die Tonight' =0AHomeless Man Helps Save House=
boat Resident From Drowning =0A=0ABy Allison Klein =0AWashington Post Staff=
 Writer =0AWednesday, January 24, 2007; Page B01 =0A=0AIt was unlucky that =
William "Al" Slaughter was wearing his slick, new dress shoes as he walked =
on an icy dock next to his houseboat on D.C.'s Southwest waterfront Monday =
night. =0A=0AIn an instant, he skidded deep into the 38-degree water and co=
uld not hoist himself out of the Washington Channel, he said. It was 10:30,=
 and not a soul was around to hear him cry "Help!" =0A=0AAfter about 10 min=
utes, Slaughter, 53, who is a crewman on a yacht that cruises the Potomac R=
iver, started to lose muscle control in the frigid water, he said. Just the=
n, he could not believe his eyes: Three men were ambling along the street b=
y the Washington Marina, separated from him by a seven-foot-high iron fence=
.=0A=0AHe yelped for them, and one, aided by the others, climbed over the f=
ence and ran over to Slaughter, who was struggling to keep his head above w=
ater.=0AFloyd Lipscomb, who police said is homeless, tried to pull Slaughte=
r out of the channel. But he did not have the strength to pull Slaughter an=
d his heavy wool coat out of the water, Slaughter said last night from his =
room at George Washington University Hospital.=0A=0ASo Lipscomb held on tig=
ht to Slaughter's arm and told him: " 'You're not going to die tonight. I'm=
 going to hold on to you. I got you,' " Slaughter said.=0AThe two other men=
, also homeless, identified by police as Duke "Showtime" Kelley and DeLeon =
Butler, alerted officers that a man had fallen into the water in the 1100 b=
lock of Maine Avenue. Slaughter feared he might drown right next to where h=
e lived, on a houseboat christened Finished Business.=0A=0ASlaughter said h=
e thinks he lost consciousness a few times while Lipscomb waited for help. =
But Lipscomb never let him go under, he said.=0A=0A"Had he not been there, =
I would have quietly slipped to the bottom," said Slaughter, who works for =
his brother's cruise business, Capital Yacht Charters.=0A...=0A=0Ahttp://ww=
w.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/01/23/AR2007012301647.html=
 =0A=0ASometimes the help you need the most will come from the place you le=
ast expect it.  =0A=0AAnd remember the next time become annoyed with a panh=
andler or someone cutting in line ahead of you or that really stupid person=
 you have to work with or whatever gets your goat, that you just never know=
 who may be called upon to save you or whom you might be asked to save.  Th=
e world is made from lucky coincidences and small miracles.  If you allow l=
ife to be ruled by fear, anger, and hate instead of openess, reason, and li=
ght, you might just miss the moment and end up being "Finished Business" yo=
urself.=0A=0APeace,=0A=0APeter

------=_Part_92938_14341097.1170128207835
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

The party was awesome.  Eric's set was funky and a good way to get us
started, and then Andrew & Origami kept it going with the yummy yummmy bass.
Big ups to Andrew for droppin' that Brand New Heavies track that I love so
much.

QBAM brought the shoulder shake as I knew he would and rocked the floor til
it was moist & wet. I haven't danced that much and gotten that sweaty in...
well let's just say it's been a long time. He finished with some of the
rock'n house that the hipsters love so much, and then it went deeeep and
sexy. I loved Leonard's set but was too tired to dance much longer so I left
around 5.

A few more fans would have helped the heat, but I'll admit to loving the
tropical atmosphere. humidity makes my hair curl ;) Thanks guys for a great
underground party. Huge props to all  involved!

~juju

So my employment @ Cinder Block pretty much lasted only a day!  Yes.. a
day!  What happen was the office position i was like being transitioned to
like some kinda new like position/ title thing, so the person working the
old position i was suppose to start working was finishing out his/ her
days of employment w/ the company... so in order for me to start work for
the company, the HR person, Cheryl i think her name is who happ3ns to be
old skool Homies' w/ Chris Jackson btw, had me work in the ummmm... lol...
ummm.. hmmm.. the manual labor no no no wait.. the warehouse!

So yeah.. it was my job to fold like 80 shirts per minute & ummm... clip
100 shirts per minute w/ the store tags & with this label gun thingie...
but I was timed @ folding 30 shirts & tagging like 50 shirts w/ the gun &
the manager of that department like totally wanted me to improve by the
end of the day... I mean.. seriously.. it was my 1st day man... ya know???

So i started getting the hang of it & gradually sped up  w/ my folding &
gun tagging... then i was tagging these "Rock n Roll" shirts for HOT TOPIC
& somehow i poked my finger w/ the gun accidentally & started bleeding...
no big i thought.. i asked the manager for a band aid & he started
freaking out.. he rushed me to the bathroom & like it was like this 911
dealie the way he was acting... Seriously!  I mean.. i understand that
like i was working w/ clothes & getting blood on them is like so not what
the stores wanna see!  So yeah... like my poke got all like patched up &
the manager took me to the HR office to sign liability papers so i
wouldn't sue CinderBlock for getting a small cut on my finger.  LoL.. i
was like ummmm.. yeah.. ok... whatev!  BUt yeah... it was kinda freaky how
this guy was acting w/ urgency

Then 2 hours later while i was still working & thought i was doing a good
job, Hello 2Day, i got fired 'cause the manager dude didn't think i was a
good fit for his sweat shop basically!  Well.. like 3 months later, i
finally got my $80 for a days work.

The End
-- 
Take Care <3

There's nothing wrong about talking about money.  For so many
generations, we've all been taught "don't talk about money.  Money is
a dirty topic.  Money is something that's secretive."  That is what
has gone wrong in all of our lives.  We don't talk about it.  You need
to talk about it.  It's a conversation we all need to have and it
should be a conversation you should want to have with everyone in your
life.

- Suze Orman

You had me fooled there for a minute with the quotation from Suze Orman.  B=
ut I guess it makes sense to quote someone who is Jewish about the importan=
ce of money eh Deep Hate?  FWIW she apparently also said, "=0A             =
                           People first, then money, then things."  but I g=
uess that doesn't quite have the same ring to it does it?=0A=0AOn to the de=
construction of today's QOD...=0A=0A=0ACharles P=E9guy, a French essayist, =
despite his staunch opposition to anti-Semitism, is considered to be one of=
 the inspirations of Italian Facism.=0A=0A=0AAccording to Wikipedia:=0A=0A=
=0A=0A"The Doctrine of Fascism", an article in the 1932 Enciclopedia Italia=
na, was written by the neo-Hegelian philosopher Giovanni Gentile, although =
it was attributed to Benito Mussolini.[citation needed] Fascism is describe=
d in it as a system in which "The State not only is authority which governs=
 and molds individual wills with laws and values of spiritual life, but it =
is also power which makes its will prevail abroad... For the Fascist, every=
thing is within the State and... neither individuals nor groups are outside=
 the State... For Fascism, the State is an absolute, before which individua=
ls or groups are only relative... Liberalism denied the State in the name o=
f the individual; Fascism reasserts the rights of the State as expressing t=
he real essence of the individual."[1] The article discussed other politica=
l and social doctrines of the time by describing fascism as: "the resolute =
negation of the doctrine underlying so-called scientific and Marxian social=
ism... and as rejecting (in democracy) "the absurd conventional lie of poli=
tical equalitarianism, the habit of collective irresponsibility, the myth o=
f felicity and indefinite progress".[1]=0A=0A=0A=0A=0A"Fascism is definitel=
y and absolutely opposed to the doctrines of liberalism, both in the politi=
cal and economic sphere. ... The Fascist State lays claim to rule in the ec=
onomic field no less than in others; it makes its action felt throughout th=
e length and breadth of the country by means of its corporate, social, and =
educational institutions, and all the political, economic, and spiritual fo=
rces of the nation, organised in their respective associations, circulate w=
ithin the State."[2]=0A=0A=0A=0A In the essay, French socialists Georges So=
rel, Charles Peguy, and Hubert Lagardelle are invoked as the sources of fas=
cism. Sorel's ideas concerning syndicalism and violence are much in evidenc=
e in this document. It also quotes from Ernest Renan who it says had "pre-f=
ascist intuitions". Both Sorel and Peguy were influenced by the Frenchman H=
enri Bergson. Bergson rejected the scientism, mechanical evolution and mate=
rialism of Marxist ideology. Also, Bergson promoted =E9lan vital as an evol=
utionary process. Both of these elements of Bergson appear in fascism. Muss=
olini states that fascism negates the doctrine of Marxist socialism and its=
 doctrine of historical materialism. Hubert Lagardelle, an authoritative sy=
ndicalist writer, was influenced by Pierre-Joseph Proudhon who, in turn, in=
spired anarchosyndicalism.=0A=0A=0A=0A=0AFrom a review of the book French L=
iterary Fascism: Nationalism, Anti-Semitism, and the Ideology of Culture by=
 David Carroll:=0A=0A"Despite his spirited defense of Dreyfus, P=E9guy's sp=
iritualistic=0Aapproach to politics lent itself to Fascist cooptation. In a=
n early=0Aessay, "Marcel, Premier dialogue de la cite ha(36240 unread) Yaho=
o! Mail Beta, dangrsmindrmonieuse, "P=E9guy=0Aemphasizes the inclusive natu=
re of his ideal socialist city. All within=0Ait must be compelled to join=
=97an invitation to collective acceptance,=0Abut an invitation that also ca=
rries the dark overtones of Augustine's=0Anotion of Christendom or Rousseau=
's concept of the general will. As=0ACarroll points out, at a deep level, "=
the foreign has to be radically=0Aexcluded as the greatest imaginable menac=
e to will." In other words,=0Athose elements that prove incapable of incorp=
oration must be eliminated=0Ain the name of social harmony. Though a staunc=
h anti-anti-Semite, P=E9guy=0Ahere provides an opening for later Fascists w=
ho, no less "spiritualist"=0Athan Peguy, claimed that the Jew could never b=
e assimilated and must,=0Aas a result, be thrown out by the body politic."=
=0A=0Ahttp://www.vqronline.org/articles/1996/winter/zaretsky-fascism-wrong-=
idea/=0A=0AMore on P=E9guy here: http://www.newcriterion.com/archive/20/nov=
01/peguy.htm including the following quotation,=0A"He who does not bellow t=
he truth when he knows the truth makes himself the accomplice of liars and =
forgers."=0A=0A-- Charles P=E9guy=0A=0APeace,=0A=0APeter=0A=0A=0A=0A=0A=0A=

Bam <invibe@gmail.com> wrote: "Double the Pleasure, Double the Fun"
$5 cover
21+ up
Shine @ 1337 Mission St (btwn 9th and 10th)
9PM – 2AM
Friday 2/2
www.shinesf.com

Two DJ's for the price of one, tag sets all night long!

8Ball (Space Cowboys) vs. Benchun (False Profit)
Kapt'n Kirk (Space Cowboys) vs. J9 (Angels of Bass)
Ernie Trevino (Space Cowboys) vs. Bam (Evil Breaks)

The opportunity to double your drinking pleasure: two 4 one (you flip
for it, you call it, before 11.)
And if you come with your "twin" (aka your friend and you dressed
alike) get in 2 for 1.

Mark your calendar's twice!

*all proceeds to benefit Killagirl and her family*
Donations can also be made at www.asylumvillage.com/killa-donate.htm

Subject: [sfraves] The 1 day job in Campbell Re: [sfraves] NRR: job opportunities

OK... so like the day after Chirstmas, I talk to Matt Downer on the
phone... he told me that he needed help like with his business yada yada
yada 'cause he "can't do eveything myself"... so I offered to work w/ him
& get his shit organized &  stuff 'cause at the time, we were reeaaly good
friends & stuff!  So we ended up talking that night for like 3 hours on
the phone, literally.  Then he told me all the things, all the benifits i
woiuld get by working with him & all this money i would make working for
him & yada yada la la la!  His promises even included him giving me my own
lap top & a condo for to stay at for free that he owned so i could finish
my Adult School Education & still work for him in SJ!  Dope!

So the next morning, he picks me up in Hercules & brings me all the way to
Campbell to his "office" which is basically his garage. He had me change
in grubby clothes to start work.  He told me to organize his garage while
he attended meetings all day.  OK.. now you gotta understand, by organize,
he meant file like 20 boxes of reciepts, documents, papers, jounral
thingies, accounting books, & mislleaneous papers... then there were
products he stocked from all the companies he owned that needed to be put
somewhere, this messy ass desk, a computer that needed t be put together,
phones answered, and general housekeeping (dust, wash, windex, vacum, etc)
that needed to be done!  So i slaved away that day and did what needed to
be done.  He came home like around 8PM & he was impressed with my work! 
We then spent the next 2 hours putting things in storage in the backyard!

Oh yeah.. it was my 1st night of well.. an online class that I was suppose
to like get online & do whatever, but I forgot my sylabus for the class @
home or something & didn't have the proper log in info i needed to do that
class thing online that night.

He dropped me off @ the Cal Train station by his house & well.. after 2
hours of waiting & seeing like 3 Cal Trains zoom by, i was stuck!  I
mean... it was still like holliday hours from xmas, & the trains stopped
running early.  I mean, i seriously thought he picked me up from Hercules
that morning & it was just curtious on his part to bring me home after i
was done working for the day, then I'd do the commute thing starting the
next day.  I mean... Matt didn't tell me he wasn't going to & it was
probably my bad just to assume.  BUt i dunno... I mean... we he got back
from his like 10 hour Meeting whatever & kept saying "I'm sooo tired", i
guess he was planning on it, but well... I wouldn't even ask a tired
person to do a 200 mile back & forth drive just to bring me home.  BUt
still.. ya know?

So funny enough, i didn't remember Matt's phone ### by heart & the paper i
had it written on was in Hercules & 411 didn't have it either!  I also
didn't know anyone elses phone ### i could call in the South Bay cause
well... i just didn't have my list with me.  So after a long while, i went
across the street to the Safeway Plaza & i dunno... i just figured it it
was more well lighted than the Cal Train Station & i could figure out what
i needed to do to be safe if i was gonna spend the next many hours by
myself.

So as soon as i got to Safeway, i just like stood there by the phone booth
& man, i was like heeeeeeella confuzed 'cause I was in this mondo pickle. 
But atleast I felt kinda safe.  Then this dude like came up to me and like
asked me for change to make a phone call & I lied & said i only had enough
money for me to take the train in the morning when Cal Train opened up & i
was pretty stuck.  Then he gave me this whole sob story about going to his
Sister's house in Redingin the morning, his Mom is the Hospital, his
grandmother, & calling his ex girlfriend's cousin who lived around the
corner.  So after he was done venting, then i vented to him about my whole
day & how I was stuck & why i was where i was @ the moment.  We kinda
talked for a while longer before he said that he'd like help me out & just
stay with me 'til Cal Train opened up since he was in the same predicament
as well!

Oh yeah.. this guy's name was Jack.  I actaully called him Crack Head Jack
'cause well.. he told me how he was spun for 3 days & he was like coming
down hard which is why he was soooooo emotional.  I mean.. i have a thing
about trusting strangers way to quick, but I dunno.. something about Jack
was sincere.  So i ended up giving him money to make that call & actually
a few minutes later, we were hangin' out at his ex girlfirends's cousin's
pad.  We were probably there for like an hour & 1/2 'til her parents got
home & we left!

While we were walking back to Safeway, he told me that it would probably
be better if we head downtown & kick it at some of the empty houses over
there.  Well... it was his hood, so i figured he knew what he was talking
about!  Anywaze, the next few hours we spent in downtown like going to
tacobell, walkin' around campus, & we actually hung out & slepton this
porch of this 1 abandoned house.

When daylight hit, we went to a donut shop & had coffee & donuts & had
like this loooooong ass goodbye.. I mean... we were reeeeeally close by
that point & practically knew almost everything about each other from
talkin' the whole night.  It was Awesome, sad, but hella touching!  He
told me that as soon he made it up to Redding, he was gonna call me!  We
even planned on hangin' out again, i'd like do a day trip up to Redding &
stuff.  But yeah, it took 3 hours, but i finally made it home.. Needless
to say, I didn't bother going back to work for Matt Downer, CEO again!  Oh
yeah.. he called me that night & we kinda had a mondo bitch session at
each other.. lol.. Hello 2day.. we ain't spoken since then :)  Hello 2day
-- 
Take Care <3
Peace=->Jus' Me =-> O§bY {8O)

DEREK PLASLAIKO

Some people filter through the record bins, taking what are on the wall or
record store employee suggestions. Then there are people who dig deeper into
the dusty crates, and absorb music like a sponge; ignoring labels, bucking
trends and are forever on a quest to find the perfect record. The ones that
make the staunchest of chin stroking, note taking trainspotters lose their
shit on the dancefloor, hanging on every record from one to the next.

Derek Plaslaiko unquestionably falls into the latter category. As a teen
equally transfixed by Mojo and Wizard cassettes and Minor Threat 7"s,
Plaslaiko followed the beats from his hometown 20 miles south of Detroit to
the epicenter of Detroit techno, then enjoying its third wave of success. He
quietly paid his dues on Detroit's rave circuit, and was a crucial piece of
the puzzle for the legendary Poorboy and Syst3m parties of the mid-nineties.
He quickly earned a reputation for forward thinking DJ sets that were
clinical, sophisticated and extremely sensual. This combination resulted in
a residency for Family, the weekly party at Detroit's legendary Motor.  With
a reputation for high energy sets that were versatile and tasteful,
Plaslaiko slowly became in demand on the Midwestern club circuit; sharing
the stage with such techno luminares as John Acquaviva, Kevin Saunderson,
Richardo Villalobos, Baby Ford, and Matthew Herbert. It was also during that
time Plaslaiko was asked by Carl Craig to perform at the inaugural edition
of the Detroit Electronic Music Festival.

In 2003, Plaslaiko became part of the original team of DJs at Detroit's
Untitled parties, sharing a residency with Tadd Mullinix (aka James T.
Cotton), Matthew Dear and Mike Servito. In 2004 he made the decision to head
east and set up camp in New York City, determined to bring a slice of the
Motor City to the Big Apple.  Currently, Derek is one of the resident DJs at
the Bunker (Subtonic) in NYC, as well as an integral part of the Wolf + Lamb
monthly parties. Most recently, he was honored in the Village Voice 2006's
"Best Of" poll as New York's Best Techno DJ.


Derek Plaslaiko's website:
http://plaslaiko.net
Derek on MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/plaslaiko


MIXES:

Live @ Yura Yura, Philadelphia  (2 hours - 111MB)
http://www.kontrolsf.com/AUD/Derek_Plaslaiko_-_Live_@_Yura_Yura_-_Philadelphia_07.15.06.mp3


Live @ Wolf+Lamb, New Year's Eve, New York  (3+ hours - 182MB)
http://www.kontrolsf.com/AUD/Derek_Plaslaiko_-_Live_@_Wolf+Lamb_-_NYC_12.31.05.mp3


_________________________________________________


TIM XAVIER

Tim Xavier made himself a household name for techno fans in the late 90s
with his innovative releases on Blueline, and since he has continued to push
the envelope with new sounds and ideas. His techno releases have been
consistent and solid, having signed work to major labels such as Default,
Advanced and PV. He has been featured on CD compilations by well known
techno artists such as Chris Liebing and Christian Wunsch, and his tracks
get repeated play by top names such as Luciano, Pan-Pot, Richie Hawtin,
Magda, Marco Carola, Troy Pierce and Adam Beyer.

More recently, he has expanded his talents and broadened his production
spectrum into the minimal genre, starting two new labels in 2005: LTD400 and
Klickhaus. LTD400 is his solo label featuring his own work, and the releases
have been featured on mix compilations by Ricardo Villalobos and Steve Bug.
His new project, Klickhaus, will feature his own production as well as other
artists. Tim has also collaborated with Tony Rohr as the Afternoon Coffee
Boys, their debut release on Clink selling out in days and continuously
demanding repress. Upcoming releases from them include a full EP on Cocoon
due out in February.

As if Tim isn't busy enough, he is also the owner and chief mastering
engineer at Manmade Mastering in Brooklyn, NY, where he cuts dubplates and
masters. His precise ear, attention to detail and demand for perfection have
created a devoted following with his clients. Somehow between producing,
running his labels and cutting records, he still finds time play
international gigs, sharing his sought-after sound with fans and dancefloors
alike.


Tim Xavier's website:
http://www.manmademastering.com/

Tim's discography:
http://www.discogs.com/artist/Tim%20Xavier

Tim on MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/timxavier


MIXES:

Zombie Mix  (66min6sec - 154MB)
http://www.kontrolsf.com/AUD/Tim_Xavier_-_Zombie_Mix.mp3

The Art of Happiness  (62min - 141MB)
http://www.kontrolsf.com/AUD/Tim_Xavier_-_The_Art_of_Happiness.mp3


_________________________________________________


PHILIP SHERBURNE

San Francisco critic Philip Sherburne has been heavily involved in the
electronic-music world for the past seven years, writing for publications
including the New York Times, Village Voice, Slate, XLR8R, URB, Wax Poetics,
Grooves, Nylon, RES, Neumu.net <http://neumu.net/> and many others --
including The Wire, where his "Critical Beats" column offers a monthly
roundup of experimental dance music. Philip has also written on sound art
and avant-garde practice for Frieze and Parkett, curated the companion CD
for Leonardo Music Journal's 2003 issue, and given talks at SFMOMA, PS1,
Tate Modern and the MUTEK festival. A book chapter on classical minimalism
and minimal techno is forthcoming in Christoph Cox and Daniel Warner's Audio
Culture: Readings in Modern Music (Continuum Press).  He is widely credited
as coining the name of the sub-genre "Microhouse" when writing for The Wire
in 2001.  As a DJ, Philip holds a residence at Barcelona's Raum Club,
formerly held a monthly event in San Francisco called "Soda", and has
performed in New York, Austin, Portland, Seattle, and Montreal.


Philip Sherburne's website:
http://www.philipsherburne.com/

Philip on MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/194425 <http://www.myspace.com/194425+>


MIX:
Live @ Raum, Barcelona  (73min - 101MB)
http://www.kontrolsf.com/Philip_Sherburne_-_Live_@_Raum_-_Barcelona_July_2006.mp3
